(13)  In order to preserve and safeguard the health, safety, and general welfare of the people of the city, it is necessary and advisable for the city to regulate the conduct of owners, managers, operators, agents, employees, entertainers, performers, and customers at establishments where the activities described in subsections (1) and (2) of this section occur. 
(14)  The potential dangers to the health, safety and general welfare of the people of the city posed by permitting an establishment at which the activities described in subsections (1) and (2) of this section occur to operate without first meeting the requirements for obtaining a license under this code are so great as to require the licensure of such establishments prior to their being permitted to operate. 
(15)  Requiring operators of establishments at which the activities described in subsections (1) and (2) of this section occur to keep a list of information concerning current employees, including their name, current address, mailing address, social security number, date of birth, drivers license number and criminal convictions, and certain recent past employees will help reduce the incidence of certain types of criminal behavior by facilitating the identification of potential witnesses or suspects, and by preventing minors from working in such establishments. 
(16)  Prohibiting establishments at which the activities described in subsections (1) and (2) of this section occur from operating within set distances of educational institutions, day care centers, religious institutions, residences, areas zoned or designated for residential use, and parks, at which minors are customarily found, will serve to protect minors from the adverse affects of the activities that accompany such establishments. 
(17)  Straddle dancing, unregulated private performances, and enclosed adult booths in establishments at which the activities described in subsections (1) and (2) of this section occur have resulted in indiscriminate commercial sex between strangers and poses a threat to the health of the participants and promotes the spread of communicable sexually transmitted diseases. Straddle dancing is primarily conduct rather than communication or expression. 
(Code 1982, § 3.5-19)  
Sec. 10-35. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Adult bookstore means an establishment which advertises, sells or rents, or offers for sale or rent adult material. The definition of adult bookstore is not intended to apply and it is an affirmative defense to an alleged violation of this article regarding operating an adult bookstore without an adult entertainment license if the alleged violator shows that at the establishment: 
(1)  Admission is not restricted to adults only; and 
(2)  All adult material is accessible only by employees; 
(3)  The gross income from the sale and/or rental of adult material comprises less than ten percent of the gross income from the sale and rental of the goods or services at the establishment; and 
(4)  The individual items of adult material offered for sale and/or rental comprise less than ten percent of the total individual new items publicly displayed as stock in trade in any of the following categories: books, magazines, periodicals, or other printed matter, or photographs, films, motion pictures, videotapes, slides, or other visual representations, or recordings, or other audio matter or less than ten percent of the individual used items publicly displayed at the establishment as stock in trade in the same categories set out above. 
Adult booth means a small enclosed area inside an adult entertainment establishment accessible to any person, regardless of whether a fee is charged for access. An adult booth shall not include a restroom or foyer through which the public enters or exits the establishment. 
Adult entertainment establishment means an adult theater, a massage rub, scrub or like and/or related establishment, an adult bookstore, or an adult performance establishment operated for commercial or pecuniary gain regardless of whether such establishment is licensed under this article. Operated for commercial or pecuniary gain shall not depend upon actual profit or loss. It shall be presumed that an establishment is operated for commercial or pecuniary gain if the establishment has a business tax receipt. An establishment with an adult entertainment license under this article shall be presumed to be an adult entertainment establishment. 
Adult material means any one or more of the following regardless of whether it is new or used: 
(1)  Books, magazines, periodicals or other printed matter, or photographs, films, motion pictures, videotapes, slides, or other visual representations, or recordings, or other audio matter, which have as their primary or dominant theme matter depicting, illustrating, describing or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas; or 
(2)  Instruments, novelties, devices or paraphernalia which are designed for use in connection with specified sexual activities. 
Adult performance establishment means an establishment where any employee: 
(1)  Engages in a private performance or displays or exposes any specified anatomical areas to a person other than another employee, regardless of whether the employee actually engages in dancing; 
(2)  Wears any covering, tape, pastie, or other device which simulates or otherwise gives the appearance of the display or exposure of any specified anatomical areas, regardless of whether the employee actually engages in dancing; 
(3)  Offers, solicits, or contracts to dance or perform with a person other than another employee and accepts any consideration, tip, remuneration or compensation from or on behalf of that person; or 
(4)  Dances or performs with or within three feet of a person other than another employee in consideration for any tip, remuneration or compensation from or on behalf of that person. These provisions are not intended to apply and it is an affirmative defense if the predominant business or attraction of the establishment is not offering to customers a product, service or entertainment which is intended to provide sexual stimulation or sexual gratification to such customers, and the establishment is not distinguished by an emphasis on or the advertising or promotion of materials relating to or employees depicting, describing, displaying, exposing or simulating specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. 
Adult theatre means an enclosed building, or a portion or part of an enclosed building, or an open-air theatre designed to permit viewing by patrons, including but not limited to patrons seated in automobiles, and any combination of any or all of the above, used to present on a regular basis, for any form of consideration, film material which is characterized by emphasis upon matters depicting, illustrating or relating to specified sexual activities for observation by patrons thereof, and includes but is not limited to, any hotel or motel, boardinghouse, roominghouse or other lodging for transient customers which advertises the presentation of such film material. For the purposes of this article an adult theatre includes an adult booth. 
Alcoholic beverage means all beverages containing more than one percent of alcohol by weight. It shall be prima facie evidence that a beverage is an alcoholic beverage if there is proof that the beverage in question was or is known as beer, wine, whiskey, moonshine whiskey, moonshine, shine, rum, gin, tequila, bourbon, vodka, scotch, scotch whiskey, brandy, malt liquor, or by any other similar name or names, or is contained in any container bearing any of the above names, or a name similar thereto, whether or not the container bears the manufacturer's insignia, name, or trademark. Any person who, by experience in the handling of alcoholic beverages, or who by taste, smell or drinking of such alcoholic beverages has knowledge of the alcoholic nature thereof, may testify as to his opinion about whether such beverage is an alcoholic beverage. 
Chief of police means the chief of police of the city. 
Commercial establishment means any business location, place or business conducting or allowing to be conducted on its premises any commercial activity. 
Commission means the city commission of Longwood, Florida. 
Conviction means a determination of guilt resulting from a trial or a plea has been entered, regardless whether adjudication was withheld or whether imposition of sentence was suspended. 
Employee means a person, independent contractor, subcontractor, lessee, sublessee, who works or performs or provides services at a commercial establishment, irrespective of whether they are paid a monetary salary or other wage by the owner or manager of the premises. 
Establishment means the physical plant or location or portion thereof, upon which certain commercial activities or operations are conducted for commercial or pecuniary gain. (Operated for commercial or pecuniary gain shall not depend upon actual profit or loss. Also, operated for commercial or pecuniary gain shall be presumed where the establishment has a business tax receipt.) 
Inspector means an employee of the department of planning and building services, licensing inspector, director of financial services, police department or fire department authorized herein to inspect premises licensed under this article and to take or require the actions authorized by this article in case of violations being found on licensed premises, and also to inspect premises seeking to be licensed under this article and to require corrections of unsatisfactory conditions found on said premises. 
Licensed premises means commercial establishments where adult entertainment establishment material is sold, offered, presented or stored or where any form of adult entertainment is presented, and also all other rooms, structures, or areas adjacent thereto over which the licensee or its agent or employees has some domination and control or stores its adult entertainment materials or to which its customers or patrons may freely pass, to utilize the products, material, or services purchased or obtained from the licensee, and shall include all of the floor or land areas embraced within the plan appearing on or attached to the application for the license involved and designated as such on said plan. 
Minor means anyone under the age of 18 years. 
Operator means any person who engages in or performs any activity necessary to, or which facilitates, the operation of an adult entertainment establishment, including but not limited to, the licensee, manager, owner, doorman, bouncer, bartender, disc jockey, sales clerk, ticket taker, or movie projectionist. 
Person means individuals, firms, associations, joint ventures, partnerships, estates, trusts, business trusts, syndicates, fiduciaries, corporations singular or plural, and all other groups or combinations of any or all of the above. 
Personal advertising means any action on the part of an employee or agent of an adult entertainment establishment that is designed to encourage a prospective patron to enter said establishment for the purpose of viewing specified anatomical areas or specified sexual activities and is performed by repeated speaking in a raised tone of voice, by making prominent physical gestures, such as waving or repeatedly pointing, or by holding signs or other written or pictorial statements. Personal advertising shall not include oral or physical references to an adult entertainment establishment by patrons or spectators. 
Preexisting adult entertainment establishments means any adult entertainment establishment which was in existence on the date that the ordinance from which this article derives takes effect. An existing adult entertainment establishment shall mean any adult entertainment establishment in existence when an application for an adult entertainment ordinance is filed and shall include preexisting adult entertainment establishments. 
Premises means not only rooms and areas where alcoholic beverages are sold, dispensed, offered, presented or consumed, but also all other rooms, structures or areas adjacent thereto over which the owner, employees, operator, or management at the premises has some dominion and control and to which customers or patrons may freely pass with said beverages. 
Principal stockholder means any individual, partnership or corporation that owns or controls, legally or beneficially, ten percent or more of a corporation's capital stock, and includes the officers, directors and principal stockholders of a corporation that is a principal stockholder under this article; provided that if no stockholder of a corporation owns or controls, legally or beneficially, at least ten percent of the capital stock, all stockholders shall be considered principal stockholders, and further provided, that if a corporation is registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission or pursuant to F.S. ch. 517, and its stock for sale to the general public, it shall not be considered to have any principal stockholders. 
Private performance means modeling, posing or the display or exposure of any specified anatomical area by an employee of an adult entertainment establishment to a person other than another employee while the person is in an area not accessible during such display to all other persons in the establishment, or while the person is in an area in which the person is totally or partially screened or partitioned during such display from the view of all persons outside the area. 
Religious institution means a building which is used primarily for religious worship and/or related religious activities, including religious education. 
Rub and/or scrub, massage establishment or any like establishment means a site or premises, or portion thereof, upon which any person who is an employee or who acts of or at the direction of an employee or owner, manipulates the superficial tissues of the body of another person, with any part of the body, whether or not such manipulation is aided by any electrical or mechanical or other device, or chemical preparation, but not establishments licensed under F.S. ch. 480. The term "rub or scrub" as used herein shall include the term "rub and/or scrub, massage or any like establishments." 
School means an institution of learning for minors, whether public or private, which offers instruction to students in accordance with F.S. § 232.01 and F.S. §§ 232.02(1) and 232.02(3), or which is maintained pursuant to standards set by the state commission of education, or serves as a nursery school. The definition includes a nursery school, day care center, kindergarten, elementary school, junior high school, vocational school for minors, or any special institution of learning under the jurisdiction of the state department of education, but it does not include an adult vocational or professional institution or an institution of higher education, including a community or junior college, college or university. 
Specified anatomical areas means: 
(1)  Less than completely and opaquely covered: 
a.  Human genitals or pubic region; 
b.  Any part of the human buttocks; 
c.  Human anus; or 
d.  The human female breast encompassed within an area falling below the horizontal line one would have to draw to intersect a point immediately above the top of the areola (the colored ring around the nipple). This definition shall include the entire lower portion of the human female breast, but shall not include any portion of the cleavage of the human female breast exhibited by a dress, blouse, shirt, leotard, bathing suit, or other wearing apparel, provided the areola is not so exposed. 
(2)  Human male genitals in a discernible turgid state, even if completely and opaquely covered; and 
(3)  Any simulation thereof. 
Specified criminal act means a violation of this article; a violation of any adult entertainment or adult use code or ordinance of any other municipality, county or local government; an offense under F.S. ch. 800; an offense under F.S. ch. 806; an offense under F.S. ch. 796; an offense under F.S. ch. 847; an offense under F.S. ch. 893; an offense under F.S. ch. 849; an offense under F.S. ch. 896; or an offense under F.S. ch. 794. 
Specified sexual activities means: 
(1)  Human genitals in a state of sexual stimulation, arousal, erection or tumescence; 
(2)  Display of the human anus for other than excretory functions; 
(3)  Acts of human anilingus, bestiality, buggery, cunnilingus, coprophagy, coprophilia, fellation, flagellation, masochism, masturbation, necrophilia, pederasty, pedophilia, sadism, sadomasochism, sapphism, sexual intercourse, sodomy, urolangis or zooerasty; 
(4)  Fondling or other erotic touch of human genitals, pubic region, buttock, anus or female breast; or 
(5)  Excretory functions as part of or in connection with any of the activities set forth in subsections (1) through (4) above. 
Straddle dance, also known as "lap dance," "face dance," or "friction dance" means the use by an employee, whether clothed or not, of any part of his body to rub, scrub, stroke, knead, caress, touch or fondle the genital or pubic area of a patron, whether clothed or not, while on the premises. It shall be a straddle dance regardless of whether the touch or touching occurs while the employee is displaying or exposing any specified anatomical area. It shall also be a straddle dance regardless of whether the touch or touching is direct or through a medium. Also included within this definition is in the straddling of the legs of an employee over any part of the body of a person other than another employee at the establishment, regardless of whether there is a touch or touching. 
(Code 1982, § 3.5-20; Ord. No. 17-2120 , § 1, 7-17-2017) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 10-36. - Obscenity not permitted. 
Nothing in this article shall be construed to allow or permit the possession, distribution and transportation of obscene materials or to authorize the exposing of persons under 18 years of age to motion pictures, exhibitions, shows, representations and presentations of specified sexual activities or persons displaying or exhibiting specified anatomical areas. These matters are preempted to the state and are subject to state regulations, and it is not the intent of the commission to legislate with respect to preempted matters. 
(Code 1982, § 3.5-21)  
Sec. 10-37. - Construction. 
This article shall be liberally construed to accomplish its purpose of licensing and regulating adult entertainment and related activities. Unless otherwise indicated, all provisions of this article shall apply equally to all persons regardless of sex, and to corporate or business entities where intended. The words "he," "his," and "him" as employed in this article shall be construed to apply to all persons, females as well as males. 
(Code 1982, § 3.5-22)  
Sec. 10-38. - Responsibility. 
Ultimate responsibility for the administration of this article is vested in the city manager. The department of financial services is responsible for receiving and issuing all licenses and permits. The chief of police is responsible for verifying all information contained on an application, made pursuant to section 10-63, for inspecting proposed or existing adult entertainment establishments in order to ascertain compliance with applicable criminal statutes and ordinances, including those set forth in other articles of this code, for determining whether adult entertainment license applicants have been convicted of a specified criminal act within the previous five years, and for enforcing applicable criminal statutes and ordinances, including those set forth in section 10-143. The department of planning and building services is responsible for the inspection of licensed premises and premises applying for a license in order to pass upon the construction and physical configuration of the premises involved. The fire chief is responsible for the inspection of licensed premises, and premises applying for a license, to ascertain compliance with all fire prevention codes, statutes or ordinances in effect in the city. The department of planning and building services is responsible for the inspection of licensed premises and premises applying for a license to ascertain compliance with health requirements, county health codes, and all other applicable municipal or state laws and regulations. The department of planning and building services is responsible for ascertaining compliance with all locational requirements of this article, all land use regulations and other applicable land use laws. 
(Code 1982, § 3.5-23)  
Sec. 10-39. - Power of administrative agencies. 
When a provision of this article gives the chief of police, the director of financial services, licensing clerk, the department of planning and building services or the fire chief the authority or duty to act, the said authority or duty vests in the chief of police, the director of financial services, the department head of the department of planning and building services, or the fire chief or in any inspector or employee of same who is given the authority or duty to act in accordance with this article and the administrative procedures of the agency or office concerned. 
(Code 1982, § 3.5-24)  
Secs. 10-40—10-60. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 
 
Sec. 10-61. - Required. 
(a)  General requirements. No adult entertainment establishment shall be permitted to do business without first obtaining a license under this article. For adult entertainment establishments in existence and operation as of the effective date hereof, permission to operate is hereby granted until an application for a license under this article is filed with the department of financial services, not later than 45 days after said date, and thereafter for so long a time as is necessary for the city to issue or to deny issuance of a license under the chapter. The business shall immediately cease operation should the business fail to apply for a license within 45 days. 
(b)  Classification. Licenses referred to in this article shall be classified as follows: 
(1)  Adult bookstore; 
(2)  Adult motion picture theater; 
(3)  Rub and/or scrub establishment; and 
(4)  Adult performance establishment. 
Each application for a license shall state the classification and location for which it is to be issued and shall be limited to one classification of license. 
(Code 1982, § 3.5-25; Ord. No. 17-2120 , § 1, 7-17-2017)  
Sec. 10-62. - Disqualification and revocation of licenses. 
(a)  Noncompliance of premises. No license shall be issued by the department of financial services, if, as a result of investigations by the chief of police, department of planning and building services or the fire chief or other applicable city official, determines that the proposed licensed premises does not meet each and every one of the general and special requirements under this article for which license has been sought, or if the proposed licensed premises fails to satisfy all applicable building, land use, health and fire codes, ordinances, statutes or regulations, whether federal, state or local, nor shall any license be issued should false information be given in the application for license. 
(b)  Issuance of license where prior license has been revoked or suspended. No license shall be issued to: 
(1)  Any person whose license under this article is suspended at the time of application or prior to license issuance; 
(2)  Any partnership, a partner of which has a license suspended under this article at the time of application or prior to license issuance; 
(3)  Any corporation of which an officer, director or principal stockholder has its license under this article suspended at the time of application for license or prior to issuance thereof; or 
(4)  Any individual who is or was at the time of suspension a partner in a partnership or an officer, director or principal stockholder of a corporation, whose license under this article is suspended at the time of application for license or prior to issuance thereof. 
(c)  Noncompliance with application. No license shall be issued if the applicant fails to execute the application described herein, or if having completed it, fails to disclose or discloses falsely, the information required by this article. 
(d)  Failure to comply with Florida Statutes. No license shall be issued if the applicant has failed to comply with F.S. chs. 620, 607 or F.S. § 865.09. 
(e)  Revocation. If it should be determined that a license has been issued as a result of false information, misrepresentation of fact, or material mistake of fact, or that the licensee has failed to comply with section 10-63, such license shall be revoked. If revoked, the department of financial services shall notify the licensee of same and the reasons thereof at the designated address, by personal service or certified mail. If a license is revoked, the licensee shall not be allowed to obtain another adult entertainment license, and no license shall be issued again to any other person for the location upon which the adult entertainment establishment was situated. The revocation shall take effect ten days after the date the department of financial services mails the notice of revocation to the licensee or on the date the licensee delivers his license to the director of financial services, whichever happens first. 
(Code 1982, § 3.5-26)  
Sec. 10-63. - License application; application fee. 
(a)  Required information and documents. Any person desiring to engage in the business of operating an adult entertainment establishment shall file with the director of financial services a sworn application on forms supplied by the department of financial services; the application shall contain the following information and shall be accompanied by the following documents: 
(1)  If the applicant is: 
a.  An individual, his legal name, date of birth, business address and phone number (or residence if none); 
b.  A partnership, the full name of the partnership, whether general or limited, the name, phone number and residential address of the individual applying for the license on behalf of the partnership, the names and addresses of all the partners and, if a limited partnership, evidence of compliance with F.S. ch. 620, and a copy of any existing partnership agreement; or 
c.  A corporation, the corporate name, the date of incorporation, the address and phone numbers of the primary business location of said corporation, evidence that the corporation is in good standing and has not acted in derogation of the conditions set forth in F.S. ch. 607, the name, residential address and phone number of the individual applying for the license on behalf of the corporation, and the names and capacity of all the officers, directors and principal stock holders. 
(2)  If the business is to be conducted under a name other than that of the applicant, the business name and the county of registration under F.S. § 865.09; 
(3)  Whether the applicant or any of the other individuals listed pursuant to subsection (a)(1) of this section has, within the five-year period immediately preceding the date of the application, been convicted of a specified criminal act, and, if so, the criminal act involved, the date of conviction and the place of conviction; 
(4)  Whether the applicant or any of the other individuals listed pursuant to subsection (a)(1) of this section has his license under this article or any other similar state or local regulation, law or ordinance, at the time of application, suspended or revoked, and if so, including the date and place of the suspension or revocation; 
(5)  The single classification as set forth above of the license for which the application is being filed; 
(6)  Whether the applicant holds any other licenses to conduct an adult entertainment establishment, and if so, the date of issuance and locations of such licensed premises; 
(7)  The proposed street location of the business; 
(8)  An entire site plan prepared by a licensed architect or draftsman, drawn to appropriate scale, of the proposed licensed premises indicating the areas to be covered by the license, including driveways, entrances, parking, all windows, doors, entrances and exits and the fixed structural features of the proposed licensed premises. The term "fixed structural features" shall include immovable partitions and counters and similar structures that are intended to be permanent; 
(9)  A designated return address where all future notices from the city may be sent; 
(10)  If a massage establishment, a valid state license issued pursuant to F.S. ch. 480; and 
(11)  The applicant's social security number or employer's tax identification number and either the applicant's driver's license number or the number of a state or federally issued identification card. 
(b)  Continuing duty/monthly reports. Each applicant shall be under a continuing duty to disclose to the department of financial services any changes or alterations in the information or disclosures required by this article for licensing, and the failure to do so shall be a violation of this article. All adult entertainment establishments shall file monthly reports reflecting the legal name, stage name if applicable, drivers license number, social security number and date of birth, together with a copy of a photo identification card of all employees, independent contractors or persons otherwise working at any adult entertainment establishment. Reports shall be due between the first and fifth day of each month and shall be considered delinquent and in violation of this article if not filed by the fifth day of each month. 
(c)  Application fee. Each application shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable fee as set out in Appendix B, payable at the time the application is filed. 
(d)  Consent. By applying for a license under this code, the applicant shall be deemed to have consented to the provisions of this code and to the exercise of their responsibilities under this code by the agents or departments of the city. 
(Code 1982, § 3.5-27)  
Sec. 10-64. - Investigation. 
Upon receipt of an application properly filed with the department of financial services and upon payment of the application fee, the department of financial services shall immediately stamp the application with the date it was received and shall immediately thereafter send a copy of the application to the chief of police, the department of planning and building services and the fire chief. Each department shall promptly conduct an investigation of the applicant, application, and the proposed establishment in accordance with its responsibilities set forth in this section to determine whether false, incomplete, or incorrect information was given on the application or whether the proposed establishment will be in violation of any provision of this article, this Code and other applicable laws and regulations relating to construction, safety, fire protection, land use, public health or any lease, deed restriction or court order. At the conclusion of its investigation, each department shall forward its findings to the director of financial services within 21 days and shall state whether the department finds that false, incomplete or incorrect information was given on the application or whether the proposed establishment will be in violation of any provision of this article or of any building, fire, health, or land use statute, code, ordinance, regulation, lease, deed restriction, or court order. In the event a complete police investigation of the application has not been completed within 21 days, the chief of police shall submit to the department of financial services a precise statement of the reasons why the findings have not been completed. The department of financial services shall review the statement and grant an extension of time for completion of the investigation if the failure to submit the findings within 21 days is solely due to reasons beyond the control of the police. Reasons solely beyond the control of the police shall include, but are not limited to, delays in obtaining or receiving requested information from the Federal Bureau of Investigation or similar information from other states or jurisdictions. In the event an extension of time is approved by the director of financial services, the chief of police shall have an additional 14 days to submit the findings of fact. 
(Code 1982, § 3.5-28)  
Sec. 10-65. - Issuance or denial. 
(a)  Approval and issuance. Upon the completion of the investigation of any application by the department of financial services, the chief of police, the department of planning and building department, and the fire chief, the department of financial services shall approve the application if none of the departments have made a finding that would require the application to be denied. If approved, the department of financial services shall notify the applicant of the granting and issue the license to the applicant upon payment of the appropriate license fee provided for in section 10-63. 
(b)  Disapproval and denial. The city shall review the findings reported by the departments and deny the application for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  The application contains material false information or is incomplete; 
(2)  The granting of the application would violate a statute or ordinance, deed restriction, lease, or an order from a court of law which prohibits the applicant from obtaining an adult entertainment establishment license. 
(3)  The applicant or any of the other individuals listed pursuant to section 10-63(a)(1)c. has had a license under this article suspended or revoked by the department of financial services. 
If the department of financial services denies the application, he shall notify the applicant of the denial, and state the reason for the denial. 
(c)  Notification within 28 days. The department of financial services shall approve or disapprove all applications within 28 days from the date a completed application has been submitted. Upon the expiration of the 28th day, unless an extension of time for completion of the findings pursuant to this section has been approved by the department of financial services, the applicant shall be permitted to begin operating the establishment for which a license is sought, unless and until the department of financial services notifies the applicant of a denial of the application and states the reasons for that denial. Reapplication shall not take place until six months from date of denial and shall require the payment of a new application fee. 
(Code 1982, § 3.5-29)  
Sec. 10-66. - Appeal. 
Within 30 days after the mailing or delivery of either a notice of denial of an application for a license or a notification of the suspension or revocation of a license, the applicant or licensee may take an appeal to the Circuit Court of the Eighteenth Judicial Circuit, in and for Seminole County, Florida. 
(Code 1982, § 3.5-30)  
Sec. 10-67. - Limitation on licenses and licensed premises. 
There shall be no limitation on the number of licenses issued, but licensed premises shall observe the locational restrictions contained in sections 10-162 and 10-163. A licensed premises may be owned by the licensee or may be leased by the licensee from a person not a licensee under this article; provided, that a licensee who is a tenant or lessee may not surrender his tenancy or lease to the owner or lessor if by so doing the said owner or lessor will take possession, control and operation of the licensed premises and the business licensed under this article, unless the license is transferred as provided for herein, and further provided that a licensee who is the owner of the licensed premises may not lease or otherwise give up possession, control, and operation of the licensed premises and the business licensed under this article to any other individual, partnership or corporation, unless the license is transferred as provided in section 10-70. 
(Code 1982, § 3.5-31)  
Sec. 10-68. - Display of license; mutilation prohibited. 
All licensees licensed under this article shall display their licenses in conspicuous places on their licensed premises in a clear, transparent cover or frame. The license shall be available for inspection at all times by the public; failure to do so shall be a violation of this article. It shall be a violation of this article to mutilate, cover, obstruct or remove a license so displayed, or authorize same. A lost or destroyed license may be replaced by application to the department of financial services, which shall issue a duplicate upon payment of a fee as set out in appendix B. 
(Code 1982, § 3.5-32)  
Sec. 10-69. - Term of license; renewals. 
(a)  Term. All licenses issued and renewed under this article shall be for terms as already established for all other business licenses. 
(b)  Renewals. A licensee under this article shall be entitled to a renewal of his annual license from year to year, as a matter of course, by presenting the license for the previous year, or satisfactory evidence of its loss or destruction to the department of financial services, by updating all information disclosed by the licensee on its original application for license, and by paying the appropriate license fee. 
(c)  Other provisions. All other provisions of the city Code concerning business licenses which are not in conflict with this section shall apply to licensing. 
(Code 1982, § 3.5-33)  
Sec. 10-70. - Licensee moving to a new location; changing name of business. 
(a)  New location. A licensee may move his licensed premises to a new location and operate at the new location upon approval by the chief of police, the department of planning and building services, and the fire chief of the licensee's application for a change of location. In order to do so, the licensee shall submit to the department of financial services an application for a change of location, stating the new location address, accompanied by an application fee as set out in Appendix B at the time the application is filed. The application shall contain, or have attached to it, a site plan, prepared as provided herein, drawn to appropriate scale, of the licensed premises at the new location indicating the area to be included in the new licensed premises, all entrances and exits and the fixed structural features and all areas of the new licensed premises. Upon approval of the application, there shall be issued to the licensee a license for the new location without the payment of any further fee. 
(b)  Change of name. No licensee may change the name of the business located at his licensed premises without first giving the director of financial services evidence of compliance with the Florida Fictitious Name Act, if applicable, and making payment to the director of financial services a change of name fee as set out in Appendix B. 
(Code 1982, § 3.5-34)  
Sec. 10-71. - Suspension of license. 
(a)  Violations of health, building, land use or fire provisions. In the event a previously licensed premises is thereafter found in violation of health, building, land use or fire provisions of this article, the appropriate agency shall notify the licensee of said violation according to the standard procedures of the agency and shall follow its normal agency procedures for correcting said violations and shall grant the licensee the right to exhaust applicable administrative remedies. Should the licensee fail either to correct the violation or to obtain an administrative reversal of the agency's finding, the appropriate agency shall notify the department of financial services, who shall forthwith initiate procedures for suspension of the license as set forth below. 
(b)  Other violations. In the event a jury, judge, administrative official, or other determiner of fact finds that a licensee has violated the provisions of this article, whether or not an adjudication of guilt has been entered, the department of financial services shall forthwith initiate procedures for suspension of license. 
(c)  Suspension or nonissuance of license. 
(1)  Procedure. Upon receiving notice that a licensee, or its employees, manager, subcontractors or other business associates have violated a provision of this article, as provided in subsection (a) of this section, or that an applicant does not meet the criteria for the issuance of a license, the director of financial services shall forthwith schedule a meeting between the city attorney, city manager, chief of police, fire chief and director of the building and planning department. At said meeting the alleged violation or denial of an application shall be reviewed. A vote shall be taken at the conclusion of the meeting (or completion of any continuation of a meeting). If a majority of the persons attending the meeting vote to suspend or not issue a license, the director of financial services shall notify the licensee or applicant of the decision. In the case of an application for license the meeting shall be held and a decision made within 30 days of application for a license. Notification of the decision shall be by personal service or certified mail and shall be sent to the designated return address on the license application, which shall be considered the correct address. 
(2)  Proof of suspension; felony conviction. Whenever a licensee, 
a.  If an individual, the licensee, or 
b.  If a partnership, then any partner thereof, or 
c.  If a corporation, then any officer or director or principal stockholder thereof, becomes convicted of a specified criminal act, the licensee shall immediately notify the city clerk, and shall have seven days to furnish adequate proof that the convicted individual has been removed from his said position; the continued operation of an adult entertainment establishment after the expiration of said seven days, without such proof, shall be a violation of this article. 
(3)  Periods of suspension. A single violation, other than subsection (c)(2) of this section shall result in suspension of the adult entertainment license for 90 days. Upon a second violation of this article within a period of two years from the date of a prior violation of this article, including any time during which the license was suspended, the license shall be suspended for 180 days. Upon a third violation of this article the license shall be revoked. All periods of suspension shall begin on the fifth day from the date the department of financial services personally serves or mails a notice of suspension to the licensee or on the date the licensee delivers his license to the director of financial services, whichever comes first. 
(4)  Surrender of license required. If a licensee, after having been mailed by certified mail, return receipt requested, notice of the suspension of his license in the manner herein provided, fails to surrender his license to the department of financial services within five days, or fails otherwise to account for the license to the satisfaction of the department of financial services, the suspension shall be extended until surrendered or accounted for and shall not expire until a period has elapsed after the date of surrender of the license, or after the date of expiration of the license, whichever comes first. 
(5)  Correction of violation. When a license is suspended for a violation of a health, building, land use or fire provision of this article, as described in subsection (a) of this section, the license shall not be reissued until said violation is corrected. 
(Code 1982, § 3.5-35)  
Sec. 10-72. - License fee. 
(a)  Levy of fees. There are levied annual license fees under this article for an adult entertainment establishment as set out in appendix B for the following: 
(1)  An adult video and/or novelty and/or bookstore, a fee as set out in appendix B; 
(2)  A massage, rub/scrub or like establishment, a fee as set out in appendix B; 
(3)  An adult motion picture theater, a fee as set out in appendix B and in addition, as follows: 
a.  Having only adult booths, a fee as set out in appendix B for each booth; 
b.  Having only a hall or auditorium or places or seats for outdoor viewing, a fee as set out in appendix B for each seat; 
c.  Having only an area outdoors designed to permit viewing by customers seated in vehicles, a fee as set out in appendix B for each parking space; 
d.  Having a combination of a., b. and/or c., the cumulative license fee applicable to each under such subsections; 
e.  Any hotel, motel, boardinghouse, roominghouse or other lodging for transient customers which advertises the presentation of such film material, a fee as set out in appendix B; 
(4)  An adult performance establishment, a fee as set out in appendix B. 
(b)  License fee as regulatory fees. The license fees collected under this article are fees paid for the purposes of examination and inspection of licensed premises under this article and the costs associated with maintenance thereof, and are declared to be regulatory fees in addition to and not in lieu of the local business taxes imposed by other sections of the Code of the city. The license fees in this article are not enacted for the purpose of raising general revenue. The payment of a license fee under this article shall not relieve any licensee or other person of liability for and the responsibility of paying a local business tax where the same is required by other sections of the city Code and other regulatory agencies, and for doing such acts and providing such information as may be required by said codes or regulations. However, an establishment that pays a license fee pursuant to this section will not have to pay the license fee for nonadult book, video or novelty store. 
(Code 1982, § 3.5-36; Ord. No. 17-2120 , § 1, 7-17-2017)  
Sec. 10-73. - Records and reports; consent by licensee. 
Each licensee shall keep such records and make such reports as may be required by this article in the implementation thereof, and to carry out its purpose. The failure to do so shall be a violation of this article. By applying for a license under this article, an individual, partnership or corporation shall be deemed to have consented to the provisions of this article and to the exercise by the director of financial services and other interested agencies of the powers given by section 10-97 in the manner therein specified. 
(Code 1982, § 3.5-37)  
Secs. 10-74—10-90. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - REQUIREMENTS 
 
Sec. 10-91. - Generally. 
In addition to the special requirements contained herein, each licensed premises shall: 
(1)  Conform to the requirements of F.S. ch. 381 and the rules and regulations of the state department of health made pursuant thereto. Each licensed premises shall be deemed to be a "place serving the public" for the purpose of sanitary facilities; provided, that when more than one license is issued for a single location, they shall collectively be considered as one licensed premises if customers may circulate freely through the entire area of the licensed premises; 
(2)  Keep the adult entertainment license posted in a conspicuous place at the establishment available for inspection by the public at all times. 
(3)  Maintain all exterior walls and surfaces of the establishment, excluding signs, a single achromatic or light pastel color and shall maintain all awnings, canopies, window shutters, window treatment, or other trim the same color or a single different shade of the same achromatic or light pastel color. The trim color shall not exceed 20 percent of the entire exterior surface of the building. Nothing in this subsection shall be construed to require the painting of an otherwise unpainted exterior portion of an establishment such as brick or stone. 
(4)  Install, construct, keep, maintain, or allow only those signs at the establishment which comply with the Longwood development code of Longwood, Florida, and the provisions of this subsection. 
a.  No sign shall contain any flashing lights, photographs, silhouettes, drawings or pictorial representations of any manner (except for the logo of the establishment, provided the logo shall not contain any specified anatomical areas, or any male or female forms at or below the clavicle), 
b.  No sign shall contain in the name or logo of the establishment, or otherwise, the words "nude," "nudity," "naked," "topless," "go-go," or "dancer," or other words or material depicting or describing, specified anatomical areas or sexual activities. 
c.  The failure to abide by any such regulation as herein stated is a violation of this article. 
(Code 1982, § 3.5-37.1)  
Sec. 10-92. - Advertising. 
It shall be a violation of this article for any adult entertainment establishment to: 
(1)  Display a sign advertising the presentation of any activity prohibited by a state statute, an ordinance of the county, or an ordinance, including this article, of the city; 
(2)  Display a sign capable of leading a reasonable person to believe that the establishment engages in an activity prohibited by a state statute, an ordinance of the county, or an ordinance of the city; 
(3)  Erect, install, maintain, alter or operate any sign in violation of the Longwood development code of Longwood, Florida; 
(4)  Engage in, encourage, or permit the display of a sign, or any form of personal advertising, for the commercial benefit of the individual who displays or exhibits specific anatomical areas within the establishment or which offers the availability of viewing specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas by description thereof. Personal advertising shall include, but not be limited to any person standing, sitting or otherwise being on the exterior of the building or window or opening in the building holding a sign, waiving at persons or in any manner attempting to get customers to enter the establishment. 
(5)  Except for existing establishments existing signs at the time of the adoption of this ordinance, to place any signs or other advertising of adult entertainment establishment on or within view of State Road 434, U.S. Highway 17-92 or County Road 427 and North Street within the city limits. 
(Code 1982, § 3.5-38)  
Sec. 10-93. - Adult bookstore. 
In addition to the general requirements contained herein, an adult bookstore shall observe the following special requirements and be in violation of this article if it fails to do so: 
(1)  All materials, devices and novelties shall be so displayed that they cannot be seen by anyone other than customers who have entered the licensed premises. 
(2)  The interior of any enclosures must be visible from the general area of the store as set forth herein. 
(Code 1982, § 3.5-39)  
Sec. 10-94. - Rub, massage, scrub or any like establishments. 
In addition to the general requirements contained herein, a massage, rub or scrub or like establishment shall observe the following special requirements and be in violation of this article if it fails to do so: 
(1)  Dressing rooms shall be proportioned to allow one person per room and separate dressing rooms shall be provided for men and women. Floors shall be of a smooth impervious material with a nonslip surface and shall be covered at the wall junction for thorough cleaning. Partition walls shall terminate at least six inches above the floor or be placed on continuous raised masonry or concrete bases at least four inches high. 
(2)  One shower shall be provided for each patron and separate shower facilities shall be provided for men and women. Floors and partition walls shall be constructed as required in subsection (1) of this section for dressing rooms, and duck boards or wooden gratings may be used on shower floors if duplicate sets are provided and rotated in use. 
(3)  One locker shall be provided for each patron who is expected to be on the licensed premises at one time, which shall be of sufficient size to hold clothing and other articles of wearing apparel. Each locker shall be capable of being locked by the patron, with no one else having the key so long as the patron is using the locker, or the locker shall be under the constant attention and supervision of an attendant. 
(4)  Rub, massage and/or scrub of a person by another person who displays or exhibits specified anatomical areas is prohibited. 
(5)  No person shall touch the genitals of another person. 
(6)  Nothing in this article shall be construed to permit or authorize any acts or activities that are prohibited by state law. 
(Code 1982, § 3.5-40)  
Sec. 10-95. - Adult theatres; additional prohibited activities. 
In addition to general requirements contained herein, an adult theatre shall observe the following special requirements and shall be in violation of this article if it fails to do so: 
(1)  Each adult booth shall be open or have a rectangular shaped entranceway not less than 36 inches wide nor less than six feet high. 
(2)  Each adult booth shall have sufficient seats or couches to accommodate the maximum number of persons expected to use the booth. The maximum number of persons who may occupy a booth shall be stated on or near the entranceway, and only that number shall be permitted to be in a booth at one time. Each booth shall be illuminated by a minimum of a 25 watt white bulb in the ceiling of the booth, to be illuminated during all hours of operation. 
(3)  All areas where a patron or customer is to be positioned in an adult booth must be visible from a continuous main aisle and must not be obscured by any curtain, door, wall or other enclosure. 
(4)  In addition to the sanitary facilities required elsewhere herein, there shall be provided within or adjacent to the common corridor, passageway or area in adult motion picture theatres having adult motion picture booths, adequate lavatories equipped with running water, hand-cleaning soap or detergent and sanitary towels or hand-drying devices; common towels are prohibited. 
(5)  An adult theatre designed to permit viewing by patrons seated in automobiles shall have the motion picture screen so situated, or the perimeter of the licensed premises so screened, that the projected film material may not be seen from any location that is not on the licensed premises. 
(Code 1982, § 3.5-41)  
Sec. 10-96. - Adult performance establishment. 
In addition to the general requirements contained herein, an adult performance establishment shall observe the following requirements and shall be in violation of this article if it fails to do so: 
(1)  Persons engaged in displaying or exposing specified anatomical areas are prohibited from dancing or simulating sexual activity with any patron, spectator, employee, or other person on the premises of an adult performance establishment. 
(2)  No person in an adult performance establishment shall engage in the display or exposition of specified anatomical areas except while the person is positioned in an entertainment area consisting of a platform or other structure raised a minimum of 18 inches above the immediately surrounding area and encompassing an area of at least 100 square feet, and while the person is positioned in a partition area at least three feet from a patron or spectator. 
(3)  No spectator or patron shall be present in the entertainment area, defined in subsection (2) of this section, during the course of any performance involving the display or exposition of specified anatomical areas. 
(4)  No employee shall provide and no operator shall permit, suffer or allow a private performance to occur until and unless the area in which the private performance occurs shall: 
a.  Have a permanently open entrance not less than 36 inches wide and not less than six feet high, which entrance shall not have any curtain rods, hinges, rails, or the like which would allow the entrance to be closed or partially closed by any curtain, door or other partition; and 
b.  Have a wall to wall, floor to ceiling partition of permanent solid construction without any holes or openings, which partition may be completely or partially transparent, and which partition separates the employee from the person viewing the private performance. 
(5)  Nothing in this article pertaining to adult dancing establishments shall be construed to permit or authorize any acts or activities therein that are prohibited by state law. 
(Code 1982, § 3.5-42)  
Sec. 10-97. - Employee records. 
(a)  An adult entertainment establishment shall maintain a record of all employees who are currently employed by the establishment, and of all former employees who were employed by the establishment during the preceding one-year period. The record shall contain the current or former employee's full legal name, including any aliases, including stage name(s), date of birth, residential address, residential telephone number (if any), social security number, driver's license number or state or federally issued identification card number, and a recent photograph of the employee and a copy of the business tax receipt if an independent contractor. 
(b)  The original records required by subsection (a) of this section, or true and exact photocopies thereof, shall be kept at the establishment at all times. 
(c)  All operators of the establishment shall be responsible for knowing the location of the original records, or the true and exact photocopies thereof. 
(d)  An operator of the establishment shall, upon request by a law enforcement officer when the establishment is open for business, immediately make available for copying and inspection the original records, or the true and exact photocopies thereof. 
(Code 1982, § 3.5-43; Ord. No. 17-2120 , § 1, 7-17-2017)  
Secs. 10-98—10-120. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - PROHIBITED ACTS 
 
Sec. 10-121. - Specific prohibited activities. 
(a)  It shall be a violation of this article and unlawful for any employee as defined in this article to engage in any sexual activity on the licensed premises in the presence of patrons or spectators. 
(b)  It shall be a violation of this article and unlawful for any employee, customer or patron of a licensed premises to participate in a straddle dance on the licensed premises. 
(c)  It shall be a violation of this article and unlawful for any patron or employee of a licensed premises, while on the licensed premises (or within the scope of his employment as an employee), to contract to perform for any form of consideration, a straddle dance within 500 feet of the licensed premises. 
(d)  It shall be a violation of this article and unlawful for an employee of a licensed premises to contract to touch, with any body parts or devices, the pubic area or genitals of a customer or patron, whether said employee is clothed or not. 
(e)  It shall be a violation of this article and unlawful for a patron of licensed premises to touch or to contract for any form of consideration to touch, with any body parts or devices, an employee's pubic area or genitals, whether said employee is clothed or not. 
(Code 1982, § 3.5-44)  
Sec. 10-122. - Alcoholic beverages prohibited. 
(a)  The sale, dispensing or permitting of consumption of alcoholic beverages at the licensed premises of an adult entertainment establishment where specified anatomical areas are exposed is prohibited, and unlawful and a violation of this article. 
(b)  The consumption, possession or otherwise having custody of alcoholic beverages while on the licensed premises of an adult entertainment establishment where specified anatomical areas are exposed is prohibited, and unlawful and a violation of this article. 
(Code 1982, § 3.5-45)  
Sec. 10-123. - Admission of minors unlawful. 
It shall be a violation of this article and unlawful for any employee, operator, owner or manager of a licensed adult entertainment establishment to admit or to permit the admission of minors within a licensed premises. 
(Code 1982, § 3.5-46)  
Sec. 10-124. - Sale to minors unlawful. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, barter, give, or to offer to sell, barter or give, to any minor any service, material, device or thing sold or offered for sale by an adult entertainment establishment. 
(Code 1982, § 3.5-47)  
Sec. 10-125. - Hours of operation. 
It shall be unlawful between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 8:00 a.m. of any day and between the hours of 2:00 a.m. each Sunday and 12:00 noon of each Sunday for: 
(1)  An operator of an adult entertainment establishment to allow such establishment to remain open for business, or to allow, suffer or permit any employee to engage in a performance, solicit a performance, make a sale, solicit a sale, provide a service, or solicit a service. 
(2)  An employee of an adult entertainment establishment to engage in a performance, solicit a performance, make a sale, solicit a sale, provide a service or solicit a service. 
(Code 1982, § 3.5-48)  
Secs. 10-126—10-140. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - SPECIAL PROVISIONS 
 
Sec. 10-141. - Operation of unlicensed premises unlawful. 
It shall be unlawful and a violation of this article for any person to operate or be employed by an adult entertainment establishment unless such business shall have a currently valid license therefor under this article, which license shall not be under the supervision or permanently or conditionally revoked. 
(Code 1982, § 3.5-49)  
Sec. 10-142. - Permitting violations of chapter or unlawful acts prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful and a violation of this article to be a licensee, operator, or employee where violations of this article have occurred if illegal acts take place on the licensed premises, if the licensee, operator, or any employee thereof knows, or has reason to know, that such violations or illegal acts are taking place, and the licensee, operator or employee has failed to remove himself from the premises and has failed to notify the police of the illegal acts or violations of this article. For the purposes of this article, any individuals present on the premises who are responsible for managing or supervising the day-to-day operations of the establishment shall be deemed to act on behalf of the licensee and their actions or knowledge shall be imputed to the licensee. 
(Code 1982, § 3.5-50)  
Sec. 10-143. - Immunity from prosecution. 
All officers and employees of the city who are acting within the scope of their authority and duties under this article shall be immune from prosecution, civil and criminal, for trespass upon real property. 
(Code 1982, § 3.5-51)  
Secs. 10-144—10-160. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 6. - PROHIBITED LOCATIONS 
 
Sec. 10-161. - Prohibited locations and distances. 
No persons shall cause or permit the establishment, substantial enlargement or transfer of ownership or control of an adult entertainment establishment within 150 feet of an existing or preexisting adult entertainment establishment; within 1,000 feet of a school or public recreation facility; within 750 feet of any local, state or federal office building, including but not limited to U.S. Post Offices which are in existence, planned or under construction, within 1,500 feet of any religious institutions; within 750 feet of an area with a residential land use as designated on the city's future land use map; or within 1,500 feet of an establishment that sells alcohol for consumption on the premises. These requirements are independent of and do not supersede the distance requirements for alcoholic beverages establishments contained in the city Code. Substantial enlargement shall mean increasing the size of the licensed premises. The above distance requirements shall be considered locational rather than land use requirements. Other prohibited locations: No new adult entertainment establishment shall be established or enlarged on the corridor (within 300 feet of either side of the right-of-way) of State Road 434, U.S. Highway 17-92, County Road 427 or North Street. 
(Code 1982, § 3.5-52)  
Sec. 10-162. - Measurement of distance. 
Distance from a proposed adult entertainment establishment to an existing adult entertainment establishment, a church, an establishment that sells alcohol for consumption on the premises, a public recreation facility or a school shall be measured by following a direct line from that point of the property of the proposed adult entertainment establishment that is closest to the nearest point of the property any existing adult entertainment establishment, or the nearest point of the church grounds, the place that sells alcohol for consumption on the premises or the public recreation facility, or in the case of a school or religious institution, to the nearest point on the school or religious institution, to the nearest point on the school or religious grounds in use as a part of the school or religious facilities. The distance from the property of the proposed adult entertainment establishment to an area zoned for residential use shall be measured by a direct line from that point of the residential area nearest any point of the property of the proposed adult entertainment establishment. 
(Code 1982, § 3.5-53)  
Sec. 10-163. - Land use. 
(a)  Land use category. Adult entertainment establishments shall be allowed to locate in an industrial (IND) land use subject to the standards and criteria of the Longwood Development Code and this article. Adult entertainment establishments shall not be allowed in any other land use category. 
(b)  Annexation; relocation. Any adult entertainment establishment which exists in locations outside of an industrial land use and which are annexed into the city after this article takes effect, shall relocate their adult entertainment business within three years of the effective date of the annexation. 
(Code 1982, § 3.5-54)  
Sec. 10-164. - Exception; restroom use. 
Notwithstanding any provisions of this article to the contrary, it shall not be unlawful for any person or employee of a commercial establishment, or adult entertainment establishment, to expose specified anatomical areas in connection with the use of an approved sanitary facilities commonly known as restrooms. However, specified anatomical areas shall be exposed or displayed only in connection with excretory functions. 
(Code 1982, § 3.5-55)  
Secs. 10-165—10-180. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 7. - VIOLATION; PRESUMPTIONS, PROOF, PENALTIES AND POWERS 
 
Sec. 10-181. - Presumptions. 
The following presumptions shall apply in actions brought for violations of this article: 
(1)  Any person who owns, operates, maintains or enters a commercial establishment, which advertises within 100 feet of the premises of the commercial establishment to the general public that said establishment provides, allows or permits the exhibition or display of specified anatomical areas or specified sexual activities, is presumed to be aware that the said exhibition or display is taking place in the establishment. 
(2)  Any establishment which has received a business tax receipt to operate commercially is presumed to be a commercial establishment. 
(Code 1982, § 3.5-56; Ord. No. 17-2120 , § 1, 7-17-2017)  
Sec. 10-182. - Penalties. 
Any person who violates any of the provisions hereof shall be prosecuted and punished in accordance with general law by fine not exceeding $500.00 or by imprisonment not exceeding 90 days, or both. 
(Code 1982, § 3.5-57)  
Sec. 10-183. - Powers of commission. 
The commission may bring suit to restrain, enjoin or otherwise prevent the violation of this article in the circuit court of the county. The commission shall be entitled to apply for and collect its attorneys' fees and costs against violators of this article in bringing such action. 
(Code 1982, § 3.5-58)  
Secs. 10-184—10-210. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - ADULT ARCADES 
 
Sec. 10-211. - Purpose and intent; findings; jurisdiction; statutory authority. 
The purpose of this article is to regulate, within the city, those games, machines or devices which are unlawful under F.S. ch. 849, because the machines are slot machines or devices as defined herein and in F.S. ch. 849. The city commission finds that evidence has been propounded indicating that slot machines or devices can lead to gambling addictions, along with the secondary consequences that such addictions impose upon the community, including increases in crime, debt, suicide and other negative effects on the health, safety, morals and welfare of the residents and visitors of the areas where these devices exist. By law, local governments have all powers of self-government which do not conflict with state laws, including those police powers sufficient to eliminate public nuisances and regulate activities which would otherwise cause harm to the public. 
(Code 1982, § 3.6-1)  
Sec. 10-212. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Casino-type slot machines means a machine, device, game or instrument which is prohibited by F.S. § 849.16, or which, by means of any element of chance, even where the application of skill is involved, has as its object the lining up of two or more colors, lights, or spinning objects, or any combination thereof. 
Slot machine or device means an amusement machine, device, game or instrument operated by means of the insertion of a coin, bill, currency, credit card, debit card, ticket, token or slug, for use as a game, contest of skill or amusement of any description, which device, machine, game or instrument is similar to, or in the nature of a casino-type slot machine. This definition is not intended to and specifically does not include merchandise vending machines, coin-operated mechanical or electrical musical instruments or devices, or coin-operated amusement devices which are not in the nature of, or similar to, casino-type slot machines. 
(Code 1982, § 3.6-2) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 10-213. - Slot machines or devices prohibited; business tax receipts not issued; affect on other regulations. 
(a)  Prohibition. It shall be unlawful to have, own, operate, use, or allow another to have, own operate or use a slot machine or device in the city and slot machines or devices are hereby prohibited in the city. 
(b)  No business tax receipts. No business tax receipts shall be issued by the city for any business or organization which proposes to operate a slot machine or device in the city and no business tax receipts shall be issued by the city for a slot machine or device. 
(c)  Affect on other regulations. This article shall not be construed to amend the Longwood Development Code, or any other land development regulation or ordinance in effect in the city. 
(Code 1982, § 3.6-3; Ord. No. 17-2120 , § 2, 7-17-2017)  
Chapter 14 - ANIMALS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Environment, ch. 38. 
 
Sec. 14-1. - Adoption of county animal control ordinance. 
(a)  The city shall enter into an agreement for implementation and enforcement of the Seminole County Code, Chapter 20, Animal Control Ordinance, within the city, such ordinance to be enforced by the county. 
(b)  The mayor is hereby authorized and directed to execute on behalf of the city, an interlocal agreement by and between the city and the board of county commissioners, for the enforcement and implementation of Seminole County Code, Chapter 20, Animal Control Ordinance within the territorial limits of the city, a copy of such agreement being on file in the city clerk's office and made a part hereof for all purposes by reference and attachment. 
(Code 1982, § 4-1)  
Sec. 14-2. - Intent. 
The regulations and requirements of this chapter are intended to preserve the residential character of the city and to minimize conflicts of noise, odor and health hazards created by the keeping of animals. 
(Code 1982, § 4-2)  
Sec. 14-3. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Animal means every living nonhuman creature. 
Animal control officer means a person employed or appointed by county animal control who is authorized by the city to enforce the county animal control regulations within the city limits. 
Animal quarters means the premises and all buildings, pens, yards and their appurtenances used for the keeping of dogs and cats or other domesticated animals. 
Cats means animals that are members of the feline family that are accustomed to living in or about the habitation of humans and are domesticated. 
Codes enforcement officer means a person employed or appointed by the city authorized to enforce this chapter. 
Commercial kennels. See the Longwood Development Code for regulations. 
Control means the regulation of the possession, ownership, care and custody of cats and dogs or other domesticated animals and having authority over a domesticated animal whether or not under restraint. 
Dogs means animals that are members of the canine family that are accustomed to living in or about the habitation of humans and have been domesticated. 
Domesticated animal means an animal accustomed to living in or about the habitation of humans. 
Fowl means all kinds of birds, whether wild or domesticated. 
Livestock means all animals of the equine, bovine or swine class, including but not limited to goats, sheep, mules, horses, hogs, cattle and other grazing animals. 
Owner means any person owning, keeping, harboring, possessing or having control or custody of a domesticated animal or, if the animal is owned by a person under the age of 18, that person's parent or guardian. 
Poultry means any animal, such as, but not limited to, chickens, roosters, turkeys, peacocks, geese and ducks. 
Public nuisance animal means an animal as described in section 14-4. 
Single family. A single dwelling unit on a single lot of record. 
Stray animal means any unlicensed or unattended animal of the owner. 
Venomous reptiles means all reptiles producing venom. 
Vicious animal means any animal or reptile that has made unprovoked attacks on any person or animal or has, for no apparent reason, caused bodily harm to any person or animal. 
(Code 1982, § 4-2; Ord. No. 18-2140 , § 2, 8-20-2018) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 14-4. - Public nuisance animals. 
(a)  It is unlawful for a person to permit animals to become a public nuisance. An animal shall be declared a public nuisance animal if such animal: 
(1)  Is repeatedly found at large; 
(2)  Repeatedly damages the property of anyone other than its owner; 
(3)  Is vicious; 
(4)  Causes unsanitary conditions of enclosures or surroundings; 
(5)  Is on property in such numbers as exceeds the number limits placed on animals in this chapter; 
(6)  Barks, chirps, howls, meows, or makes other such prolonged and disturbing noises which interfere with the peace and quietude of the neighboring property when such noises continue for periods longer than 15 minutes; 
(7)  Harasses passersby or passing vehicles; 
(8)  Has attacked other domestic animals; 
(9)  Has been designated by the animal control officer or the codes enforcement officer to be a public nuisance by virtue of being a menace to public health, welfare or safety; or 
(10)  Has otherwise been determined to be a stray. 
(Code 1982, § 4-3; Ord. No. 18-2140 , § 2, 8-20-2018)  
Sec. 14-5. - Prohibited animals. 
(a)  Specific animals. It shall be unlawful to keep, maintain or raise in the city the following animals: 
(1)  Cows, all species; sheep, all species; goats, all species; all other hoofed animals and livestock. 
(2)  Animals, such as, but not limited to, chickens, roosters, turkeys, peacocks, geese and ducks, other poultry, excluding chickens that are allowable pursuant to a backyard chicken permit in section 14-6. 
(3)  Any dangerous animal or reptile. 
(4)  Venomous reptiles. 
(5)  Public nuisance animals. 
(b)  Exceptions. Subsection (a) of this section is not intended to apply and it is an exception to those provisions regarding the keeping of prohibited animals if the prohibited animals are trained guard animals or trained law enforcement animals and are maintained by a law enforcement agency and used exclusively by the law enforcement agency in fulfilling its duties. 
(c)  Number of animals. It shall be unlawful to keep, maintain, husband, or raise in the city more than a total of five animals, including dogs, cats, hamsters, gerbils, ferrets, mice, guinea pigs, nonvicious and nonvenomous reptiles, parrots and other birds and rabbits, on one parcel of land of one acre or less. 
(1)  For parcels of land larger than one acre, the number of animals permitted shall increase by one animal for each one-fifth acre over one acre until the parcel reaches two acres in size. Parcels of land two acres or greater shall be permitted to have up to ten animals, but no more than ten such animals shall be permitted in areas with a residential land use. 
(2)  This restriction of the number of animals shall not apply if the number is exceeded due to birth of animals and the violation of this section is temporary in nature and does not extend past 16 weeks after the birth of such animals. 
(3)  This restriction shall not apply to chickens subject to a permit authorized under section 14-6. 
(Code 1982, § 4-4; Ord. No. 11-1972, § 1, 9-19-2011; Ord. No. 18-2140 , § 2, 8-20-2018)  
Sec. 14-6. - Backyard chickens. 
(a)  Applicability. The standards of section 14-6, backyard chickens, applies to all single family properties. Regardless of the underlying future land use district, chickens shall not be kept on properties developed with commercial uses, mobile home/manufactured home parks, duplexes, triplexes, and apartments or other multifamily properties. 
This section does not authorize persons to violate applicable restrictive covenants and homeowners' association rules and regulations. The city does not police or enforce private restrictive covenants and homeowners' association rules and regulations. Persons applying for and receiving permits under this section are solely responsible for compliance with all applicable restrictive covenants and homeowners' association rules and regulations and shall be required to comply with section 18-62, appearance requirements for single-family residential structures in deed restricted subdivisions where applicable. 
(b)  Permit requirements The issuance of a permit for the keeping of chickens is conditioned upon and subject to the terms and conditions of this section. Persons desiring to participate in the backyard chicken program must show that they can meet the requirements of this section and shall apply for and obtain a permit from the community development director or his/her designee prior to keeping chickens. 
(1)  Fee. A fee shall be charged to persons applying for a permit under this section to cover processing costs. 
(2)  No more than 50 permits will be issued. Permits shall be awarded by the city on a first-come, first-served basis.
