Cross reference— Alcoholic beverages, ch. 6; amusements and entertainments, ch. 10; emergency services, ch. 34; obscene behavior in commercial establishments, § 46-6; peddlers and solicitors, ch. 54; secondhand goods, ch. 66; taxation, ch. 82; utilities, ch. 90; franchises, app. A; supplemental standards for home occupations, pt. III, § 5.5.0. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 22-1—22-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - CONVENIENCE BUSINESS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Convenience business security, F.S. §§ 812.1701—812.175. 
 
Sec. 22-31. - Purpose, applicability. 
This article is enacted for the purpose of establishing and requiring certain minimum security measures to be taken at certain businesses, stores or operations of a commercial nature; requiring employee training; requiring that a minimum number of personnel be on duty; providing for exemptions, minimum lighting requirements, and penalties for noncompliance. 
(Code 1982, § 6.5-1)  
Sec. 22-32. - Definition of convenience business. 
(a)  The term "convenience business" means any place of business that is primarily engaged in the retail sale of groceries, or both groceries and gasoline, and that is open for business at any time between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m. The term "convenience business" does not include: 
(1)  A business that is solely or primarily a restaurant. 
(2)  A business that always has at least five employees on the premises after 11:00 p.m. and before 5:00 a.m. 
(3)  A business that has at least 10,000 square feet of retail floor space. 
(b)  The term "convenience business" does not include any business in which the owner or members of his family work between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m. 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, § F.S. § 812.171.  
Sec. 22-33. - Intent. 
The provisions of this article are intended to prevent violent crimes and thereby to protect employees and the consumer public at late-night convenience businesses. It is the further intent that security standards for late-night convenience businesses be uniform throughout the state. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, F.S. § 812.172.  
Sec. 22-34. - Convenience business security. 
(a)  Every convenience business shall be equipped with the following security devices and standards: 
(1)  A security camera system capable of recording and retrieving an image to assist in offender identification and apprehension. 
(2)  A drop safe or cash management device for restricted access to cash receipts. 
(3)  A lighted parking lot illuminated at an intensity of at least two footcandles per square foot at 18 inches above the surface. 
(4)  A conspicuous notice at the entrance which states that the cash register contains $50.00 or less. 
(5)  Window signage that allows a clear and unobstructed view from outside the building and in a normal line of sight of the cash register and sales transaction area. 
(6)  Height markers at the entrance of the convenience business which display height measures. 
(7)  A cash management policy to limit the cash on hand at all times after 11:00 p.m. 
(b)  A convenience business shall not have window tinting that reduces exterior or interior view in a normal line of sight. 
(c)  Every convenience business shall be equipped with a silent alarm to law enforcement or a private security agency, unless application for an exemption is made to and granted by the attorney general. An application for exemption must be in writing and must be accompanied by an administrative fee as set out in Appendix B for each store for which an exemption would apply. 
(d)  If a murder, robbery, sexual battery, aggravated assault, aggravated battery, or kidnapping or false imprisonment, as those crimes are identified and defined by state statutes, occurs or has occurred at a convenience business since July 1, 1989, and arises out of the operation of the convenience business, that convenience business shall implement at least one of the following security measures: 
(1)  Provide at least two employees on the premises at all times after 11:00 p.m. and before 5:00 a.m.; 
(2)  Install for use by employees at all times after 11:00 p.m. and before 5:00 a.m. a secured safety enclosure of transparent polycarbonate or other material that meets at least one of the following minimum standards: 
a.  American Society for Testing and Materials Standard D3935 (classification PC110 B 3 0800700) and that has a thickness of at least 0.375 inches and has an impact strength of at least 200 foot pounds; or 
b.  Underwriters Laboratory Standard UL 752 for medium power small arms (level one), Bullet Resisting Equipment; 
(3)  Provide a security guard on the premises at all times after 11:00 p.m. and before 5:00 a.m.; 
(4)  Lock the business premises throughout the hours of 11:00 p.m. to 5:00 a.m., and only transact business through an indirect pass-through, trapdoor, or window; or 
(5)  Close the business at all times after 11:00 p.m. and before 5:00 a.m. 
(e)  For purposes of this section, any convenience business that by law implemented any of the security measures set forth in subsections (d)(1) through (d)(5) of this section and has maintained said measures as required by the state department of legal affairs without any occurrence or incidence of the crimes identified by subsection (d) of this section for a period of no less than 24 months immediately preceding the filing of a notice of exemption, may file with the department a notice of exemption from these enhanced security measures. In no event shall this exemption be interpreted to preclude full compliance with the security measures set forth in subsection (d) of this section should any occurrence or incidence of the crimes identified by subsection (d) cause subsection (d) to be statutorily applicable. The department of legal affairs will provide notice to any convenience business to which a subsection (d) of this section incident has previously occurred. In no event shall the state or the department of legal affairs incur any liability for the regulation and enforcement of this article.  
Sec. 22-35. - Training of employees. 
The owner or principal operator of a convenience business or convenience businesses shall provide proper robbery deterrence and safety training by an approved curriculum to its retail employees within 60 days of employment. A proposed curriculum shall be submitted in writing to the attorney general with an administrative fee not to exceed the amount set out in Appendix B. The attorney general shall review and approve or disapprove the curriculum in writing within 60 days after receipt. The state shall have no liability for approving or disapproving a training curriculum under this section. Approval shall be given to a curriculum which trains and familiarizes retail employees with the security principles, devices, and measures required by section 22-34. Disapproval of a curriculum shall be subject to the provisions of F.S. ch. 120. No person shall be liable for ordinary negligence due to implementing an approved curriculum if the training was actually provided. A curriculum shall be submitted for reapproval biennially with an administrative fee not to exceed the amount set out in Appendix B. Any curriculum approved by the attorney general since September 1990 shall be subject to reapproval two years from the anniversary of initial approval and biennially thereafter. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, F.S. § 812.174.  
Sec. 22-36. - Penalties. 
Any person violating any provision of this article, shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-13. 
(Code 1982, § 6.5-4)  
Sec. 22-37. - Liberal construction. 
The provisions of this article shall be liberally construed in order to effectively carry out the purposes of this article in the interest of the public health, welfare and safety of the citizens and residents of the county and the state. 
(Code 1982, § 6.5-5)  
Secs. 22-38—22-60. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - MOTION PHOTOGRAPHY PRODUCTIONS 
 
Sec. 22-61. - Title. 
This article may be known and cited as the "Longwood Motion Photography Production Permit Ordinance." 
(Code 1982, § 10.5-1)  
Sec. 22-62. - Purposes. 
The purposes of this article are to establish a standard permitting process for motion photography production endeavors on public property owned or controlled by or under the jurisdiction of the city, to provide a means whereby acts otherwise prohibited by this Code may be allowed during such productions, and to provide for an exemption from other city Code permit requirements in recognition of the economic impact of the motion picture and television industry. 
(Code 1982, § 10.5-2)  
Sec. 22-63. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly requires otherwise: 
City equipment means any tangible property, other than real property, purchased by public funds and utilized in the normal course and scope of providing governmental service by the city. 
City facility means any public street, sidewalk, place or building owned or controlled by or under the jurisdiction of the city to include, but not be limited to, city parks, cemeteries and recreation facilities. 
Film commissioner means the Director of the Motion Picture and Television Division of the Industrial Development Commission of Mid-Florida, Inc. 
Motion photography means the commercial taking or making of a motion picture, television, videotape or film production utilizing city equipment or utilizing city facilities. This term shall include, and a production permit shall be required for, such productions on private property not at a studio involving the erection of tents or other temporary structures or involving the use of pyrotechnics, explosives or other incendiary devices. This term shall not include the shooting of such film at studios constructed for such purpose where no city equipment or city facilities are involved and shall not include any news, news feature or documentary production. 
Production permit (also referred to herein as "permit") means the permit required by this article. 
(Code 1982, § 10.5-3) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 22-64. - Film commissioner. 
The film commissioner is hereby authorized to act as the agent for the city in the receipt and processing of applications for production permits. After review and written approval by the city manager or his designee, the film commissioner shall issue the permit. With regard to motion photography production, no other city permits shall be required. 
(Code 1982, § 10.5-4)  
Sec. 22-65. - Permit required; suspension and/or revocation; violation. 
(a)  No person shall advertise, engage in, participate in and/or start any motion photography production unless a production permit shall first have been obtained from the film commissioner. Violation of this section shall be punishable pursuant to general law. 
(b)  Failure to comply with the terms and conditions of the production permit once issued shall be grounds for immediate suspension. The suspension shall be initially communicated orally, followed by a written suspension order. Continued failure to comply with the terms and conditions of the production permit may result in revocation of the permit. Revocation or suspension procedure may be carried out by either the film commissioner or the city manager. Continuation of the production in violation of the suspension and/or revocation shall be punishable by general law. 
(Code 1982, § 10.5-5)  
Sec. 22-66. - Application for permits. 
(a)  Any person seeking the issuance of a production permit shall file an application with and on forms provided by the film commissioner. Said application shall be filed not less than 180 days before and not less than five working days before the commencement of production. The application shall be signed, under oath, by an authorized representative of the applicant. 
(b)  The application shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Location(s) of the production. 
(2)  Duration and type of production. 
(3)  Proof of general liability insurance coverage in the amount of at least $1,000,000.00 with the city named as an additional insured. 
(4)  Special effects to be utilized, especially incendiary or explosive devices, with proof of $5,000,000.00 liability insurance therefor. In addition, the application shall list the person in charge (pyrotechnician) of such special effects, together with his qualifications and licensure by the applicable federal and/or state agencies. 
(5)  Proposed utilization of city equipment. 
(6)  Necessity for closures of public streets or sidewalks and for what duration, approval of which is subject to the public safety and welfare needs of the city. 
(7)  A written summary or explanation of the portion of the production to be shot within the city. 
(8)  Number and type of vehicles and/or equipment and number of personnel to be on location with the production. 
(9)  An agreement to pay for extraordinary services provided by the city. 
(10)  Certificate signed under oath that all private property owners and tenants have been notified of the filing and arrangements made to cause the least disruption for them as possible. 
(Code 1982, § 10.5-6)  
Sec. 22-67. - Exemption from other Code requirements. 
(a)  Once a production permit has been issued, and notwithstanding any other provisions of this Code to the contrary, no other city permits shall be required for any of the activities forming a part of the production. 
(b)  The provisions of this Code and the Longwood Development Code, insofar as certain acts are required or prohibited, may be suspended by the city manager in connection with the conduct of a production pursuant to this article. The city manager shall not compromise the public safety by a suspension of requirements. 
(c)  If some or all of a motion photography production is to take place on public or private property not at a studio and the production involves the erection of temporary structures or temporary modification of an existing structure or the introduction of an object or substance onto the property, the applicant for the production permit shall be required to restore the property to the condition existing prior to the production. In addition, the city may require that the applicant provide a performance bond in any amount to be determined by the city to insure such restoration. 
(Code 1982, § 10.5-7)  
Sec. 22-68. - Costs for extraordinary services. 
The city shall recover direct costs for extraordinary services rendered in connection with a production. Such costs shall include, but not be limited to, charges for personnel and/or equipment committed in support of the production which are outside the normal scope of governmental services. Based upon the information contained in the permit application, an estimate of these costs will be provided to the applicant prior to issuance of the permit. The city may require prepayment of all or a portion of these estimated costs prior to the issuance of the permit. At the conclusion of the production, actual costs below or in excess of the estimates will be refunded by the city or paid by the applicant, respectively. The city is under no obligation to provide city personnel or equipment, and the same shall be provided only if the city manager approves. 
(Code 1982, § 10.5-8)  
Sec. 22-69. - Acts prohibited; penalty. 
It shall be a violation of this article to film, tape or act out on or upon any city facility any act that would portray the acts of rape, sodomy, bestiality, sexual intercourse, or acts of violence that portray exploding body parts or the dismemberment of bodies or body parts of humans or animals. Violation of this section shall be punishable according to general law. 
(Code 1982, § 10.5-9)  
Sec. 22-70. - Using the word "Longwood." 
Usage of the word "Longwood" either visually or verbally in the film, including in the credit line, shall be prohibited without the express written consent of the city manager. 
(Code 1982, § 10.5-10)  
Chapter 26 - CEMETERY[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 78. 
State Law reference— Florida cemetery act, F.S. § 559.30 et seq. 
 
Sec. 26-1. - Definition. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Municipal cemetery or cemetery, when used in this chapter, means the municipal cemetery of the city, commonly referred to as "Longwood Memorial Gardens." 
(Code 1982, § 6-1) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 26-2. - Authority in city commission. 
The city commission shall manage, operate and maintain the municipal cemetery subject to any limitations and restrictions set forth in this chapter contained in any applicable law. 
(Code 1982, § 6-2)  
Sec. 26-3. - Rules and regulations. 
The city commission shall from time to time establish rules and regulations for the use of the cemetery relating to: 
(1)  Subdividing the cemetery into lots; 
(2)  Capacity of each lot; 
(3)  Location of graves; 
(4)  Type of plantings, monuments and markers that will be permitted for the proper and most attractive development of the cemetery. 
(Code 1982, § 6-3)  
Sec. 26-4. - Duties of director of public works. 
The director of public works shall have the following duties with regard to the cemetery: 
(1)  Direct cemetery. The director of public works shall look after and take proper care of the cemetery and see that no lot therein is used or occupied in violation of this chapter or of any rule or regulation promulgated by the city commission. 
(2)  Collect and turn over fees. All fees and charges collected by the director of public works for duties and services performed in connection with the cemetery shall immediately be turned over by him to the city clerk. 
(3)  Supervise interment. The director of public works shall supervise interment. 
(Code 1982, § 6-4)  
Sec. 26-5. - Lot valuation; method of purchase. 
(a)  The city commission shall at the beginning of each fiscal year place a value upon all unsold lots in the cemetery, and shall record such valuations on an official map or plan of such cemetery that shall be kept on file, open to public inspection, in the office of the clerk. Such valuations shall be fixed and the valuation as established shall be the price at which such lots shall be sold. 
(b)  Any person desiring to purchase available lot or lots in the cemetery, for the purpose of which it is intended, shall be permitted to do so upon payment of the full price fixed for such lot in accordance with the payment fee schedule and the rules and regulations. 
(Code 1982, § 6-5)  
Sec. 26-6. - Records of ownership. 
The city clerk shall keep full and complete records of the ownership of all lots in the cemetery, of the burial capacity of each lot, sold and unsold, of the location of each grave, of the names of the persons buried in each grave that has been or shall hereafter be used, and of the date of burial of each. 
(Code 1982, § 6-6)  
Sec. 26-7. - Rules for interment. 
No deceased person shall be interred in the cemetery until the director of public works has found: 
(1)  That a burial permit has been obtained from the public health officer as required by law; 
(2)  That the lot in which burial is to be made has been fully paid for; 
(3)  That the person arranging for such burial has the right to the use of such lot; 
(4)  That such lot is not used beyond its capacity; 
(5)  That proper record is made of the name and age of the deceased person and of the exact location of the grave. 
(Code 1982, § 6-8)  
Sec. 26-8. - Reports. 
The city clerk shall make a monthly report on the condition of the cemetery to the city commission. The city clerk shall make an annual report on the condition of the cemetery providing the city commission with all information necessary to recommending the amount that should be appropriated for the cemetery in the budget. 
(Code 1982, § 6-9)  
Sec. 26-9. - Cemetery fee schedule. 
The cemetery fee schedule shall be as set out in Appendix B. 
(Code 1982, § 6-10)  
Chapter 30 - ELECTIONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Nominations and elections, art. VIII. 
Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2. 
State Law reference— Electors and elections, F.S. chs. 97—106. 
 
Sec. 30-1. - When election held. 
(a)  Pursuant to Charter section 8.01, regular city elections shall be held on the first Tuesday after the first Monday in November and shall be in the manner provided for in section 30-8. 
(b)  When any regular, special, or run-off city election is held on the same day an election is being conducted by the Seminole County Supervisor of Elections, the term "city clerk," as stated in section 30-5 shall denote the "Seminole County Supervisor of Elections." For all other elections the term "city clerk" shall stand as written. 
(c)  When any regular, special, or run-off city election is held on the same day an election is being conducted by the Seminole County Supervisor of Elections, the term "canvassing board" shall mean the Seminole County canvassing board and the canvassing shall be conducted in accordance with the Florida Election Code. For all other city elections, the term "canvassing board" shall mean the Seminole County canvassing board and the canvassing shall be conducted in accordance with the Florida Election Code. 
(Code 1982, § 7-1; Ord. No. 09-1896, § 1, 6-15-2009) 
Charter reference— Date of election, § 8.01(a).  
Sec. 30-2. - Qualification of candidates. 
Any qualified elector of the city who has been a resident of the city for a period of one year next preceding the date of qualification, qualified to vote in city elections at the time of qualification for office, and has resided at the time of such qualification in the commission district for which he qualifies for six months prior to qualification, and who is otherwise qualified to be a member of the city commission may be a candidate for election to the city commission. 
(Code 1982, § 7-3) 
Charter reference— Candidates, §§ 3.01, 8.02.  
Sec. 30-3. - Mayor to issue election proclamations. 
The mayor shall issue an election proclamation ordering all regular or special elections to be held, stating therein the time and polling place or places of such regular or special elections and stating therein the different offices to be filled or questions to be voted upon, giving at least 15 days' notice of the qualification period prior to the election. Said election proclamations shall be posted at the front door of city hall and at the post office of the city or be published once each week for two weeks in a newspaper of general circulation within the city. 
(Code 1982, § 7-4)  
Sec. 30-4. - Candidate qualifying procedures. 
(a)  Generally. Any elector, otherwise duly qualified pursuant to state law and the City Charter, may become a candidate for the office of city commissioner by filing an application with the city clerk during the city's regular business days and hours within the qualifying period. The qualifying period shall commence at 12:00 noon on the 78th day prior to the municipal election and shall end at 12:00 noon on the 74th day prior to the municipal election. 
(b)  Qualifying fee. A nonrefundable qualifying fee equal to five percent of the annual compensation shall be required of each candidate, or if such candidate is unable to pay the qualifying fee, then the candidate shall be required to qualify in accordance with F.S. § 99.095. 
(Code 1982, § 7-5; Ord. No. 12-1984, § I, 3-5-2012)  
Sec. 30-5. - Inspectors and clerk; appointment. 
The city clerk is hereby assigned responsibilities for the proper conduct of municipal elections within the city and for ensuring compliance with state and city election laws. The Seminole County Supervisor of Elections shall appoint qualified individuals to serve as precinct clerk, inspectors and poll marshal for municipal elections. 
(Code 1982, § 7-6; Ord. No. 09-1896, § 2, 6-15-2009)  
Sec. 30-6. - Election returns—Certification. 
Immediately following the close of elections, all ballots, including absentee ballots, shall be delivered to the supervisor of elections office for the county for automatic tabulation. Immediately following the tabulations and certification of returns, the canvassing board will sign the certificates indicating the number of votes cast for each candidate and for each question. 
(Code 1982, § 7-9)  
Sec. 30-7. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 09-1896, § 3, adopted June 15, 2009, repealed § 30-7 which pertained to canvass of election returns and derived from § 7-10 of the 1982 Code.  
Sec. 30-8. - Swearing in ceremony; special meeting following election. 
In accordance with the city Charter, newly elected and reelected members of the city commission shall be sworn in within 15 days following the date of the election. If the swearing in of the newly elected or reelected members results in a situation where there is no member on the commission who has signature authority, then a special meeting shall be scheduled and held immediately upon the conclusion of the swearing in ceremony. The matters to be considered at this special meeting shall be limited to the election of the mayor, seating of deputy mayor, and the adoption of the required resolutions in order to designate bank signature authority and facsimile signature authorization. 
(Code 1982, § 7-11)  
Sec. 30-9. - Forfeiture. 
Any candidate for election to the city commission or any commissioner-elect who ceases to possess the necessary qualifications of section 3.01 of the city Charter will have his/her name struck from the ballot or forfeit his office-elect. 
(Code 1982, § 7-12) 
Charter reference— Forfeiture of office, § 3.06(b).  
Sec. 30-10. - Geographical commission districts. 
(a)  The city shall be divided into five commission districts described as follows: 
(1)  District 1: That area of Longwood lying east of Rangeline Road extended from State Road 434 north to the intersection of E.E. Williamson Road / Longwood Hills Road; thence north to the northwest corner of the Danbury Mill subdivision; thence east to the northeast corner of the Danbury Mill subdivision, thence south to Longwood Hills Road; thence east on Longwood Hills Road to the northeast corner of CorJesu Subdivision; thence south to the northern boundary of the Tiberon Cove subdivision; thence east to the northeast boundary of the Tiberon Cove subdivision; thence south to the intersection of South Milwee Street and State Road 434; thence west on State Road 434 extended to the intersection of Rangeline Road and State Road 434. 
(2)  District 2: That area of Longwood lying south of State Road 434 at the westerly city limits to the intersection of State Road 434 and South Milwee Street; thence north to the intersection of West Church Avenue; thence east to the intersection of East Church Avenue and Credo Street; thence south to State Road 434; thence east to the easterly city limits; thence south to the southern city limits. 
(3)  District 3: That area of Longwood east of the northeast corner of CorJesu Subdivision; thence east on Longwood Hills Road to the intersection of Longwood Hills Road and Citrus Tree Lane; thence south to West 14th Avenue; thence east to the Seaboard Coastline Railroad; thence south to the southwest corner of the Oak Villa Subdivision; thence east along the south boundary line of the Oak Villa Subdivision to the intersection of North Grant Street; thence south to the intersection of North Grant Street and Seminole Avenue; thence east to the intersection of Seminole Avenue and Highland Street; thence north to the intersection of Highland Street and Florida Avenue; thence east to the intersection of Florida Avenue and Highway 17-92; thence south to the midpoint on Highway 17-92 between the intersection of Highway 17-92 and Nursery Road and the intersection of Highway 17-92 and Oak Lane; thence east to Ridge Street; thence south on Ridge Street to the intersection of Ridge Street and Oak Lane; thence east to the intersection of Oak Lane and Talmo Street; thence south to the intersection of Talmo Street and State Road 434; thence west to a point on State Road 434 directly south of the intersection of Credo Street and Bay Avenue; thence north to the intersection of Credo Street and East Church Avenue; thence west to the intersection of West Church Avenue and South Milwee Street; thence north to the northeast corner of the Tiberon Cove subdivision; thence west along the northern boundary of the Tiberon Cove subdivision to a point directly south of the intersection of Longwood Hills Road and the northeast corner of the CorJesu Subdivision; thence north to the intersection of Longwood Hills Road and the northeast corner of the of CorJesu Subdivision. 
(4)  District 4: That area of Longwood from the northern most point of Lake Emma Road; thence south to the intersection of Lake Emma Road and Longwood Hills Road; thence east to the intersection of Longwood Hills Road and Citrus Tree Lane; thence south to West 14th Avenue; thence east to the Seaboard Coastline Railroad; thence run south to the southwest corner of the Oak Villa Subdivision; thence east along the south boundary of the Oak Villa Subdivision to the intersection North Grant Street; thence south to the intersection of North Grant Street and Seminole Avenue; thence east to the intersection of Seminole Avenue and Highland Street, thence north to the intersection of Highland Street and Florida Avenue; thence east to the intersection of Florida Avenue and Highway 17-92; thence north to the northern city limits. 
(5)  District 5: That area of Longwood lying west of Rangeline Road extended from the northern city limits to State Road 434 to the western city limits and including the Coventry and the Shadow Hill Subdivisions. 
(b)  For the year 1981 and all years subsequent thereto, no amendment to district boundaries shall be commenced later than March 31 of any given year. 
(Code 1982, § 7-14; Ord. No. 12-1987, § 1, 3-19-2012) 
Charter reference— Geographical commission districts to be created, § 3.01(c).  
Sec. 30-11. - Vacancy in candidacy. 
(a)  Time remaining before election: 
(1)  If the death, withdrawal, or removal from the ballot of a qualified candidate following the end of the qualifying period results in fewer than two candidates for an office, and more than 28 days remain prior to the date of the election, qualifying shall be reopened to allow candidates to qualify for the election to that office in accordance with the City Charter and Code. Any candidate wishing to qualify shall comply with candidate qualifying procedures as required by the City Charter no later than noon on the 21st day prior to the date of the election. 
(2)  If less than 28 days remain to the election date after the death, withdrawal, or removal from the ballot of the lone qualified candidate for an office, and if a vacancy shall result on the city commission, such vacancy shall be filled in accordance with law. 
(3)  If the qualifying period is reopened pursuant to subsection (b)(1) of this section, supplemental absentee ballots reflecting the new candidates who have qualified for that office only shall be mailed by the city clerk as soon as possible to any absentee voter who was mailed an absentee ballot and to any voter requesting an absentee ballot for the special election. If an absentee voter returns the initial ballot he was mailed, his vote for the office for which qualification was reopened will be null and void, but his votes on all other offices and issues shall be counted. 
(b)  Removal of name from ballot. The name of any qualified candidate who has withdrawn, died, or been removed from the ballot shall not be printed on the ballot. If the ballot cannot be changed, the city shall use the appropriate state guidelines. 
(c)  Refund of qualification fee. A candidate withdrawing or being removed from the ballot after having qualified and paid the qualification fee shall not receive a refund of the qualifying fee. 
(Code 1982, § 7-15; Ord. No. 05-1756, §§ 1, 2, 5-2-2005; Ord. No. 09-1896, § 4, 6-15-2009) 
State Law reference— Procedure for filling of vacancy in candidacy, F.S. § 166.031(6).  
Sec. 30-12. - Early voting. 
The city hereby exercises its right pursuant to F.S. § 101.657(1)(e), to exempt itself from the statutory early voting provisions of F.S. § 101.657, and shall specially contract with the Seminole County Supervisor of Elections to conduct early voting for the city at the Office of the Supervisor of Elections. In addition to the regular voting date, the following are early voting days: 
Friday, November 4 th from 10:00 a.m. until 6:00 p.m. 
Saturday, November 5 th from 12:00 p.m. until 4:00 p.m. 
Sunday, November 6 th from 12:00 p.m. until 4:00 p.m. 
This provision shall only apply to the election of November 2011 unless readopted by the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 04-1723, § 1, 10-18-2004; Ord. No. 09-1896, § 5, 6-15-2009; Ord. No. 11-1960, § 2, 4-4-2011)  
Sec. 30-13. - Campaign treasurer's reports. 
All candidates for elected office in the city shall electronically file their campaign treasurer's reports required by state law utilizing the Seminole County Supervisor of Elections Office's electronic filing system. Campaign treasurer's reports electronically filed as required by this section shall be deemed filed with the city clerk simultaneously upon the Seminole County Supervisor of Elections Office's receipt of the electronic filing. 
(Ord. No. 13-2022, § I, 1-6-2014)  
Chapter 34 - EMERGENCY SERVICES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 22; fire prevention and protection, ch. 42. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 34-1—34-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - ALARM SYSTEMS 
 
Sec. 34-31. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Alarm means a signal (audible, or visual, recorded or live) transmitted to the Longwood police or fire departments, or 911 dispatcher indicating a predetermined condition. Said alarm is received either: 
(1)  Via telephone line to a designated position on an alarm panel; 
(2)  Via a private alarm contracting company relayed to the Longwood police or fire department. 
(3)  Via an audible/visual signal relayed to the city police or fire department by a third party. 
Burglary alarm means an alarm system designed to indicate a condition of forced entry, or attempted forced entry. 
False alarm means the activation of an alarm, by any means, which does not represent the designated condition. 
Fire alarm means an alarm system designed to indicate the presence of fire and/or smoke. 
Robbery alarm means an alarm system designed to indicate a robbery (hold-up) is in progress or has occurred. 
Telephone alarm system means any alarm system which automatically transmits by telephone line a recorded electronic or mechanical signal, or from a private alarm contracting company, to a telephone instrument at the Longwood police or fire department, or 911 dispatcher. Such system to be totally automated and require no relaying or action by a human being. 
(Code 1982, § 2.5-1) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 34-32. - Duty of owner or lessee of premises, response to alarms, corrective action, reports required and fees charged. 
(a)  Newly installed or substantially modified systems shall be allowed to operate for a period of 30 days from the date of installation or modification without penalty for false alarms, provided the police and fire departments are notified of the installation or modification in advance of same. 
(b)  Owners and/or lessees of any alarm system shall provide response to the alarm location, when requested, by the police or fire department, in order to reset or disable the alarm within one hour of activation. Failure to provide such response will, after notification, result in a charge as set out in appendix B for each such occurrence. 
(c)  All alarm systems having an audible or visual signal at the premises shall be so equipped so as to automatically shut off the audible or visual signal after 15 minutes, except those systems required by law to have a longer operating period in which case said system shall be so equipped, so as to automatically shut off the audible or visual signal at the conclusion of said longer required operating time. 
(d)  All alarm systems shall be properly maintained, system malfunctions due to faulty maintenance shall not be grounds for an excused false alarm under subsection (g) of this section. Excusable false alarms are defined as: 
(1)  Alarms occurring during electrical storms, hurricanes, tornados, blizzards and acts of God; where there is clear evidence of physical damage to the system; 
(2)  The intermittent disruption or disruption of the telephone circuits beyond the control of the alarm company and/or alarm user; 
(3)  Electrical power disruption or failure in excess of two hours; or 
(4)  Alarms caused by a failure of the equipment at the monitoring company with written verification. 
(e)  For each response by the police department or fire department to an alarm, the department will cause a report to be filed, classifying the alarm as one of the following: 
(1)  False alarm or system test with no notification; 
(2)  Valid alarm for cause designated. 
(f)  Upon the reception of a false alarm or system test with no notification, the police department/fire department shall issue a warning notice to the owner or lessee or manager of the premises involved. The owner or lessee or manager shall file a written report with the police department/fire department within five working days, indicating that the alarm system in question has actually been examined by a repair service authorized by the system manufacturer and either repaired, if said repaired malfunction was the cause of the false alarm, or owner certifies that the system is in good working order. 
(g)  There shall be a service fee charged for the following false alarms categories according to the schedule as set out in Appendix B. 
First and second response (within six months). 
Third and fourth response (within six months). 
Fifth and subsequent response (within six months). 
In a given 24-hour period, only one response to a specific location will count for purposes of the above warning/fee determination. If the day following the alarm incident is a Sunday or a legal holiday, consideration will be given to the real ability of the owner to actually have his system serviced by an alarm system technician, and if the police/fire chief or designee determines that it was not reasonably possible for the owner/lessee to have the system serviced to correct the malfunction causing the false alarm, a fee waiver will be granted for that day. 
(h)  If an excessive problem exists, defined as seven or more false alarms within a six-month period, the problem will be referred to the codes enforcement board. It shall be a violation of this Code if an owner or lessee of a premises fails to pay the fee specified in subsection (g) of this section within 30 days of a notice of fee due to false alarm. Such violation shall be referred to the code enforcement officer and handled in the same manner as other code violations pursuant to this Code. 
(Code 1982, § 2.5-2)  
Sec. 34-33. - Telephone alarm devices. 
Telephone alarm devices will be so constructed or installed such as to not seize or otherwise hold or preempt the telephone lines of the city police or fire departments. 
(Code 1982, § 2.5-3)  
Sec. 34-34. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - COST RECOVERY 
 
Sec. 34-35. - User fees for deployment of emergency services. 
(a)  The fire and police departments shall initiate user fees for the delivery of fire and police department services, personnel, supplies, and equipment to the scene of motor vehicle accidents which occur within the corporate limits of the City of Longwood or to which the fire and/or police department respond in the unincorporated areas of Seminole County pursuant to mutual aid agreements. The rate of the user fees shall be the usual, customary and reasonable costs, which includes any services, personnel, supplies, and equipment and which may vary based on the needs of the accident. 
(b)  The user fees shall be initially filed to the responsible motor vehicle insurance carrier, representing an add-on-cost of the claim for damages of the vehicles, property, and/or injuries. The claim costs shall also be filed to the owner of the vehicle, the owner of responsible property, or other responsible parties. 
(c)  Any vehicle(s) that is registered to any person, business, corporation or entity whose address is within the incorporated limits of the City of Longwood is exempt from user fee assessment. Also exempt are registered government vehicles of political subdivisions that have provided reciprocity to the City of Longwood. 
(d)  The city manager may make rules or regulations, and periodically may amend, revoke, or add rules and regulations, not inconsistent with this article as may deem necessary or expedient with respect to billing for these fees or the collection thereof. 
(e)  All amounts collected as a result of this article shall be placed into the general fund budget. 
(f)  The rate schedule for the calculation of user fees for the delivery of fire and police department service, personnel, supplies and equipment to the scene of motor vehicle accidents are listed in exhibits A and B. 
(g)  The rate schedule attached to this article is made a part of this Code [set out in appendix B]. 
(Ord. No. 07-1852, § 2, 11-5-2007)  
Chapter 38 - ENVIRONMENT[1] 
Footnotes:
