(a)  Any actual or prospective bidder, proposer, offeror or contractor, who is aggrieved in connection with a solicitation or award of a bid or contract, may protest to the purchasing manager within seven calendar days after such aggrieved person knows or should have known of facts giving rise thereto. Said protest shall be in writing and shall state with specificity the grounds therefor and also the action requested of the purchasing manager. 
(b)  The purchasing manager shall attempt to settle or resolve protests. Protests not so settled or resolved shall be submitted to the city manager by the purchasing manager. 
(c)  Decisions of the city manager may be appealed to the city commission by submission to the city clerk of a written request for hearing within seven calendar days following such decision. The written request shall state with specificity the grounds for the appeal and also the action requested of the city commission. 
(d)  A decision under this section shall be final and conclusive upon the protestant and shall represent the position of the city. 
(e)  Timely filing of the protest and/or appeal to the city commission is jurisdictional. 
(f)  In the event of a timely protest and/or appeal, the city shall not proceed further with the solicitation or with the award of the bid/contract, unless the purchasing manager, after consultation with the head of the using agency, forwards to the city manager a written request to award the bid/contract without delay in order to protect the interests of the city. 
(Code 1982, § 16.5-13)  
Secs. 62-38—62-60. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - SOURCE, SELECTION AND CONTRACT FORMATION 
 
Sec. 62-61. - Methods of source selection. 
(a)  Unless otherwise authorized by law or ordinance, all purchases shall be made by competitive procedures except as specifically provided in sections 62-64 and 62-67. 
(b)  The preferred method of procurement shall be competitive sealed bidding. 
(c)  Where only one bid or proposal is received, an award may be made to such bidder or proposer if the purchasing manager determines (i) that the price submitted is fair and reasonable; (ii) that other prospective bidders or proposers had a reasonable opportunity to respond; and (iii) that there is not adequate time for a resolicitation. Otherwise, the bid or proposal may be rejected pursuant to section 62-68, and the purchasing manager may (i) cancel the proposed procurement; (ii) solicit new bids or proposals; or (iii) proceed with procurement pursuant to section 62-66 or section 62-67 as appropriate. 
(Code 1982, § 16.5-14)  
Sec. 62-62. - Competitive sealed bidding. 
(a)  Invitation for bids. Where competitive sealed bidding is utilized, an invitation for bids shall be issued which shall include a purchase description and all contractual terms and conditions applicable to the procurement. 
(b)  Public notice: 
(1)  Adequate public notice of the invitation for bids shall be given a minimum of 21 days for projects funded partially or in full with state or federal funds, otherwise 15 days prior to the date set forth therein for the opening of bids. Such notice may include publication in a newspaper of general circulation a minimum 21 or 15 calendar days prior to bid opening based on funding sources. The public notice shall state the date and time of bid opening. 
(2)  Where it can be demonstrated that an emergency requirement for supplies or services exists, the requirement for public notice may be waived by the appropriate procurement officer. See section 62-67, emergency procurement. 
(c)  Bid opening. Bids shall be opened publicly in the presence of one or more witnesses at the time and place designated in the invitation for bid. The amount of each bid, and such other relevant information as may be specified in the invitation for bid, together with the name of each bidder, shall be recorded. Bids and bid files shall be available for public inspection after opening. 
(d)  Bid acceptance. Bids shall be unconditionally accepted, except as authorized in this chapter. 
(e)  Correction or withdrawal of bids. Correction or withdrawal of inadvertently erroneous bids shall be permitted up to the time of bid opening. After bid opening, no changes in bid prices or other provisions shall be permitted; provided, however, the purchasing manager shall have the authority to waive minor irregularities. 
(f)  Bid evaluation and award. Bids shall be evaluated based on the requirements set forth in the invitation for bids, which may include criteria to determine acceptability, such as inspection, testing, quality, workmanship, delivery and suitability for a particular purpose. Those criteria that will affect the bid price and be considered in evaluation for award shall be objectively measurable, such as discounts, transportation costs and total or life cycle costs, etc. The invitation for bids shall set forth the evaluation criteria to be used. No criteria may be used in bid evaluation that are not set forth in the invitation for bids. 
(1)  The contract shall be awarded to the responsible and responsive bidder whose bid meets the requirements and criteria set forth in the invitation for bids. In determining "lowest responsible bidder," in addition to the bid evaluation criteria above, the following may be considered: 
a.  The ability and skill of the bidder to perform the contract; 
b.  Whether the bidder can perform the contract or provide the supplies/services promptly, without delay or within the time specified; 
c.  The quality of performance of previous contracts or services. 
(g)  Multistep sealed bidding. When it is considered impractical (due to insufficient data, uncertain requirements, etc.) to initially prepare a purchase description to support an award based on price, an invitation for proposals may be issued requesting the submission of unpriced offers to be followed by an invitation for bids limited to those bidders whose proposals have been qualified under the criteria set forth in the invitation for proposals. 
(Code 1982, § 16.5-15; Ord. No. 11-1963, § 1 (Exh. A), 5-2-2011)  
Sec. 62-63. - Competitive sealed proposals. 
(a)  Determination of use. When the purchasing manager determines that the use of competitive sealed bidding is either not practical or not advantageous to the city, due to existing market conditions or the type of service/supply required, a contract may be entered into through receipt of competitive sealed proposals. Competitive sealed proposals may also be used for the procurement of professional services. 
(b)  Request for proposals. Competitive sealed proposals shall be solicited through a request for proposals. 
(c)  Public notice. Public notice of the request for proposals shall be given in the same manner as provided for competitive sealed bidding. 
(d)  Receipt of proposals. Proposals shall be opened as provided in section 62-62(c). 
(e)  Evaluation factors. The request for proposals shall state relative importance of price and other evaluation factors. 
(f)  Discussion with responsible offerors and revisions to proposals. As provided in the request for proposals, discussions may be conducted with responsible offerors who submit proposals determined to be reasonably acceptable of being selected for award for the purpose of clarification and to assure full understanding of, and responsiveness to, the solicitation requirements. Offerors shall be accorded fair and equal treatment with respect to any opportunity for discussion and revision of proposals, and such revisions may be permitted after submission prior award for the purpose of obtaining best and final offers. In conducting discussions, there shall be no disclosure of any information derived from proposals submitted by competing offerors, except as may be required by the Florida Public Records Law, F.S. ch. 119. 
(g)  Award. Award shall be made to the responsible offeror whose proposal is determined to be the most advantageous to the city, taking into consideration the evaluation factors set forth in the request for proposals. No other factors or criteria shall be used in the evaluation. The contract file shall contain the basis on which the award was made. 
(Code 1982, § 16.5-16)  
Sec. 62-64. - Small purchases. 
Where it is determined, by policy promulgated by the purchasing manager, that it is either not practical or not advantageous to the city to conduct competitive sealed bidding or competitive sealed proposal procedures, purchases may be made in the open market in accordance with small purchase procedures; provided, however, that contract requirements shall not be artificially divided so as to constitute a small purchase under this section. 
(1)  Minimum number of quotations. All open market purchases shall, whenever feasible, be based on at least three competitive quotations and shall be made to the business offering the lowest acceptable quotation. The name of the business submitting a quotation and the date and amount of each quotation shall be recorded and maintained as a public record. 
(2)  Notice inviting quotations. Quotations shall be solicited by: 
a.  Direct mail request to prospective vendors; 
b.  Telephone; or 
c.  Publication in a newspaper of general circulation in the city. 
(3)  Recording. The purchasing manager shall keep a record of all open market orders and the quotations submitted in competition thereon, and such records shall be available for public inspection. Said records may be disposed of as indicated in state records retention requirements. 
(4)  Purchase from federal, state, county and other city contracts. The purchasing manager shall have authority to purchase directly from federal, state or county contracts or from other city contracts for cooperative purchasing in accordance with procedures promulgated by the purchasing manager. 
(Code 1982, § 16.5-17)  
Sec. 62-65. - Field purchase order (FPO) or procurement card. 
(a)  Any procurement not exceeding the amount of $500.00 may be made in accordance with field purchase order procedures or procurement card procedures by the purchasing manager; provided, however, that the total amount procured shall not be artificially divided so as to constitute a greater amount than authorized under this section. 
(b)  Any purchase exceeding the maximum amount must be made in accordance with procedures outlined in sections 62-62 through 62-67. 
(Code 1982, § 16.5-18)  
Sec. 62-66. - Sole source or negotiated procurement. 
A contract may be awarded for a supply, service or construction without competition when the purchasing manager determines that there is only one source for the required service, supply or construction item or by negotiation where the procurement by competitive procedures is not feasible or practicable. 
(Code 1982, § 16.5-19)  
Sec. 62-67. - Emergency procurement. 
Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, the purchasing manager or his designee may make or authorize others to make emergency procurement when there exists a threat to public health, welfare, or safety as determined under emergency purchase procedures promulgated by the purchasing manager, provided that such emergency procurements shall be made with such competition as is practicable under the circumstances. A full written determination of the basis of the emergency and for the selection of the particular contractor shall be included on the emergency purchase form and shall be filed as a permanent and public record of the purchase. 
(Code 1982, § 16.5-20)  
Sec. 62-68. - Cancellation or rejection of invitation for bids or request for proposals. 
An invitation for bids, a request for proposal or other solicitation may be delayed or cancelled or all bids or proposals may be rejected in whole or in part as may be specified in the solicitation, if it is determined by the purchasing manager that such action is in the best interest of the city. 
(Code 1982, § 16.5-21)  
Sec. 62-69. - Prequalification of suppliers. 
(a)  Prospective suppliers may be required to be prequalified for particular types of supplies or services. 
(b)  Solicitation mailing lists of potential contractors shall include, but not be limited to, such prequalified suppliers. 
(Code 1982, § 16.5-22)  
Sec. 62-70. - Approval of contracts, bonds and certificates of insurance. 
All contracts under this chapter shall be subject to approval as to form and legality by the city attorney. All bonds and certificates of insurance required by this chapter shall be subject to the approval of the purchasing manager and the director of the department of financial services. 
(Code 1982, § 16.5-23)  
Sec. 62-71. - Types of contracts. 
Firm fixed price contracting is the preferred method; however, any type of contract which will promote the best interest of the city may be used. A cost reimbursement contract may be used only when a determination has been made that such contract is likely to be less costly to the city than any other type or that it is impractical to obtain the supplies, services or construction required except under such a contract. 
(Code 1982, § 16.5-24)  
Sec. 62-72. - Multiterm contracts. 
(a)  Specified period. Unless otherwise provided by law, a contract for supplies or services may be entered into for any period of time deemed to be in the best interest of the city, provided the term of the contract and conditions of renewal or extension, if any, are included in the solicitation and funds are available for the first fiscal period at the time of contract. Payment and performance obligations for succeeding fiscal periods shall be subject to appropriation by the city commission of funds thereof. 
(b)  Cancellation due to unavailability of funds in succeeding fiscal periods. When funds are not appropriated or otherwise made available to support continuation of performance in a subsequent fiscal period, the contract shall be cancelled and the contractor shall be entitled to reimbursement for the reasonable value of any nonrecurring cost incurred but not advertised in the price of the supplies or services delivered under the contract or otherwise recoverable. 
(Code 1982, § 16.5-25)  
Sec. 62-73. - Right to inspect facilities. 
The city may at reasonable times inspect the facility or place of business of a contractor or any subcontractor which is related to the performance of any contract awarded or to be awarded by the city. 
(Code 1982, § 16.5-26)  
Sec. 62-74. - Right to audit records. 
The city shall be entitled to audit the books and records of a contractor or any subcontractor to the extent that such books and records relate to the performance of such contract or subcontract. Such books and records shall be maintained by the contractor for a period of three years from the date of final payment under the subcontract, unless a shorter period is otherwise authorized in writing. 
(Code 1982, § 16.5-27)  
Sec. 62-75. - Reporting of anticompetitive practices. 
When for any reason collusion or other anticompetitive practices are suspected among any bidders' offers, a notice of the relevant facts shall be transmitted to the city attorney for investigation and appropriate action. 
(Code 1982, § 16.5-28)  
Secs. 62-76—62-100. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - MODIFICATION AND TERMINATION OF CONTRACTS FOR SUPPLIES AND SERVICES 
 
Sec. 62-101. - Modification of contracts. 
(a)  Contract clauses. Subject to review and approval by the city attorney, the purchasing manager is authorized to promulgate and adopt regulations permitting or requiring the inclusion of clauses providing for or relating to change orders, modifications or adjustments in prices, time of performance or other contract provisions. 
(b)  Additional contract clauses. Subject to review and approval by the city attorney, the purchasing manager is authorized to adopt and promulgate regulations including, but not limited to, regulations permitting or requiring the inclusion in city contracts of clauses providing appropriate remedies covering the following subjects: 
(1)  Liquidated damages as appropriate; 
(2)  Specified excuses for delay or nonperformance; 
(3)  Termination of the contract for default; 
(4)  Termination in whole or in part for the convenience of the city; 
(5)  Insurance requirements and/or hold harmless provisions. 
(Code 1982, § 16.5-29)  
Sec. 62-102. - Contractual remedies. 
(a)  Authority to debar or suspend: 
(1)  Authority: 
a.  The purchasing manager shall have the authority to suspend a person from consideration for award of bids/contracts, if there is sufficient cause. The suspension shall not exceed a maximum period of six months. 
b.  The city commission shall have the authority to debar a person from consideration for award of bids/contracts. The debarment shall not exceed a maximum period of three years. 
(2)  Causes for debarment or suspension. The causes for debarment or suspension include, but are not limited to, the following: 
a.  Conviction or commission of a criminal offense incident to obtaining or attempting to obtain a public or private contract or subcontract or incident to performance of such contract or subcontract; 
b.  Conviction under state or federal statutes of embezzlement, theft, forgery, bribery, falsification or destruction of records, receiving of stolen property, or any other offense indicating a lack of business integrity or business honesty which currently, seriously and directly affects responsibility as a contractor; 
c.  Conviction under state or federal antitrust statutes arising out of the submission of bids or proposals; 
d.  Violation of material bid/contract provision: 
1.  Deliberate failure without good cause to perform in accordance with the specifications or within the time limit provided in the bid/contract or; 
2.  A recent record of failure to perform or of unsatisfactory performance in accordance with the terms of one or more bids/contracts; provided that failure to perform or unsatisfactory performance caused by acts beyond the control of the contractor shall not be considered to be a basis for debarment; 
3.  Failure of bidders to respond to bid invitation three consecutive times. 
e.  Any other cause/material factor affecting responsibility as a city contractor, including debarment of another governmental entity for any of the causes listed in this section. 
(b)  Authority to resolve contract and breach of contract controversies: 
(1)  Applicability. This section applies to controversies between the city and a contractor which arise under or by virtue of a contract between them. This includes, without limitation, controversy based upon breach of contract, mistake, misrepresentation or other cause for contract modification or recision. 
(2)  Authority: 
a.  The purchasing manager shall settle or resolve controversies arising under this section. 
b.  All controversies not settled or resolved by the purchasing manager shall be submitted to the city manager for settlement or resolution. 
(3)  Right to appeal. Decisions of the city manager may be appealed to the city commission. A written request shall be submitted to the city clerk requesting a hearing before the city commission within seven calendar days from the decision. 
(4)  Notice of decision. A copy of the decision under this section shall be mailed or otherwise furnished immediately to the contractor. 
(5)  Finality of decision. Any decision under this section shall be final and conclusive upon the contractor. 
(Code 1982, § 16.5-30)  
Chapter 66 - SECONDHAND GOODS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 22. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 66-1—66-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - GARAGE SALES 
 
Sec. 66-31. - Definition. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Garage sale. A garage sale is defined as a sale by a resident within the city of secondhand items belonging to said resident, which shall take place at the residential site of the resident conducting the garage sale. 
(Code 1982, § 17-16) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 66-32. - Duration of sale; frequency. 
Garage sales must not last more than 48 hours and may not be conducted by any resident more than once very three months. 
(Code 1982, § 17-17)  
Sec. 66-33. - Permit required. 
Garage sales may not be conducted without first obtaining a permit from the city, which permit shall set forth the time and place of said garage sale. Garage sales will only be authorized during daylight hours. 
(Code 1982, § 17-18)  
Sec. 66-34. - Display of sale goods. 
Merchandise for sale shall not be displayed on public sidewalks or rights-of-way. 
(Code 1982, § 17-19)  
Sec. 66-35. - Signs. 
One garage sale sign may be placed in a yard at a residence where the sale is to be held and no more than five off-premises signs. Garage sale signs shall not exceed a maximum of four square feet. Signs may be placed after 5:00 p.m. the day before the sale and must be removed by 8:00 a.m. following the last day of the sale. Signs shall not be located within any right-of-way. 
(Code 1982, § 17-20; Ord. No. 05-1753 § 1, 4-18-2005)  
Sec. 66-36. - Parking. 
Parking shall be controlled by the permittee so as not to be a hazard, or create any congestion on adjacent streets. 
(Code 1982, § 17-21)  
Sec. 66-37. - Display of city permit. 
The city permit shall be publicly displayed at the sale. 
(Code 1982, § 17-22)  
Secs. 66-38—66-60. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - PRECIOUS METALS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Secondhand dealers, F.S. ch. 538. 
 
Sec. 66-61. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this article is to set forth regulations governing the purchase and disposition of personal property made of precious metals by dealers within the city. 
(Code 1982, § 17-31)  
Sec. 66-62. - Definitions; applicability. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Consignment shop means a shop engaging in the business of accepting for sale, on consignment, secondhand goods which, having once been used or transferred from the manufacturer to the dealer, are then received into the possession of a third party. 
Pawn means either of the following transactions: 
(1)  Loan of money. A written or oral bailment of personal property as security for an engagement or debt, redeemable on certain terms and with the implied power of sale on default. 
(2)  Buy-sell agreement. An agreement whereby a purchaser agrees to hold property for a specified period of time to allow the seller the exclusive right to repurchase the property. A buy-sell agreement is not a loan of money. 
Pawnbroker means any person, corporation, or other business organization or entity which is regularly engaged in the business of making pawns but does not include a financial institution as defined in F.S. § 655.005 or any person who regularly loans money or any other thing of value on stocks, bonds, or other securities. 
Pledge means pawn or buy-sell agreement. 
Precious metals means any item containing any gold, silver, or platinum, or any combination thereof, excluding: 
(1)  Any chemical or any automotive, photographic, electrical, medical, or dental materials or electronic parts. 
(2)  Any coin with an intrinsic value less than its numismatic value. 
(3)  Any gold bullion coin. 
(4)  Any gold, silver, or platinum bullion that has been assayed and is properly marked as to its weight and fineness. 
(5)  Any coin which is mounted in a jewelry setting. 
Precious metals dealer means a secondhand dealer who normally or regularly engages in the business of buying used precious metals for resale. The term does not include those persons involved in the bulk sale of precious metals from one secondhand or precious metals dealer to another. 
Secondhand dealer means any person, corporation, or other business organization or entity which is not a secondary metals recycler subject to F.S. § 538.18 et seq. and which is engaged in the business of purchasing, consigning, or pawning secondhand goods. However, secondhand dealers are not limited to dealing only in items defined as secondhand goods in subsection (a)(7) of this section. Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, the term means pawnbrokers, jewelers, precious metals dealers, garage sale operators, secondhand stores, and consignment shops. 
Secondhand goods means personal property previously owned or used, which is not regulated metals property regulated under F.S. § 538.18 et seq. and which is purchased, consigned, or pawned as used property. Such secondhand goods shall be limited to watches; diamonds, gems, and other precious stones; fishing rods, reels, and tackle; audio and video electronic equipment, including television sets, compact disc players, radios, amplifiers, receivers, turntables, tape recorders; video tape recorders; speakers and citizens' band radios; computer equipment; radar detectors; depth finders; trolling motors; outboard motors; sterling silver flatware and serving pieces; photographic equipment, including cameras, video and film cameras, lenses, electronic flashes, tripods, and developing equipment; microwave ovens; animal fur coats; marine equipment; video games and cartridges; power lawn and landscape equipment; office equipment such as copiers, fax machines, and postage machines but excluding furniture; sports equipment; golf clubs; weapons, including knives, swords, and air guns but excluding firearms and ammunition as those items are defined in F.S. § 790.001; telephones, including cellular and portable; tools; calculators; musical instruments, excluding pianos and organs; lawnmowers; bicycles; typewriters; motor vehicles; gold, silver, platinum, and other precious metals excluding coins; and jewelry, excluding costume jewelry. 
Secondhand store means the place or premises at which a secondhand dealer is registered to conduct business as a secondhand dealer, or conducts business, including pawn shops. 
Transaction means any purchase, consignment, or pawn of secondhand goods by a secondhand dealer. 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
(b)  Applicability. This article does not apply to: 
(1)  Any secondhand goods transaction involving an organization or entity registered with the state as a nonprofit, religious, or charitable organization or any school-sponsored association or organization other than a secondary metals recycler subject to the provisions of F.S. § 538.18 et seq. 
(2)  A law enforcement officer acting in an official capacity. 
(3)  A trustee in bankruptcy, executor, administrator, or receiver who has presented proof of such status to the secondhand dealer. 
(4)  Any public official acting under judicial process or authority who has presented proof of such status to the secondhand dealer. 
(5)  A sale on the execution, or by virtue of any process issued by a court, if proof thereof has been presented to the secondhand dealer. 
(6)  Any garage sale operator who holds garage sales less than 10 weekends per year. 
(7)  Any person at antique, coin, or collectible shows or sales. 
(8)  Any person who sells household personal property as an agent for the property owner or their representative pursuant to a written agreement at that person's residence. 
(9)  The purchase, consignment, or pawn of secondhand goods from one secondhand dealer to another secondhand dealer when the selling secondhand dealer has complied with the requirements of this article. 
(10)  Any person accepting a secondhand good as a trade-in for a similar item of greater value. 
(11)  Any person purchasing, consigning, or pawning secondhand goods at a flea market regardless of whether at a temporary or permanent business location at the flea market. 
(12)  Any auction business as defined in F.S. § 468.382(1). 
(13)  Any business that is registered with the department of revenue for sales tax purposes as an antique dealer pursuant to F.S. ch. 212 and that purchases secondhand goods from the property owner or his representative at the property owner's residence pursuant to a written agreement that states the name, address, and telephone number of the property owner and the type of property purchased. 
(14)  Any person purchasing, consigning, or pawning secondhand goods ordered by mail, computer-assisted shopping, media-assisted, media-facilitated, or media-solicited shopping or shopping by other means of media communication, including, but not limited to, direct mail advertising, unsolicited distribution of catalogs, television, radio, or other electronic media, telephone, magazine, or newspaper advertising, so long as such person is in this state at the time of the order. 
(15)  A motor vehicle dealer as defined in F.S. § 320.27. 
(c)  Applicability to secondary metals recyclers. This article does not apply to secondary metals recyclers regulated under F.S. § 538.18 et seq., except for F.S. § 538.11, which applies to both secondhand dealers and secondary metals recyclers. 
(Ord. No. 11-1973, § 4, 9-19-2011) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, F.S. § 538.03.  
Sec. 66-63. - Recordkeeping requirements; penalties. 
(a)  Secondhand dealers shall maintain records of all transactions of secondhand goods on the premises. Within 24 hours of the acquisition of any secondhand goods by purchase or pledge as security for a loan, a secondhand dealer shall deliver to the police department or, if the goods were purchased outside of a municipality, to the sheriff's department of the county where the goods were purchased, a record of the transaction on a form approved by the state department of law enforcement. 
(b)  Such record shall contain: 
(1)  The time, date, and place of the transaction. 
(2)  A complete and accurate description of the goods acquired, including any serial numbers, manufacturer's numbers, or other identifying marks or characteristics. 
(3)  A description of the person from whom the goods were acquired, including: 
a.  Full name, address, workplace, and home and work phone numbers. 
b.  Height, weight, date of birth, race, gender, hair color, eye color, and any other identifying marks. 
(4)  Any other information required by the form approved by the state department of law enforcement. 
(c)  The secondhand dealer shall require verification of the identification by the exhibition of a government-issued photographic identification card such as a driver's license or military identification card. The record shall contain the type of identification exhibited, the issuing agency, and the number thereon. 
(d)  The seller shall sign a statement verifying that the seller is the rightful owner of the goods or is entitled to sell or pledge the goods. 
(e)  Any person who knowingly gives false verification of ownership or who gives a false or altered identification, and who receives money from a secondhand dealer for goods sold or pledged commits: 
(1)  If the value of the money received is less than $300.00, a misdemeanor of the first degree, punishable as provided in section 1-13. 
(2)  If the value of the money received is $300.00 or more, a felony of the third degree, punishable as provided in F.S. §§ 775.082, 775.083 or 775.084. 
(f)  Secondhand dealers are exempt from the provisions of this section for all transactions involving secondhand sports equipment except secondhand sports equipment that is permanently labeled with a serial number. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, F.S. § 538.04.  
Sec. 66-64. - Inspection of records and premises of secondhand dealers. 
(a)  The premises and required records of each secondhand dealer are subject to inspection during regular business hours by the police department or, if located outside the city, by the sheriff's department of the county in which the premises are located, and by any state law enforcement officer who has jurisdiction over the dealer. 
(b)  The inspection authorized by subsection (a) of this section shall consist of an examination on the premises of the inventory and required records to determine whether the records and inventory are being maintained on the premises as required by section 66-63 and whether the holding period required by section 66-65 is being complied with. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, F.S. § 538.05.  
Sec. 66-65. - Holding period. 
(a)  A secondhand dealer shall not sell, barter, exchange, alter, adulterate, or in any way dispose of any secondhand goods within 15 calendar days of the date of acquisition of the goods. Such holding periods are not applicable when the person known by the secondhand dealer to be the person from whom the goods were acquired desires to redeem, repurchase, or recover the goods, provided the dealer can produce the record of the original transaction with verification that the customer is the person from whom the goods were originally acquired. 
(b)  A secondhand dealer must maintain actual physical possession of all secondhand goods throughout a transaction. It is unlawful for a secondhand dealer to accept title or any other form of security in secondhand goods in lieu of actual physical possession. A secondhand dealer who accepts title or any other form of security in secondhand goods in lieu of actual physical possession commits a violation, punishable as provided in section 1-13. 
(c)  Upon probable cause that goods held by a secondhand dealer are stolen, a police officer may extend the holding period to a maximum of 60 days. However, the holding period may be extended beyond 60 days by a court of competent jurisdiction upon a finding of probable cause that the property is stolen and further holding is necessary for the purposes of trial or to safeguard such property. The dealer shall assume all responsibility, civil or criminal, relative to the property or evidence in question, including responsibility for the actions of any employee with respect thereto. 
(d)  All dealers in secondhand property regulated by this article shall maintain transaction records for five years. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, F.S. § 538.06.  
Sec. 66-66. - Penalty for violation of article. 
(a)  Except where otherwise provided herein, a person who knowingly violates any provision of this article commits a violation, punishable as provided in section 1-13. 
(b)  When the lawful owner recover stolen property from a secondhand dealer and the person who sold or pledged the stolen property to the secondhand dealer is convicted of theft, a violation of this section, or dealing in stolen property, the court shall order the defendant to make restitution to the secondhand dealer pursuant to F.S. § 775.089. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, F.S. § 538.07.  
Sec. 66-67. - Certain acts and practices prohibited. 
It is unlawful for a secondhand dealer or any employee thereof to do or allow any of the following acts: 
(1)  Knowingly make a transaction with: 
a.  Any person who is under the influence of drugs or alcohol when such condition is visible or apparent; 
b.  Any person under the age of 18 years; or 
c.  Any person using a name other than his own name or the registered name of his business. 
(2)  Have a secondhand store open or engage in or conduct business as a secondhand dealer between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. A secondhand dealer shall not conduct any transaction at a drive-through window or similar device. 
(3)  Fail to pay any sales tax owed to the state department of revenue or fail to have a sales tax registration number. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, F.S. § 538.15.  
Chapter 70 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; environment, ch. 38; accumulation of garbage, trash, weeds and wild growth, § 38-101 et seq.; utilities, ch. 90. 
State Law reference— Florida litter law, F.S. § 403.413. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 70-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Commercial establishment means any public or private place, building and/or enterprise devoted in whole or in part to a business enterprise, whether nonprofit-making or profit-making in nature, except where such place, building and/or enterprise constitutes a single-family residence or multiple dwelling of two units or less. Condominiums, patio houses and other such facilities, where the individual units are privately owned and used for residential purposes, are not commercial establishments within the context of this definition, unless bulk collection for such facilities is used rather than individual residential unit collection. 
Commercial rubbish and trash means such combustibles as paper, wood, yard trimmings, etc., and noncombustibles such as metal, glass, stone, dirt, etc. 
Commercial solid waste means garbage, rubbish, trash, etc., resulting from the normal activities of establishments either required to have a business, occupation or professional license and/or utilize containers of one cubic yard capacity or more. 
Commission means the city commission of the City of Longwood. 
Container, commercial means any portable, nonabsorbent, enclosed container with a close-fitting cover, or doors, approved by the health department and the city, which is used to store large volumes of refuse, It must be capable of being serviced by mechanical equipment. 
Container, residential means a container made of nonabsorbent material provided with a close-fitting cover, side bail handles, and of 32 gallons or less gross capacity, or a waterproof bag of a strength and material approved by the commission. 
Curbside pickup means service rendered by a franchisee whereby the franchisee picks up an unlimited number of household refuse containers and yard trash. Yard trash service shall not exceed three cubic yards each pickup day. Collection service shall be provided at least twice weekly at the curb or other public road frontage area on days approved by the commission. 
Franchisee means the individual, partnership or corporation who/which agrees, as provided herein and in the individual franchise ordinance, to perform the work or service or to furnish the materials or equipment, or both, as set forth in the franchise ordinance. 
Garbage means every waste accumulation and animal and vegetable matter which attend the preparation, use, cooking, processing, handling or storage of meats, fish, fowl, fruits, vegetables or other matter which is subject to decomposition, decay, putrefaction and the generation of offensive and noxious gases or odors or which, during or after decay, may serve as breeding or feeding materials for flies, insects, rodents or animals. 
Handicapped persons means persons who are certified by a licensed physician to be physically unable to transport garbage to the curb or road frontage area from other areas of the persons' residential property and who reside alone or reside only with other persons likewise unable to transport garbage to the curb or road frontage area. 
Hazardous waste means hazardous, infectious, and special waste as defined in Florida Administrative Codes and regulations, which shall be collected and disposed of pursuant to state law and applicable federal regulations. 
Household shall apply to all single-family and duplex dwelling units. Multiple-dwelling units and complexes having more than two dwellings units will be considered commercial establishments. 
Household refuse means all waste from and incidental to the use of homes, residences and dwelling units including, but not limited to, newspapers, magazines, citrus fruit, wrappings, discarded clothing, empty flattened packing cases, packing materials, bottles, cans, ashes, broken glass and garbage. Christmas trees shall be collected under the definition of household refuse. Not included in the definition of refuse are automobile tires, automobile batteries, paint, dead animals, dirt or earth. Construction or industrial waste material such as plaster, lumber, concrete, bricks, tile or fixtures resulting from building construction, alterations or manufacturing processes shall not be considered household refuse. 
Rear door pickup means service rendered by a franchisee whereby the franchisee collects, at least twice weekly from the requesting resident only, an unlimited number of containers of household refuse from the side or rear of the dwelling unit within an area no further than 100 feet from the curb or other public road frontage and an unlimited number of containers or bundles of trash from the curb or other public road frontage area; and, if possible, such trash shall be placed not more than three feet from the curb or other public road frontage. 
Recyclable container means a portable recycling bin approved by the city. 
Recyclable materials means the following materials, which will be collected under the curbside recycling service: newspaper (newspaper only), aluminum cans (aluminum cans only), glass jars and bottles, and any additional items later determined to be recyclable materials. 
Resident means a person, family or residential unit benefitting from refuse collection service as provided by this chapter, meaning persons possessing or residing at property entitled to residential refuse collection. 
Special courtesy service means service rendered by a franchisee whereby the franchisee collects at least twice weekly, from the residences of handicapped persons verified by the commission only, an unlimited number of containers of household refuse from the side or rear of the dwelling unit within an area no further than 100 feet from the curb or other public road frontage and an unlimited number of containers or bundles of yard trash from the curb or other public road frontage area. This service shall be provided at no additional charge or fee beyond the commission-approved curbside service charge. 
Special handling service means an additional convenience or service to the customer which increases the cost of service and is not a service required to be provided pursuant to this chapter. 
Special material means bulky materials or other special wastes that are not stored in standard storage containers and cannot be picked up by a normally used collection vehicle. Wastes not to be collected are major appliances, furniture, building materials, tree limbs, noncontainerized trash piles or any abnormal amount of refuse not suitable for containerization, which will be picked up by calling the office of the franchisee and arranging by special service to be billed on the basis of labor, truck costs and dumping charges. 
Yard trash means all garden and yard trimmings, leaves, branches, aquatic weeds and grasses, and all other similar vegetation. 
(Code 1982, § 9-1) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 70-2. - Grant of franchise. 
The city commission is hereby authorized to grant the right, privilege or franchise, exclusive or nonexclusive, as the case may be, to collect household refuse and yard trash from all residents of the city, or to collect garbage, refuse, trash and other solid waste materials from commercial establishments during the terms and subject to the limitations and conditions as hereinafter set forth and as set forth in the particular franchise ordinances. 
(Code 1982, § 9-2)  
Sec. 70-3. - Term of franchise; extension. 
(a)  The term of a franchise shall be three years from the effective date thereof, provided, however, the city reserves the right to terminate the same prior thereto if the franchisee defaults in any of the terms and conditions specified herein or in the ordinance granting the franchise. 
(b)  The term of a franchise may be extended unilaterally by the city commission for up to an additional 90 days on the last-prevailing terms and conditions by giving notice in writing to the franchisee at least 30 days prior to the expiration of the original term. 
(c)  The term of a franchise may be extended mutually by the city commission and the franchisee for up to an additional three years, providing the city commission gives notice in writing to the franchisee at least 90 days prior to the expiration of the original term. 
(Code 1982, § 9-3)  
Sec. 70-4. - Office. 
The franchisee shall establish and maintain a local office or such other facilities through which it can be contacted, where service may be applied for and complaints can be made. Such facility shall be equipped with sufficient telephones, shall have one responsible person in charge during collection hours and shall be open during collection hours. 
(Code 1982, § 9-4)  
Sec. 70-5. - Complaints; notification of procedures. 
(a)  Complaints. All complaints shall be resolved within 24 hours. The franchisee shall supply the city with copies of all complaints on a form approved by the city and indicate the disposition of each complaint. Such records shall be available for city inspection at all times during business hours. The form shall indicate the day and hour on which the complaint was received, the day and hour on which it was resolved, the name of the complainant, the nature of the complaint and the manner of resolution. When a complaint is received on the day preceding a holiday, a Saturday or on a Sunday, it shall be serviced on the next working day. 
(b)  Notification. The franchisee shall notify all customers about complaint procedures, rates, regulations and days of collection. 
(Code 1982, § 9-5)  
Sec. 70-6. - Remedies; attorney's fees and cost. 
All remedies provided in this chapter or in the franchise ordinance shall be deemed cumulative and additional and not in lieu of or exclusive of each other or of any other remedy available to the city at law or in equity. In the event the city shall prevail in any action arising under this chapter or the franchise ordinance, the franchisee shall pay to the city its costs referable thereto, including attorneys' fees. 
(Code 1982, § 9-6)  
Sec. 70-7. - Amendment. 
The city reserves the right to amend this chapter and the franchise ordinance in any manner necessary for the health, safety or welfare of the public, and the city reserves the right, in the public interest from time to time, to prescribe reasonable rules and regulations governing the franchisee's operations. 
(Code 1982, § 9-7)  
Sec. 70-8. - Penalty for violation. 
Any person or company who violates this chapter or who fails to comply with any of its requirements shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished as provided in section 1-13 and in addition shall pay costs and expenses involved in the case. 
(Code 1982, § 9-8)  
Sec. 70-9. - Throwing or distributing unsolicited materials—Prohibitions. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to cast, throw or otherwise place any paper, unsolicited merchandise or discarded material on any private residential lawn or driveway without the express consent of the owner, or of an adult occupant thereof, or of a person authorized by such owner or occupant to give such consent. 
(b)  It is unlawful for any person to cast, place or scatter any paper, unsolicited merchandise, or discarded material on any vehicle on any public property or on any parking lot open to the use of the public, in any manner other than by the delivery thereof to a person who then and there accepts the same or has given his express consent to the receipt thereof. 
(Code 1982, § 9-9)  
Sec. 70-10. - Same—Delivery to private residence after notice of objection. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to continue to distribute, cast, throw, or otherwise place circulars, handbills, political materials, newspapers, magazines, or merchandise on private residential property, after receiving notification by the owner or occupant of a private residence that said owner or occupant does not wish to receive the item being distributed to said residence. 
(Code 1982, § 9-10)  
Sec. 70-11. - Same—Exemptions. 
The provisions of sections 70-9 and 70-10 shall not apply to the regular delivery of newspapers or magazines which have been subscribed to by the persons receiving them or to the distribution of mail by the United States Government or to the service of any lien foreclosure or governmental notices of process. 
(Code 1982, § 9-11)  
Sec. 70-12. - Same—Variances. 
The city commission may, by written resolution, grant variances from the provisions of sections 70-9 and 70-10 to permit the distribution of papers or merchandise as otherwise prohibited, upon such terms and conditions as the city commission may impose, after due consideration of the following: 
(1)  The nature, scope, purpose, method and times of distribution. 
(2)  The extent of the distribution, both as to time required therefor and area to be covered. 
(3)  The identity of the person or persons who will be responsible for the distribution. 
(4)  The date or dates on or between which the distribution is to be accomplished. 
(5)  The approximate number of individuals who will be engaged in the distribution. 
(6)  The provision for removal, by the individual or organization proposing the distribution, of items not removed by the property owner within a reasonable period of time following the distribution. 
(7)  The likelihood, or lack thereof; of the distribution constituting a real and present danger to the public health, welfare and safety. 
(Code 1982, § 9-12)  
Secs. 70-13—70-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - RESIDENTIAL SOLID WASTE COLLECTION 
 
Sec. 70-31. - Residential collection service required. 
All residential units (single or duplex) shall have service provided by the city's residential collection contractor. Owners of all residential units (single or duplex) shall be responsible for payment of bills rendered by the city. 
(Code 1982, § 9-21)  
Sec. 70-32. - Frequency of collection. 
All refuse shall be collected at frequencies not less than those specified in these rules and regulations. The frequency of collection is hereby established as follows: 
(1)  Household refuse: At least twice each calendar week and at least three days apart. 
(2)  Yard trash: At least once each calendar week. 
(3)  Quarterly cleanups: The contractor will provide a special pickup once every three months, on a day mutually agreed upon between the city and the contractor, to provide residents an opportunity to dispose of large items which are not permitted during regular pickups, such as refrigerators, stoves, washing machines, etc. The city will provide notice to residents concerning these pickups. 
(Code 1982, § 9-22)  
Sec. 70-33. - Period of collection. 
All collection of refuse shall be made during the hours from 7:00 a.m. until 7:00 p.m. The contractor is hereby prohibited from collecting and picking up household refuse on Sundays and on the following holidays: New Year's Day, Labor Day, the Fourth of July, Thanksgiving and Christmas Day. The city manager may authorize refuse collections to commence at 6:00 a.m. Monday through Friday during the months of July, August and September. 
(Code 1982, § 9-23)  
Sec. 70-34. - Contractor's responsibility for cleanliness of operation. 
The contractor shall be responsible for cleaning from the streets and collection places all refuse spillage resulting from the contractor's operation. Each truck shall be equipped with an adequate shovel and broom for this purpose. In addition, the contractor shall be responsible for removing and cleaning all oil, grease, paint, glass or other substance on the public streets due to equipment failure or refuse leakage resulting from refuse operations. 
(Code 1982, § 9-24)  
Sec. 70-35. - Noncollection. 
When any refuse is not collected by the contractor, he shall leave a tag on which he has indicated the reason for the refusal to collect. This information shall be either in writing or by means of a check system. The tag shall carry the name of the contractor and telephone number and be securely fastened to the container or the article refused, or placed on the front door of such residence. The contractor shall make and keep a duplicate copy of the tag for record purposes. 
(Code 1982, § 9-25)  
Sec. 70-36. - Collection equipment. 
(a)  The contractor shall provide an adequate number of vehicles for regular collection services. The vehicles shall be kept in good repair, appearance, and in a sanitary condition at all times. Each vehicle shall have clearly visible, on each side, the name and telephone number of the contractor, and vehicle number not less than four inches in height on the rear and side of each vehicle. 
(b)  The contractor shall certify to the city within 60 days after the commencement of each contract year the description and quantity of vehicles and equipment on hand and available for regular collection services and backup equipment in the event of any breakdowns. 
(Code 1982, § 9-26)  
Sec. 70-37. - Disposal. 
All household refuse, recyclable materials and yard trash for disposal shall be hauled to sites or facilities legally empowered to accept it for treatment or disposal. However, the site or facility shall be in compliance with the interlocal agreement between the city and the county and any management plan adopted pursuant to said interlocal agreement. 
(Code 1982, § 9-27)  
Sec. 70-38. - City's payment to contractor. 
The city shall pay the contractor for services provided, less the 12 percent billing and collection fee, by the 15th of the month following provision of service. The payment due will be based upon the monthly number of residential customers billed. The city will provide this information to the contractor. 
(Code 1982, § 9-28)  
Sec. 70-39. - Routes and schedules. 
Routes and schedules of collection shall be subject to the approval of the city. The contractor shall provide the city with proposed schedules for collection routes and shall keep such information current at all times. It shall be the customer's responsibility to place refuse at the appropriate location for collection before the approved pickup time. 
(Code 1982, § 9-29)  
Sec. 70-40. - Books and records. 
The contractor shall keep records of household refuse collected and the number of customers served and payments received from the city and residents for service performed. The city will have the right to review all records of the contractor. 
(Code 1982, § 9-30)  
Sec. 70-41. - Charges and rates. 
(a)  Generally. The contractor agrees to perform the services as stated herein at the rate as set out in appendix B per month per residence, which rate shall include charges for all types of recyclable materials (glass containers, cans, paper, newspaper). The rates may be adjusted annually on every anniversary date of the franchise or at any other time as set forth in the contract to reflect any change to be calculated pursuant to the terms and conditions with the contractor pursuant to the contract with the city. 
(b)  Extraordinary rate adjustment. The contractor may petition the city commission at any time for an additional rate adjustment on the basis of extraordinary and unusual changes in the cost of operations that could not reasonably be foreseen by a prudent operator. The contractor's request shall contain substantial proof and justification to support the need for the rate adjustment. The city may request from the contractor such further information as may be reasonably necessary in making its determination. The decision by the city to grant or deny an extraordinary rate adjustment shall be at their sole discretion. The contractor may not terminate service or fail to perform pursuant to the contract for failure to receive an extraordinary rate adjustment. 
(c)  Billing and collection. The city will perform the duties of billing and collection agent for all residential refuse and curbside recycling service, except as provided in subsection (d) below. An administrative fee as set out in appendix B per month per residence shall be charged for the billing and collection service. Said administrative fee shall be added to the amount billed for the collection of residential solid waste. 
(d)  Items requiring special handling. Items requiring special handling due to size, weight, type of material or method of placement and payment may be negotiated between the contractor and the resident prior to collection. 
(e)  Copies of bills to resident and city. A copy of every bill rendered to a resident shall be provided to the city simultaneously. 
(Code 1982, § 9-31)  
Sec. 70-42. - Contractor rules and procedures. 
Rules and procedures required of the contractor are as follows, such rules and procedures shall be changed by ordinance: 
(1)  The contractor shall not park trucks in residential areas except for loading purposes. 
(2)  The contractor shall maintain a listed, local city/county telephone number by company name which shall be manned during hours of operation on scheduled collection days (except holidays, as approved by the commission). If citizens find that the company cannot be contacted in a reasonable time, the city may require installation of additional telephones and telephone operators. Answering services are not acceptable. The contractor shall have at all times a competent and reliable representative at the office authorized to act for it. 
(3)  All customer complaints shall be resolved within 24 hours of notice. Complaint forms shall show the date, time and disposition of the complaint, the name of the complainant and the action taken. These records shall be maintained in writing by consecutive date and shall be open to inspection by the city during business hours. 
(4)  The contractor shall supply to customers a printed information card containing information on rates, general information, customer responsibility, complaint procedure, collection schedules, holiday schedules, etc. Such information shall be approved by the city and may not be distributed prior to such approval. Distribution shall be made by the contractor as approved by the city manager or designee. 
(5)  In the event of equipment breakdown, a shortage of employees, or other causes which will or might delay regular service for more than one day, the contractor shall immediately notify the city manager. 
(6)  Employees of the contractor shall be courteous with customers, shall be neatly dressed, and shall wear identification, either by uniform, insignia or other device which will readily identify the employee and the contractor. Employees shall replace containers in carts or otherwise place containers so as to prevent damage. 
(7)  The contractor shall respond to new requests for resident service within two working days and shall provide new customers with the information required under subsection (4) of this section. 
(8)  The contractor shall be familiar with all provisions of this chapter. 
(9)  Equipment shall be maintained in a good condition and shall meet all Occupational Safety and Health Act requirements. 
(10)  The contractor must provide the commission with names and addresses of all persons who are officers, managers and owners of said contractor. Companies registered to sell stock over the counter or upon a listed exchange shall not be required to provide names and addresses of owners. 
(11)  The contractor shall not use a firm name containing the words "City of Longwood" or other words implying city ownership. 
(12)  Each truck shall at all times have in the cab a facsimile of the registration of the truck, of the certificate of insurance, and an identification card with the name of whom to telephone in case of an accident. 
(13)  Palm fronds, tree limbs, and other trash not subject to containerization must be securely tied and bundled and shall be picked up at the curb if cut to a length not to exceed three feet or 60 pounds in weight. 
(14)  The contractor shall provide for a quarterly curbside pickup of discarded appliances and household furnishings. A minimum of 30 days advance notice shall be provided by the city. 
(15)  Hazardous, infectious, and special waste as defined in Florida Administrative Codes and regulations, or other state or federal laws, shall be collected and disposed of pursuant to the above requirements and any applicable state and/or federal regulations. 
(16)  In the event an excessive amount of debris or refuse has accumulated by reason of a storm, natural disaster, severe disturbance, riot or other calamity, the city shall pay the contractor for such additional service, upon certification by the contractor of the payroll, equipment and disposal costs. The city shall give official recognition to the emergency and shall provide notice to the contractor of the service required by the city. All invoices submitted by the contractor for such additional services shall be subject to approval by the city. 
(17)  The contractor shall make available to any resident at its principal place of business, upon the resident's request, any pertinent information regarding the service rendered. The contractor shall have on file for inspection upon request of the general public at each of its principal places of business the following: 
a.  A copy of the form of contract relating to the service area of the contractor; 
b.  A copy of the applicable city ordinances, resolutions, rules and regulations; 
c.  A map showing the area serviced by the contractor; and 
d.  A legible notice placed in a conspicuous place in the office to the effect that a copy of the foregoing are kept there for inspection by the general public. 
(18)  The contractor shall provide garbage and trash service at least twice a week to all municipal facilities owned and/or operated by the city at no cost to the city. The contractor shall provide garbage containers. Such service locations include, but are not limited to: 
a.  City hall; 
b.  City hall annex; 
c.  Community center; 
d.  Police department; 
e.  All fire stations; 
f.  All parks and playgrounds; 
g.  Public works and facilities; 
h.  Water plants. 
The contractor may subcontract for this service, with the approval of the subcontractor by the city. 
(Code 1982, § 9-32)  
Sec. 70-43. - Customer rules and regulations. 
(a)  Solid food waste. Customers shall be required to place all solid food waste in a sturdy plastic or metal container which shall be covered with a tight-fitting lid to prevent animals from littering waste. Plastic bags, as defined in section 70-1, are permitted. 
(b)  Household refuse. Any or all types of household refuse shall be picked up at curbside from each family or residential unit. The contractor will provide special courtesy service to the rear of any residential unit for those handicapped individuals, who request this service and are approved by the city, at no additional charge beyond the curbside rate. Any resident (nonhandicapped) may request rear door pickup for a surcharge as set out in appendix B, per month, subject to change by the commission. 
(c)  Yard trash. Any and all types of yard trash shall be picked up at curbside, or equivalent location on unpaved streets, from each family or residence unit. Trash will be bagged, tied in bundles or placed in garbage containers. Tree limbs and shrubbery trimmings must be tied in bundles not exceeding three feet in length and not weighing more than 60 pounds. 
(d)  Replacement containers. In all cases of collection, the contractor shall carefully replace containers in an upright position with the lids alongside in their proper location after emptying. The contractor, his agents and employees shall not throw containers to the ground nor in any other way break or damage the same. 
(e)  Containers: 
(1)  Containers shall be watertight and of impervious material, provided with a tightfitting cover suitable to protect the contents from flies, insects, rats and other animals, or a waterproof bag safely and securely closed, of a type approved by the commission or health department, and not exceeding 32 gallons' capacity nor 60 pounds in weight, including container, when full. 
(2)  The container shall not have any inside structures, such as inside bands or reinforcing angles, which might prevent the free discharge of contents. Containers shall be free of jagged or sharp edges. 
(f)  Placement of containers: 
(1)  Back door pickup. For back door or side collection, garbage containers shall be within side or back yards, at or near ground level and located so as to be easily accessible to the collector and within an area no further than 100 feet from the curb or other public road frontage. Trash containers shall be placed as near to the curb or road surface as safely possible and, if possible, shall be placed not more than three feet from the curb or public roadway abutting the customer's property. Customers must ensure that containers may be picked up without interference from pets or other sources and that the safety of the collector not be threatened. A surcharge as set out in appendix B per month shall be charged for nonhandicapped back door pickup. 
(2)  Curbside pickup. Containers shall be placed as near the curb or public road surface as safely possible and, if possible, shall be placed not more than three feet from the paved or improved roadway abutting the customer's property. Containers shall be removed within 12 hours after collection. Containers shall not be placed at curbside more than 12 hours prior to collection. 
(3)  Containers must be placed behind the front line of the house any days not designated for collection. 
(g)  House numbering. Each customer shall display a house number in plain view from the street if such a number has been assigned to the premises by the county or other governmental authority as provided in chapter 18, article VII of this Code. 
(h)  Christmas service. Cardboard boxes, wrappings and Christmas trees shall be placed at the curb and picked up without restriction except as to weight. Trees may be cut to lengths not to exceed three feet and be securely tied and bundled. 
(i)  Trash not subject to containerization. Customers shall ensure that palm fronds, tree limbs and other trash not subject to containerization shall be securely tied and bundled, placed at the curb and cut to lengths not to exceed three feet nor a weight of 60 pounds. 
(j)  Hazardous, infectious and special waste. Hazardous, infectious, and special waste as defined in Florida Administrative Codes and regulations shall be prepared by the customers for disposal in a manner consistent with the above requirements and any applicable federal regulations. 
(k)  Vacant lots. Waste collection services for vacant lots shall be subject to negotiation between the contractor and the owner or other party desiring such service. It will not be the responsibility of the contractor to remove waste resulting from cleaning property for building purposes. 
(Code 1982, § 9-33)  
Sec. 70-44. - Billing; payment. 
(a)  The city shall prepare and deliver bills to all residential units on a monthly basis. Bills for service are due and payable in the month service is given. Bills for service are due on the tenth of the month, with a $5.00 late charge added after the 15th of the month. No credit can be given for vacant property, unless written notice is received by the city at least ten days prior to vacancy. 
(b)  Residents requiring back door pick up, where a charge is made, shall be liable for at least six months of charges. 
(Code 1982, § 9-34)  
Sec. 70-45. - Discontinued service; delinquent accounts. 
The contractor shall discontinue service when authorized by the city due to nonpayment of monthly charges. 
(Code 1982, § 9-35)  
Sec. 70-46. - Residential curbside recycling service. 
(a)  Services to be performed by contractor. The contractor shall: 
(1)  Operate and maintain a solid waste recycling program, starting with curbside pickup and consisting of the processing and brokering of recyclable materials from all residences within the city limits. Materials to be collected are the following: 
Newspaper (newspaper only), aluminum cans (aluminum cans only), glass jars and bottles, and any additional items later determined to be recyclable materials. 
(2)  Furnish at its own cost all labor, material, equipment and tools necessary to perform the above-described services. The city will be responsible for purchasing recycling bins. 
(b)  Manner of performance: 
(1)  The contractor shall deliver a bin to each home for the purpose of storing recyclable materials in the home and identifying the recyclable materials at the curb. The contractor will replace any bins damaged or destroyed by the contractor. 
(2)  The contractor shall remove only such recyclable materials from all households receiving regular residential garbage collection in accordance with the terms of the contractor. These materials are to be placed in the recycling bin at the curbside collection point. 
(3)  Recyclable materials shall be collected once each week on a normal garbage collection day. There shall be no limit to the quantity of recyclable materials, provided they are placed in a recycling bin. 
(4)  The city may inspect the recyclable materials to ascertain that they conform to the requirements of this section. The contractor will not be required to collect materials that are in violation of this section. The nonrecyclable materials in the recycling bin will be left in the bin at the residence as examples of incorrect materials that should not be placed for collection, with an explanation as to why the materials are not acceptable. 
(c)  Obligations of residents: 
(1)  Recycling bins: Upon implementation of the recycling program, each residence will be provided, free of charge, one portable bin for recycling materials to accommodate the amount of recyclable materials generated. This initial bin will be purchased by the city at no expense to the resident, and the contractor will deliver the bin to each home with instructions and date of pickup for that particular residence. Additional containers may be purchased from the city if desired. 
(2)  Placement of recycling bins: On the day designated for collection, the recycling bin shall be placed for collection on the curb at the normal collection point not later than 7:00 a.m. on the day of collection. 
(3)  Replacement of recycling bins: In the event the recycling bin is lost or stolen, a replacement bin must be obtained from the city for a fee as set out in appendix B. Once the curbside recycling program has been implemented, new residents will be charged a fee as set out in appendix B for bins. 
(d)  Ownership: 
(1)  All recyclable material collected by the contractor shall be and become the property of the contractor from and after the time of collection. 
(2)  The parties understand and acknowledge that no person other than the owner thereof, his agents or employees, or an officer or employee of the city, or the contractor, his agents or employees authorized for such purposes shall tamper or meddle with any bin or the contents of the bin or remove the bin from the location where the same shall have been placed by the owner thereof or his agent. 
(3)  When vacating a residence, the resident must return the recycling bin to the city. Failure to return the bin to the city will result in the resident being charged a fee as set out in appendix B on the final utility bill. 
(4)  New residents will be charged a fee as set out in appendix B upon initiation of utility services, and the bin will be delivered to the residence by the contractor. 
(e)  Collection hours. Recyclable material collections shall be made between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m. The city manager may authorize collections to commence at 6:00 a.m. on Monday through Friday during the months of July, August and September. 
(f)  Holidays. On the following legal holidays, no collection of recyclable materials will be made by the contractor: Independence Day (Fourth of July), Labor Day, Thanksgiving Day, Christmas Day, New Year's Day. Should one of the legal holidays fall on a regularly scheduled pickup day, the collection of recyclable materials will be accomplished on the next regularly scheduled recycling collection day. 
(g)  Reporting requirements. The contractor shall keep records of recyclable materials picked up in the city so as to allow the city to meet the state department of environmental regulation reporting requirements or other state or federal requirements. 
(Code 1982, § 9-36)  
Sec. 70-47. - Compliance with contract terms and conditions. 
The contractor shall comply with all of the terms and conditions that are set forth in the contract with the city for the collection of residential solid waste. 
(Code 1982, § 9-37)  
Sec. 70-48. - Contract term. 
(a)  Initial term. The term of the resulting contract shall be for a five-year period beginning May 5, 1998, and terminating May 4, 2003. The city reserves the right to terminate the contract prior to the expiration date, if the bidder defaults in any one of the terms and conditions of the contract or city Code. 
(b)  Option to renew. The contract term between the city and the contractor may be extended for one additional three-year period at the option of the city. The city shall notify the contractor of its intent to exercise this renewal option to allow the contract to terminate. Said notice shall be in writing and delivered not less than 120 days prior to May 4, 2003. In the event the city notified the contractor of its intent to exercise this renewal option, the contractor shall notify the city of its intent to accept or decline the renewal offer. Such notice shall be made in writing and delivered to the city within 20 days of receipt by the contractor of the city's notice of intent to exercise the renewal option. In the event the contract is renewed, the city may, at the end of the three-year period, either renegotiate the terms and conditions of the contract with the current contractor or request bids from qualified contractors to provide solid waste collection and recycling services. The city shall notify the contractor of its decision not less than 120 days prior to the end of the extension period. 
(Code 1982, § 9-38)  
Secs. 70-49—70-70. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - PRIVATE COMMERCIAL SOLID WASTE COLLECTION 
 
Sec. 70-71. - Collection by private commercial collector. 
All commercial solid waste accumulated in the city by commercial establishments shall be collected, conveyed and disposed of by a private commercial collector authorized to do business within the city. Commercial establishments shall further be required to participate in and comply with all requirements of any recovered materials (recycling) program, to include segregation of special waste such as yard waste, which shall be offered by the franchised commercial collectors under the requirements of this chapter. 
(Code 1982, § 9-51)  
Sec. 70-72. - Authority to award nonexclusive franchises. 
(a)  Award of franchise generally. The city commission is hereby authorized to award nonexclusive franchises to private commercial collectors, who shall qualify to do business within the city, the right and privilege to contract for and collect solid waste from commercial establishments within the city, subject to the limitations and conditions as are contained within the franchise ordinance. Such a grant is a nonexclusive right, and shall be awarded by ordinance. 
(b)  Terms and conditions. The franchise ordinance shall provide the terms and conditions under which the franchisee shall operate. Said franchise ordinance shall contain appropriate standards and requirements designed to protect and ensure the public health, safety and welfare. 
(Code 1982, § 9-52)  
Sec. 70-73. - Term of nonexclusive franchise. 
(a)  The term of the nonexclusive franchise between the city and the private commercial collectors shall be for a term not to exceed one year expiring on September 30 following the effective date of the franchise provided, however, the city reserves the right to terminate the same prior thereto if the franchise defaults in any one of the terms and conditions herein specified. 
(b)  The franchise shall be automatically extended for one additional one-year term expiring the following September 30, provided the franchise shall make application for said extension 30 days prior to its termination. 
(Code 1982, § 9-53)  
Sec. 70-74. - Authorization by city required. 
No private commercial collector shall engage in collection of commercial solid waste within the city until awarded a franchise to do so. A fee as set out in appendix B shall be charged for each franchise application to cover associated administrative costs. Violation of this section shall be referred to the code enforcement board for enforcement. 
(Code 1982, § 9-54)  
Sec. 70-75. - Compensation to city. 
For the privilege of collecting solid waste materials from commercial establishments within the city, securing a franchise from the city and for the use of the city streets, the franchised collector shall pay to the city, a monthly franchise fee. The franchise fee shall be established by the franchise ordinance. 
(Code 1982, § 9-55)  
Sec. 70-76. - Rates. 
The rates of collection charged by private commercial collectors to commercial establishments shall be determined by the franchisee in negotiation with the commercial establishment. Rates shall not be set by the city commission but rather shall be determined in the marketplace based upon competition among franchisees. 
(Code 1982, § 9-56)  
Sec. 70-77. - Use of franchisee required. 
It is the intent of this chapter that all commercial establishments as defined herein shall be serviced by franchised private commercial collectors. No commercial establishment within the city shall utilize the services of a collector not holding a franchise from the city. Violation of this section shall be referred to the code enforcement board for enforcement. 
(Code 1982, § 9-57)  
Sec. 70-78. - Use and location of approved containers. 
Containers used for collection of solid waste from commercial establishments shall be standard manufactured type mechanically serviced containers, compatible with the private commercial collector's servicing equipment. Containers shall be placed at locations readily accessible to franchisee's personnel. Containers shall be located upon private property unless the use of public property is approved by the city. Violations of this section shall be referred to the code enforcement board for enforcement. 
(Code 1982, § 9-58)  
Secs. 70-79—70-100. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - DUMPING OF INDUSTRIAL WASTE AND REFUSE 
 
Sec. 70-101. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
