ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 90-1—90-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - WATER AND WASTEWATER 
 
Sec. 90-31. - Connection required. 
Where the same shall be available, the owner of every lot or parcel of land within the city shall connect, or cause the plumbing of any building or buildings thereon to be connected, with the city public utilities system, and use the facilities of such system. All such connections shall be made in accordance with rules and regulations which shall be adopted from time to time by the city commission, which rules and regulations shall provide for a charge for making any such connections in such reasonable amount as the city commission may fix and determine; provided, however, that this shall not be construed to entitle any person to cross the private property of another to make such connections. All such work, including new construction, repair, replacement, maintenance or upgrading as related to any portion of the city public utilities system, as well as the installation of backflow prevention devices, shall be accomplished in strict accordance with the City of Longwood Manual of Standards for the Design, Construction and Maintenance of Water and Wastewater Systems . 
(Code 1982, § 23-16)  
Sec. 90-32. - Mandatory wastewater service connection. 
(a)  The owner of every other lot or parcel of land which abuts an existing or planned street, right-of-way, or other public thoroughfare or public easement containing a wastewater line upon which a building is or will be constructed so as to produce deleterious wastewater shall use and connect such building to the city wastewater system, when such building is located within the city wastewater service area (as may be amended from time to time) and the city wastewater system is available for connection. The city wastewater system is deemed available for connection and a mandatory connection to the city wastewater system shall occur as follows: 
(1)  For all new residential subdivisions, as defined in the Longwood Development Code, connection to the city wastewater system shall be mandatory. This shall include new subdivisions of three or more lots created by replatting existing lots. 
(2)  For all lots or land parcels with a commercial, infill and mixed use, neighborhood commercial mixed use, or industrial land use designation, connection to the city wastewater system shall be mandatory. 
(3)  For all lots or land parcels, regardless of the land use designation, connection shall be mandatory when the city wastewater system is within 50 feet of the property line as accessed via existing public rights-of-way or easements. 
(4)  For all lots and land parcels, regardless of the land use designation, connection shall be mandatory, regardless of the distance from the property line to the city wastewater system, when: (i) the county health department has denied a permit for construction or reconstruction of an onsite wastewater disposal system, or (ii) the private sewage treatment and disposal system or septic tank fails or is not properly functioning. In such case, the private sewage treatment and disposal system or septic tank shall be cleaned and abandoned as directed by the city and any other applicable controlling regulatory agency. 
(5)  The owner of a properly functioning private sewage treatment and disposal system (including a septic tank) must connect the system or the building's plumbing to the city wastewater sewer system within 365 days after written notification by the city that the city wastewater sewer system is available for connection. The private sewage treatment and disposal system or septic tank shall be cleaned and abandoned as directed by the city and any other applicable controlling regulatory agency. No less than one year prior to the date the city wastewater sewer system will become available, the city will notify the affected owner of the private sewage treatment and disposal system or septic tank of the anticipated availability of the city wastewater sewer system and shall also notify the owner that the owner will be required to connect to the city wastewater sewer system within one year of the actual availability. However, if the city wastewater sewer system was already available for connection prior to July 30, 2016, then the city shall have the right to send written notice at any time and require the affected owner of the private sewage treatment and disposal system or septic tank to connect to the city wastewater sewer system within one year after said written notice. If the connection to the city wastewater sewer is timely made by the owner, the owner shall have the option of prepaying the amortized value of required connection charges in equal monthly installments over a period not to exceed two years from the date of the initial notification of anticipated availability. The foregoing does not limit the city's ability to provide for a longer installment payment schedule by way of ordinance or resolution. 
(b)  The city commission may, upon a finding of extraordinary circumstances and approval of the health department, if applicable, waive or extend the requirements of subsection (a). To request a waiver or an extension, an applicant must submit a request, accompanied by applicable fees and any additional information that may be required, along with a written justification for the requested waiver or extension to the city engineer. Such request shall be placed on the agenda for review by the city commission within 30 days of receipt of a complete request. The city commission shall have the right to impose conditions including the assessment of fees, on any waiver/extension granted so as to better meet the intent and spirit of the City Code. 
(c)  The city commission may, by ordinance or resolution, create incentive or subsidy programs to encourage or facilitate the abandonment of previously approved and properly functioning septic tanks and the connection of such properties served by septic tanks to the city's wastewater system. Such programs may include, without limitation, wastewater capacity fee, development assistance fee and connection fee waivers and financial or manpower assistance in the abandoning of septic tanks and making the building's plumbing connection to the city's wastewater system. 
(d)  The property owner shall be responsible for making connection to the wastewater system at an appropriate point approved by the city and shall pay all costs associated with making the connection from his building to the system connection point, as well as the connection fee, development assistance fee and the applicable wholesale wastewater capacity charge. 
(e)  All wastewater connections shall be made in compliance with the rules and regulations of the city and the state department of environmental protection and shall be subject to inspection and approval by the city. 
(f)  Effective August 3, 1996, any person or property owner who is required and fails to comply with subsection (a) of this section concerning mandatory connections within the prescribed time period after notification of availability shall be required to pay the monthly base rate for wastewater service whether connected to the city wastewater system or not. Such charge of the monthly base rate for wastewater service is a readiness to serve charge. 
(g)  Upon failure to pay the connection fee, development assistance fee and applicable wholesale wastewater capacity charge which is or would be due upon connection, the city may either: 
(1)  Impose and collect the amounts owed as a non-ad valorem assessment and place it on the owner's property tax bill in accordance with Ordinance No. 01-1574, known as the "Capital Projects Assessment Ordinance," as may be amended, and in doing so (i) the assessment will include the administrative costs related to placing the amounts on the property tax bill, (ii) the amounts outstanding will bear interest at the city's average investment rate for the previous 12 months, and (iii) the amounts will be repaid in a period not to exceed ten years; 
(2)  Add such fees to the monthly utility bill and in the event of nonpayment of such fees on the monthly utility bill, the city may terminate public utilities service as provided for in this article; or 
(3)  Take other collection efforts as may be authorized by this chapter or otherwise by ordinance. 
(Code 1982, § 23-17; Ord. No. 11-1959, 4-4-2011; Ord. No. 16-2090 , § 2, 7-18-2016)  
Sec. 90-33. - Failure to connect. 
In the event that a property owner fails to make a connection to the city sewer system as and when required by section 90-32, in addition to any other provisions of this chapter, the city shall have the right to one or more of the following remedies or actions: 
(1)  Institute code enforcement proceedings and prosecute code violations against the violator and the property owner of the real property where the violation occurs; 
(2)  Institute any appropriate action to bring about compliance or remedy, including but not limited to, instituting an action in court to enjoin violating actions or obtain a mandatory injunction to bring about compliance, in which case the violating person shall be liable to the city for reimbursement of the city's attorneys' fees and costs concerning such action. 
(Ord. No. 16-2090 , § 2, 7-18-2016) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 16-2090 , adopted July 18, 2016, repealed § 90-33 and enacted a new § 90-33 as set out herein. Former § 90-33 pertained to optional wastewater connection authorization and residential properties and derived from the code of 1982.  
Sec. 90-34. - Outside privies prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person or property owner to erect, use or have within the corporate limits of the city any outside privy. (Code 1982, § 23-19)  
Sec. 90-35. - Unlawful connections. 
No person or property owner shall be allowed to connect to the public utilities system without the consent of the city, and the connection with such system shall only be made under the direction and supervision of the city and in accordance with all rules and regulations promulgated by the city for construction standards of such connection. 
(Code 1982, § 23-21)  
Sec. 90-36. - Consent of property owner for installation of service. 
In case the applicant is not the owner of the premises or of the intervening property between the premises and the city's public utilities lines, the applicant shall obtain from the property owner or owners the written, recordable in the public records of the county, easement required for providing public utilities service to the premises. 
(Code 1982, § 23-22)  
Sec. 90-37. - Approval of existing plumbing for connections. 
Whenever it is desirable to connect existing plumbing with the city public utilities system, the person or property owner contemplating doing such work shall notify the city who shall inspect the plumbing and notify the person or property owner of any alterations necessary to place the plumbing in an acceptable condition for connection to the system. 
(Code 1982, § 23-23)  
Sec. 90-38. - Application for service. 
(a)  Generally. All requests for public utilities service must be made in writing on an application provided by the city in person. Applications require government-issued photo identification to be presented. All appropriate fees and/or deposits shall be paid as required by this Code. The owner or authorized occupant of the premises proposed for service must sign the application. Customers who have an outstanding bill at one location shall not be served utilities at a new location until such time that all charges and fees are paid on the previous account. 
(b)  Application to constitute contract; withdrawal. The application for public utilities service becomes a binding contract upon the owner or authorized occupant and the city. Prior to the initiation of service, the owner or authorized occupant may cancel or withdraw the application upon his written request, subject to the restrictions contained in this article. 
(c)  Annexation agreement. If application is made for public utilities service to property located outside the city boundaries that is contiguous to the existing city boundaries or is an enclave within the city boundaries, the property owner shall simultaneously annex the property into the city as a prerequisite to the provision of public utilities service to the property. If application is made for public utilities service to property located outside the city boundaries that is not contiguous to the existing city boundaries, the property owner shall simultaneously execute an agreement to annex the property into the city when the property becomes contiguous to the boundaries. Failure of the property owner to annex the property pursuant to the agreement shall constitute grounds to terminate water and/or wastewater service to the subject property. "Application" for public utilities service shall include any and all applications for water and/or wastewater service, to reactivate prior water and/or wastewater service, or to add additional water and/or wastewater service, including the addition of additional water meters, new fixtures or water and/or wastewater service capacity. 
(d)  Customer agreement. By accepting utility services from the city, customers and property owners agree to comply with and that they are subject to the provisions of this chapter regardless of whether the property connected to utility services is located within or outside the jurisdictional limits of the city. 
(Code 1982, § 23-24; Ord. No. 15-2073 , § 2, 10-19-2015; Ord. No. 17-2121 , § 2, 7-17-2017)  
Sec. 90-39. - Deposit. 
(a)  Each application for public utilities service shall be accompanied by a deposit, which shall be retained by the city and returned to the applicant when service is terminated, or returned as described below, providing all utility bills have been paid as a result of such application and no damage is sustained to city property as a result of such connection. 
(b)  All unpaid bills and damages may be charged against the deposit. Refunds of less than $1.00 will not be paid. 
(c)  In the event the deposit for public utilities service is not sufficient to pay for all unpaid service or damages, a lien may be filed in the public records against any properties for which service has not been paid in full. 
(d)  The deposit shall be returned to the customer after one years of service, provided that all bills for service during the first one-year period are current and have been paid on time. Any delinquencies during the first years shall be cause to retain the deposit until two consecutive years of prompt payment has been achieved. 
(Code 1982, § 23-25; Ord. No. 15-2073 , § 2, 10-19-2015)  
Sec. 90-40. - Connections and meters. 
(a)  Each separate dwelling unit within each building designed or used for residential purposes shall be considered a separate unit for the payment of the water and/or wastewater fees herein established, and a separate connection shall be required for each such unit. Each connection shall be separately metered. 
(b)  Each separate unit within a commercial or industrial use building shall be considered a separate unit for the payment of the water and/or wastewater fees herein established, and a separate connection shall be required for each such unit. Each connection shall be separately metered. 
(c)  Buildings which are combined residential/commercial shall be considered as one commercial connection if they are owner-occupied and no subunit is rented, leased or sold. 
(d)  Existing customers who wish to convert from master meters to individual meters shall be permitted to do so at their own expense. New accounts shall not be permitted to utilize master meters. 
(e)  Residential customers who wish to have an irrigation meter installed or an existing irrigation meter replaced shall pay the connection fee as set forth in appendix B. The city may adopt policies to allow the payment of the connection fee by an existing residential customer over a 12 month period for the installation or replacement of an irrigation meter. 
(Code 1982, § 23-26; Ord. No. 16-2111 , § 1, 1-16-2017)  
Sec. 90-41. - Connection fee. 
(a)  Water. Where installation of a water meter is required, the applicant for water service shall pay a water meter connection fee. 
(b)  Wastewater. Where installation of a wastewater service connection is required, the applicant for wastewater shall pay a wastewater connection fee, except as otherwise provided herein. 
(c)  Connection fees. Connection fees shall be paid at the time the permit for connection is obtained. If the actual cost for materials and labor incurred by the city for each connection should exceed the connection fee, the applicant shall pay any additional costs or install the connections at his own expense in accordance with the City of Longwood Manual of Standards for the Design, Construction and Maintenance of Water and Wastewater Systems. 
(d)  Cost of material and labor. If installation of a water and/or wastewater service line is required, the actual cost for materials and labor incurred by the city shall be paid in addition to the connection fee. 
(Code 1982, § 23-27) 
Cross reference— Rates, Fees and charges, § 90-181.  
Sec. 90-42. - Access to private premises. 
The making of an application under this article shall act to grant the properly authorized agent of the city free access to the premises at all reasonable hours for the purpose of reading, repairing, removing or examining the water meter or water or wastewater service connection, or making such other inspection of the premises as the city may determine necessary to properly maintain and service the public utilities system as it relates to the health and general welfare of the citizens of the city. Further, the accepting of or participation in any incentive or subsidy program that encourages or facilitates the abandonment of a previously approved and properly functioning septic tank and the connection to the city's wastewater system shall serve as a grant to the properly authorized agent of the city free access upon and use of the premises at all reasonable hours to implement the purposes and intent of the incentive or subsidy program. 
(Code 1982, § 23-28; Ord. No. 16-2090 , § 2, 7-18-2016)  
Sec. 90-43. - Maintenance of plumbing. 
The owner of the property connected to the public utilities system shall be responsible for maintaining all plumbing on such property and the pipes leading to and connecting from the structures thereon across the owner's property to the city right-of-way. 
(Code 1982, § 23-29)  
Sec. 90-44. - Reinstallation costs. 
In the event a person or property owner shall cause a change requiring reinstallation of water meters, water meter boxes, any portion of the city wastewater system or any portion of the owner's system subsequent to connection, such person or property owner shall pay the actual cost incurred by the city for each such reinstallation. The actual cost shall include but not be limited to materials and labor. 
(Code 1982, § 23-30)  
Sec. 90-45. - Temporary water service. 
Where water service is requested for temporary construction use at property that has been issued a building permit or where a contractor is working for the city, the city shall provide in accordance with the deposit schedule a three-inch hydrant meter. The meter shall be issued for 60-day time periods. Renewal of 60-day time periods shall be reviewed on a case-by-case basis. Water usage shall be billed at the current city water rate schedule for commercial customers, and the deposit shall be returned when the temporary service is terminated providing all utility bills have been paid and no damage is sustained to city property as a result of such connection. 
(Code 1982, § 23-31)  
Sec. 90-46. - Charges for service. 
(a)  Each residential unit receiving public utilities service shall pay the charges established herein. All units shall be metered. A residential unit shall be: 
(1)  A single-family residential structure; 
(2)  A subunit of a multifamily structure, i.e., apartment unit or duplex rental unit; 
(3)  An individual mobile home; or 
(4)  An individual condominium unit. 
(b)  Each nonresidential unit receiving public utilities service shall pay the charge established herein. All units shall be metered. A nonresidential unit shall be: 
(1)  A structure housing one non-residential operation, enterprise, business or activity; or 
(2)  A subunit of a structure having one or more units for rent or lease or sale. 
(c)  A utility tax of ten percent shall be levied on the water service fees of all customers. 
(d)  In certain commercial establishments, an offset to the monthly wastewater service fee may be obtained (at the sole discretion of the city) if such commercial establishment satisfactorily demonstrates to the city the following: 
(1)  A substantial portion of the commercial establishment's total metered water is not being received by the city wastewater system; and 
(2)  The commercial establishment has installed metering devices approved by the city to track the portion delivered to the city wastewater system. 
(e)  The commercial establishment requesting an offset shall submit monthly readings to the city in order to receive the offset. These readings are subject to verification on a semiannual basis or as deemed necessary by the city. 
(f)  The monthly wastewater service fee for a nonwater system customer shall be determined on a case-by-case basis by resolution or ordinance and may be set as a monthly flat fee. If the customer's water is not supplied and metered by another agency, the customer shall be required to purchase and install at his own expense a metering device approved by the city to track the amount of wastewater delivered to the city wastewater system. Location of the meter shall be approved by the city prior to installation by the customer. It is the responsibility of the customer to ensure that the meter is properly functioning at all times and to repair or replace a malfunctioning meter at his own expense. If the customer fails to repair or replace an improperly functioning meter, the monthly wastewater service fees shall be calculated at the maximum GPD for the establishment's use in accordance with the standards established for calculation of development assistance fees, and wastewater service shall be discontinued until the meter is repaired or replaced. 
(g)  It is the intent of the city to encourage conservation of energy and resources in every way possible, and the city fully supports the development and conversion of residential and commercial wastewater systems to a "gray water" system which is defined as a wastewater system which retains waste from showers, bathtubs, laundries and sinks on site in a drainage field and/or in a recirculating retention tank, and only waste from water closets and garbage disposal units would enter the city wastewater system. As an incentive to developers and homeowners to install or convert to a "gray water" system, wastewater service fees shall be reduced by 25 percent per month and wastewater connection fees shall be reduced by $100.00 for those residential and commercial customers installing or converting to a "gray water" system. 
(h)  A 25 percent surcharge shall be levied on the water and wastewater service fees of all customers located outside the corporate city limits. 
(i)  One meter calibration test for accuracy on the account will be granted without charge per year, additional requests shall be required to pay a service charge as set out in appendix B. If the meter is found to be malfunctioning, this charge will be waived. 
(j)  Each structure or building for which city wastewater system is deemed available for connection to the city wastewater system and is not connected, shall pay the monthly base rate for wastewater service to the city as a readiness to serve charge. Such readiness to serve charge for wastewater service shall commence two months after the end of the period of time for which the structure or building is required to connect to the city wastewater system pursuant to section 90-32. 
(Code 1982, § 23-32; Ord. No. 15-2073 , § 2, 10-19-2015; Ord. No. 16-2090 , § 2, 7-18-2016; Ord. No. 17-2121 , § 3, 7-17-2017)  
Sec. 90-47. - Exceptions. 
(a)  No public utilities service shall be furnished free of charge. Any person or property owner who uses the city public utilities system shall pay the rates fixed by this article, except as provided for below: 
(1)  A customer who experiences a leak or excessive usage of city water may apply for a credit adjustment. 
(2)  The customer's account must have all outstanding charges paid in full and must submit an application to the city to be considered for a credit adjustment. 
(3)  The city shall review the customer's previous 12-month consumption history to determine the average water consumption, and shall provide a credit adjustment equal to the difference between the excessive consumption and the average consumption as calculated for the previous 12 months. If the customer's wastewater bill, based on volumetric charges, is excessive due to the water consumed by the leak or excessive use, the city shall provide an adjustment equal to the difference between the excessive bill and the customer's average wastewater bill for the previous 12 months. 
(4)  If the customer does not have a 12-month history at the same address where the leak or excessive use occurred, standard gallons per day as prescribed in this Code shall be used to calculate the 12-month average. 
(5)  A customer shall be entitled to a credit adjustment per verifiable occurrence up to two consecutive billing cycles per a 12-month period. 
(6)  A customer may also apply for a sewer credit adjustment for a pool fill once every year of the account. A signed and dated application must be submitted showing the date(s) of fill and the gallons used to fill the pool. The reduction of sewer charges will be calculated based on the amount of water used to fill the pool multiplied by the sewer usage rate. 
(b)  In the event the city or any department, agency or instrumentality thereof shall avail itself of the facilities or services provided by the public utilities system, the rates, fees and charges applicable to such services shall be as provided in this article. Such charges shall be paid as they accrue, and the city shall transfer to the public utilities fund sufficient sums to pay such charges. The revenues so received shall be deemed to be revenues derived from the operation of the public utilities system, and shall be deposited and accounted for in the same manner as other revenues derived from the operation of such system. 
(Code 1982, § 23-33; Ord. No. 15-2073 , § 2, 10-19-2015)  
Sec. 90-48. - Billing. 
Bills for public utilities service are rendered each month and are due and payable within 15 days of the date of the bill. Unpaid bills shall be considered delinquent on the 16th day after the date of bill, and late charges as set forth in section 90-49 are applied at that time. Payment may be made to the city in person during regular office hours, by phone, through automatic bank draft, online payments, or by mail. The maximum charge allowed by Florida Statutes shall be levied for each payment made with a check returned to the city due to insufficient funds. 
(Code 1982, § 23-34; Ord. No. 15-2073 , § 2, 10-19-2015)  
Sec. 90-49. - Late charges; discontinuance of service; turn-on/turnoff charges. 
The city reserves the right to levy a late charge of the greater of ten percent of the balance due or a charge as set out in appendix B for nonpayment of utility bills. This charge shall be automatically added to each bill in arrears without notice to the customer. As a courtesy and in the city's discretion, a late fee may be waived once in a 12-month period. Upon failure by the customer to pay such late charge with all charges in arrears seven business days of the date the late fee is assessed, the city may immediately discontinue furnishing public utilities service until the late charge, reconnection charge and all bills in arrears have been paid in full. 
(Code 1982, § 23-35; Ord. No. 15-2073 , § 2, 10-19-2015)  
Sec. 90-50. - Charge for change in service location. 
All customers requesting a change of service from one location within the city or its service area to another location within the city or its service area shall be charged the turn-on charge. 
(Code 1982, § 23-36)  
Sec. 90-51. - Service charge after hours. 
All customers requesting service after regular working hours or on weekends or city holidays, shall be charged a service charge as provided in the fee schedule in appendix B or actual costs, including, but not limited, to materials and labor, whichever amount shall be greater. Disconnections for nonpayment requiring subsequent turn on after 4:00 p.m. will be charged an additional $50.00. 
(Code 1982, § 23-37; Ord. No. 17-2121 , § 4, 7-17-2017)  
Sec. 90-52. - Resale of water. 
Water supplied to customers shall not be resold. 
(Code 1982, § 23-38)  
Sec. 90-53. - Damaging system. 
It shall be unlawful for any person or property owner, unless expressly authorized in writing by the city, to tamper with, work on, connect to or in any way alter or damage any part of the public utilities system or to remove any seal, tag or notice placed upon any water meter. Tampering or work shall include but not be limited to unauthorized operation of city-owned valves, fire hydrants, meter tampering, straightlines, unauthorized taps, line ruptures and/or illegal dumping. A tamper fine, as set forth in appendix B, and the cost of repairing the damages will be levied against and billed to the owner of the property for any violation of this section. 
(Code 1982, § 23-39; Ord. No. 15-2073 , § 2, 10-19-2015)  
Sec. 90-54. - Line locations; notification to city prior to digging. 
(a)  Forty-eight hours prior to commencing any digging, excavation, construction or utility installation work, all persons and property owners shall be required to provide written notification to the city identifying the work to be conducted and the location of the proposed work. 
(b)  A duly authorized representative of the city must be present on the site prior to commencement of digging, excavation, construction or utility installation for the purpose of locating city utility lines. 
(c)  Written notification may be reduced in case of emergency, as determined by the city, provided that the property owner or applicant shall bear all costs incurred by the city in meeting the expedited work schedule. 
(Code 1982, § 23-40)  
Sec. 90-55. - Extension of service lines. 
(a)  Any person or property owner requesting public utilities service, where such request requires extension of existing service lines, shall be liable to pay to the city the costs of said extension, including but not limited to costs of all materials, labor and fire hydrants. 
(b)  In the alternative, any person or property owner may have a qualified contractor install such extension, providing, however, that installation shall be subject to inspection and approval by the city. In such cases, service shall not commence until approval in writing is obtained. 
(c)  As a condition of allowing a qualified contractor to perform installation or extension of service lines, the city manager or his/her designee shall have the right to require the contractor to submit proof of insurance, obtain applicable permits, to indemnify and hold the city and its officials, officers, employees and agents harmless concerning contractor's work and activities, and to impose other reasonable requirements upon the contractor for the protection of the city, the public, and real and personal property. 
(d)  Minimum construction standards for all development activity within the city or development to be served by city facilities shall be as outlined in the City of Longwood Manual of Standards for the Design, Construction and Maintenance of Water and Wastewater Systems. 
(Code 1982, § 23-41; Ord. No. 15-2073 , § 2, 10-19-2015)  
Sec. 90-56. - Water conservation rebate program. 
(a)  Program description. In an effort to assist residents and businesses with increasing water cost, the city is creating the water conservation rebate program. While most residents and businesses will simply appreciate lower water bills, the impact of reducing water consumption for a significant number of homes and businesses has far reaching environmental and financial benefits. Water conservation reduces the demand for water from the Floridan Aquifer and reduces the amount of chemicals and energy needed for the production of potable water. It is easy to see the ripple effect created by making simple improvements at your home or business to reduce water consumption. 
The program provides residents and businesses a financial incentive of $50.00 to $150.00 to install water conserving plumbing fixtures and irrigation controls in their homes or businesses. The rebate is available to any resident or business located in the city to reduce water consumption in their home or business. 
(b)  Eligible improvements and rebate criteria. The following is a list of improvements and eligibility requirements that will qualify for a rebate under this program: 
(1)  Toilets—WaterSense&reg; only (1.28 gallons per flush or less): 
a.  A rebate of $100.00 per toilet for the replacement of existing 3.5 to seven gallons per flush (GPF) toilets. 
b.  Toilets are limited to WaterSense&reg; only 1.28 gallons per flush or less. 
c.  Limit two toilets per household or business within the city limits. 
(2)  Rain sensors—All: 
a.  A rebate of $50.00 per household or business to add or replace the rain sensor connect to an existing irrigation system. 
b.  Limit one rain sensor per household or business every five years. 
c.  For residents and businesses within the city limits only. 
(3)  Irrigation controllers with a moisture sensing device: 
a.  A rebate of $150.00 per household or business to add an irrigation controller that uses "smart" irrigation control technology. For a complete list, visit the WaterSense website. 
b.  Limit one rain sensor per household or business every five years. 
c.  For residents and businesses within the city limits only. 
(c)  Application and allocation process. 
(1)  The applicant or a licensed contractor can perform the installation of the toilet or irrigation control. A building permit is not required. 
(2)  The rebate is for the cost of equipment only. It does not apply to installation cost or sales taxes. 
(3)  A complete application package shall be submitted to the community development services department. The application shall include a description of the project, product descriptions and/or specifications necessary to provide proof of eligibility, before and after photos, and proof of purchase from the retailer/supplier or the final invoice from the contractor who performed the work. 
(4)  Staff will review the application for completeness and eligibility. Eligible applications will be processed for payment after the application is deemed complete. Applications are taken on a first come first serve basis. The city reserves the right to discontinue or amend the program at any time. 
(Res. No. 15-1378 , § I(Exh. A), 8-3-2015)  
Secs. 90-57—90-80. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - CROSS CONNECTION CONTROL 
 
Sec. 90-81. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Air gap separation means the unobstructed vertical distance through the free atmosphere between the lowest opening from any pipe or faucet supplying water to a tank, plumbing fixture or other device and the flood level rim of the receptacle and shall be at least double the diameter of the supply pipe, measured vertically above the flood level rim of the vessel. In no case shall the gap be less than one inch. 
Auxiliary supply means any water source or system, other than the public water supply, that may be available in the building or premises. 
Backflow means the flow, in other than the intended direction of flow, of any foreign liquids, gases or substances into the distribution system of a public water supply. 
Backflow prevention device means an assembly composed of two single, independently acting, check valves, including tightly closing shutoff valves, located at each end of the assembly and suitable connections for testing the watertightness of each check valve. 
Back pressure means backflow caused by a pump, elevated tank, boiler or other means that could create pressure within the system greater than the supply pressure. 
Back siphonage means a form of backflow due to a negative or subatmospheric pressure within a water system. 
Cross connection means any physical arrangement whereby a public water supply is connected, directly or indirectly, with any other water supply system, sewer, drain, conduit, pool, storage reservoir, plumbing fixture, or other device which contains, or may contain, contaminated water, sewage, or other waste or liquid of unknown or unsafe quality which may be capable of imparting contamination to the public water supply as a result of backflow, bypass arrangements, jumper connections, removable sections, swivel or changeover devices, and other temporary or permanent devices through which, or because of which, backflow could occur are considered to be cross connections. 
Public water supply means any system or water supply intended or used for consumption or other domestic uses including source, treatment, storage, transmission and distribution facilities where water is furnished to any community, collection or number of individuals or is made available to the public for human consumption or domestic use. 
Reduced pressure principle backflow prevention device means a device incorporating two or more check valves and an automatically operating differential relief valve located between the two check valves, two shutoff valves, and equipped with the necessary appurtenances for testing. The device shall operate to maintain the pressure in the zone between the two check valves, less than the pressure on the public water supply side of the device. At cessation of normal flow, the pressure between the check valves shall be less than the supply pressure. In case of leakage of either check valve, the differential relief valve shall operate to maintain this reduced pressure by discharging to the atmosphere. When the inlet pressure is two pounds per square inch or less, the relief valve shall open to the atmosphere, thereby providing an air gap in the device. 
(Code 1982, § 23-42) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 90-82. - Implementation of cross connection control program 
The city is hereby directed to implement this program by taking any and all appropriate action necessary and/or adopting any and all necessary rules and regulations to comply with state and federal regulations. The city shall recognize the varying degrees of hazard and apply the principle that the degree of protection shall be commensurate with the degree of hazard. 
(Code 1982, § 23-43)  
Sec. 90-83. - Cross connections prohibited. 
(a)  All cross connections, whether or not such cross connections are controlled by automatic devices such as check valves or by hand-operated mechanisms such as gate valves or stop cocks, are hereby prohibited. 
(b)  Failure on the part of the person to discontinue the use of any and all cross connections and to physically separate such cross connections shall be sufficient cause for the discontinuance of public water service to the premises on which the cross connection exists. 
(Code 1982, § 23-44)  
Sec. 90-84. - Inspections. 
The city may make periodic inspections of premises served by the water supply to check for the presence of cross connections. Any cross connections found in such inspection shall be ordered removed by the city. If an immediate hazard to health is caused by the cross connection, water service to the premises shall be discontinued until it is verified that the cross connection has been removed. 
(Code 1982, § 23-45)  
Sec. 90-85. - Backflow prevention device installation; type; location; inspection; testing; failure to comply. 
(a)  Installation required. Backflow prevention devices shall be installed at the service connection or within any premises where, in the judgment of the city, the nature and extent of the activities on the premises, or the materials used in connection with the activities or materials stored in the premises, would present an immediate and dangerous hazard to health should a cross connection occur, even though such cross connection does not exist at the time the backflow prevention device is required to be installed. This shall include but not be limited to the following situations: 
(1)  Premises having an auxiliary water supply, unless the quality of the auxiliary supply is in compliance with applicable federal laws and is acceptable to the city. 
(2)  Premises having internal cross connections that are not correctable, or intricate plumbing arrangements which make it impractical to ascertain whether or not cross connections exist. 
(3)  Premises where entry is restricted so that inspections for cross connections cannot be made with sufficient frequency or at sufficiently short notice to assure that cross connections do not exist. 
(4)  Premises having a repeated history of cross connections being established or reestablished. 
(5)  Premises on which any substance is handled under pressure so as to permit entry into the public water supply, or where cross connections could be reasonably expected to occur. This shall include the handling of process waters and cooling waters. 
(6)  Premises where materials of a toxic nature are handled such that if backsiphonage should occur, a serious health hazard may result. 
(7)  The following types of facilities shall fall into one of the above categories where a backflow prevention device is required to protect the public water supply. A backflow prevention device shall be installed at these facilities: 
Hospitals, mortuaries, clinics (doctors' offices); 
Animal hospitals; 
Laboratories; 
Piers and docks; 
Schools; 
Wastewater treatment plants, lift stations; 
Food or beverage processing plants; 
Metal-plating industries; 
Petroleum processing plants or nuclear reactors; 
Nurseries; 
Landscape irrigation systems; 
Other facilities specified by the city. 
(b)  Type. The type of protection device shall be determined by the city and shall depend on the degree of hazard which exists. 
(c)  Health or system hazard. An air gap separation or a reduced pressure principle backflow prevention device shall be installed where the water supply may be contaminated with sewage, industrial waste of a toxic nature or other contaminant which would cause a health or system hazard. 
(d)  Objectionable but not hazardous. In the case of a substance which may be objectionable, but not hazardous to health, a double check valve assembly, airgap separation or a reduced pressure principle backflow prevention device shall be installed. 
(e)  Location. Backflow prevention devices shall be installed at the meter or at a location designated by the city. The device shall be located so as to be readily accessible for maintenance and testing and where no part of the device shall be submerged or buried below ground level unless in a watertight container. 
(f)  Testing. Backflow prevention devices shall be installed by the owners of the premises at no expense to the city and shall be tested and certified by a certified backflow technician. Required testing may be conducted by the city for the actual cost of service provided. 
(g)  Approved devices. Any protective devices required in this section shall be a model approved by the city. A backflow prevention device shall be approved if it has successfully passed a performance test of the University of Southern California Engineering Center or other testing laboratories satisfactory to the city. 
(h)  Inspection, testing, repairs. Residential and nonresidential backflow prevention devices shall be annually inspected, tested and certified to the city at the customer's expense. The devices shall be repaired, overhauled or replaced at the customer's expense whenever they are found to be defective. Inspection, tests and repair records shall be kept by the city at the customer's expense. 
(i)  Failure to comply. Failure of the customer to cooperate in the installation, maintenance, testing or inspection of backflow prevention devices required in this section shall be grounds for the termination of water service to the premises. 
(Code 1982, § 23-46)  
Sec. 90-86. - Enforcement, remedies, penalties for violations. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of all officers and employees of the city to assist in the enforcement of this program by reporting seeming violations. 
(b)  In case any consumer uses a water system in violation of the program, any proper officials of the city or its duly authorized representatives, in addition to other remedies, may institute any appropriate action or proceedings to prevent such unlawful use or other violations, to restrain, correct or abate such violations. Each day such violation continues shall constitute a separate violation. 
(c)  The owner or general agent of a building or premises where a violation of any provision of this program has been committed or still exists, or lessee or tenant of the entire building or entire premises where such a violation has been committed or shall exist, or at the general agent or any person who commits, takes part in, or assists in any such violations, or who maintains any building or premises in which any such violation shall exist, shall be guilty of a first degree misdemeanor. 
(d)  In interpreting and applying the provisions of this program these shall be held to be the minimum requirements for the promotion of public health, safety, convenience, comfort, prosperity and general welfare. 
(Code 1982, § 23-47)  
Secs. 90-87—90-110. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - DEVELOPMENT ASSISTANCE FEES 
 
Sec. 90-111. - Definitions. 
Unless specifically defined in this section, words or phrases used in this section shall be interpreted to give this section its most reasonable application, consistent with state and federal law and other city regulations. The following words and phrases shall have the following meanings unless the context requires otherwise: 
City rate resolutions and ordinances means all resolutions and ordinances, either currently in effect or to be adopted in the future, by the commission or its successors, which establish and fix rates, fees and charges for the Longwood Public Utilities System. 
Collection facilities means the lines, pipes, meters and appurtenant equipment used to collect sewage from the building sewer and carry it to the transmission facilities. 
Commission means the city commission of Longwood, Florida, a political subdivision of the state. 
Effluent disposal facilities means those wastewater facilities necessary to detain transmit, store, and dispose of wastewater previously treated at treatment facilities. 
GPD means gallons per day on an annual average basis. 
Longwood Public Utilities System means all facilities and interests in real and personal property owned, operated, managed or controlled by the city now and in the future and used to provide public utilities service to existing and future customers within the service area of the city. 
Public utilities system means the water and/or wastewater systems. 
Service capacity means an amount of water or wastewater measured in GPD. 
Sewage or wastewater means a combination of the water-carried wastes from residences, businesses buildings, institutions, industrial establishments and other customers of the city wastewater system, together with such ground water, surface water and stormwater as may be present. 
Transmission facilities means those lines, pipes, force mains, pumps, meters and appurtenant equipment used to transmit sewage from the collection facilities to the headworks of the treatment facilities as defined and determined by the city. 
Treatment facilities means those facilities used to treat and filter wastewater prior to effluent disposal. Treatment facilities do not include any portions of the collection facilities, transmission facilities or effluent disposal facilities. 
Wastewater facilities means all wastewater collection, transmission, treatment and effluent disposal facilities, including all interceptors, lines, pipes, meters, couplings, pumps, force mains and appurtenant equipment necessary to provide wastewater service capacity. 
Wholesale wastewater capacity charge means the amount collected by a third party, on a GPD basis, for capacity allocation at a third party wastewater treatment plant. 
(Code 1982, § 23-48(a)) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 90-112. - Determination of service capacity. 
(a)  For purposes of calculating and imposing city water and/or wastewater development assistance fees, service capacity shall be calculated and imposed as follows:

(b)  For all establishments not listed above, service capacity shall be determined by multiplying the number of fixture units, as published in the Florida Building Code, by 25 GPD per fixture unit. 
(c)  In no event shall the total service capacity used to calculate a development assistance fee for any separate nonresidential establishment be less than 300 GPD. 
(d)  If an applicant for service capacity within any of the categories set forth above can demonstrate to the city that the actual usage will be less than 80 percent of the service capacity assigned to such establishment as set forth above, the city may determine (at its sole discretion), based on actual usage, anticipated usage, peak load requirements, or any combination of the foregoing, using acceptable engineering standards, that a different or lesser service capacity value applies. If the city determines that actual usage will be greater than the service capacity assigned to such establishment as set forth above, the city may determine, based on actual usage, anticipated usage, peak load requirements, or any combination of the foregoing, using acceptable engineering standards, that a different or greater service capacity value applies. 
(Code 1982, § 23-48(b))  
Sec. 90-113. - Wastewater development assistance fee and connection fee; applicability. 
The development assistance fee and the connection fee as set forth above shall be paid by those new customers who connect to the city wastewater system except as follows: 
(1)  Those customers who connect to interim, temporary "package" facilities or septic tanks, for which, as determined by the city, there is no existing plan or concept to disconnect the interim facilities and transmit such flows to treatment facilities owned, operated or participated in by the city, shall be exempt from the development assistance fee and the connection fee. 
(2)  Those customers who connect to interim wastewater facilities or interim septic tanks for which, as determined by the city, there is an existing plan or concept to disconnect such interim facilities and connect the customers thereof to areawide treatment facilities owned, operated or participated in by the city, shall pay all applicable development assistance fees and connection fees. If, after payment is received, the city should determine that the interim facilities will not be disconnected and the customers thereof will not be connected to areawide treatment facilities, then upon making such determination, the payment shall be released and returned to the customer. 
(3)  The city may exempt any customer from the payment of any portion of the development assistance fee to the extent that the city accepts an easement, a contribution in aid of construction, or other valuable consideration having a value of not less than the portion of the development assistance fee being exempted. 
(Code 1982, § 23-48(c))  
Sec. 90-114. - Payment of development assistance fees and connection fees. 
(a)  All development assistance fees, wholesale capacity charges and connection fees shall be paid prior to the issuance of a building permit or prior to processing an application with the state department of environmental protection, where applicable, for a structure or structures to be served by the city public utilities system, or such other time as may be specified provided by city resolution or ordinance. 
(b)  Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, upon connection each existing building owner shall be entitled to prepay the development assistance fees, wholesale capacity charges and connection fees. Unless these amounts are prepaid, the city will impose and collect assessments for the amounts in accordance with Ordinance No. 01-1574, known as the "Capital Project Assessment Ordinance." The owner shall fill out an application and sign a certificate of acknowledgement with the city which acknowledges that (i) the city will impose and collect the amounts owed as a non-ad valorem assessment and place it on the owner's property tax bill, (ii) the assessment will include the administrative costs related to placing the amounts on the property tax bill, (iii) the amounts outstanding will bear interest at the city's average investment rate for the previous 12 months, and (iv) the amounts will be repaid in a period not to exceed ten years. 
(c)  Upon connection, each existing building owner that has a Department of Revenue Code of 70-79 on such date shall be entitled to prepay their development assistance fees, wholesale capacity charges and connection fees. Unless these amounts are prepaid, the city will impose and collect assessments for the amounts in accordance with the Capital Project Assessment Ordinance. The owner shall fill out an application and sign a certificate of acknowledgment with the city which acknowledges that (i) the city will impose and collect the amounts owed as a non-ad valorem assessment and place it on the owner's property tax bill, (ii) the assessment will include the administrative costs related to placing the amounts on the property tax bill, (iii) the amounts outstanding will not bear interest, and (iv) the amounts will be repaid in a period not to exceed 15 years. 
(Code 1982, § 23-48(d))  
Sec. 90-115. - Responsibility for collection and transmission costs. 
In addition to the development assistance fees and connection fees, the customer shall either provide, or pay all capital costs (including land costs) of, the required capital improvements for the extension of distribution facilities from the city's distribution mains to the boundaries of the property owned by the customer, the collection of wastewater within the boundaries of the property owned by the customer to which the city intends to provide service, and the transmission of wastewater from those boundaries to the city's transmission mains or collection lines prior to connection to treatment facilities. The city shall allow the customer to connect to the water distribution mains, the wastewater transmission mains or wastewater collection lines at the nearest feasible point as determined by the city. 
(Code 1982, § 23-48(e))  
Sec. 90-116. - State department of environmental protection permits. 
(a)  Applications for service capacity may require a permit from the state department of environmental protection subsequent to processing of the application by the city and reservation of service capacity. If required, it shall be the responsibility of the applicant to obtain this permit from the state department of environmental protection and provide any additional information needed. The applicant has 180 calendar days from the date of service capacity reservation by the city to obtain the required state department of environmental protection permit or be subject to the recapture provisions of this Code. Should the department refuse to issue the permit, or modify the service capacity allocation or number of developmental units, it shall be incumbent upon the applicant to notify the city to facilitate refunds or recalculation of the development assistance fee and requisite revisions to city records. No refunds of service capacity allocation shall be given except in the form of credits to be applied to the same property to which they were originally allocated. 
(b)  Permits issued by the state department of environmental protection have an expiration date of one year from the date of issuance. During the life of the permit, the applicant must construct the system in accordance with the approved permitted plans. Should the permit expire and the construction of the system not be completed, the city may, subject to state department of environmental protection approval, agree to an extension of the permit, subject further to a satisfactory demonstration that construction of the system has been initiated and is being actively prosecuted. If construction of the system has not been initiated or is not being actively prosecuted, the city may rescind its certification of the project, and the applicant shall be subject to the service capacity recapture provision of this Code. 
(Code 1982, § 23-48(f))  
Sec. 90-117. - Capacity limitations. 
(a)  An upper limit of 50,000 GPD per application shall apply to service capacity allocations. Exceptions to the 50,000 GPD limit per application may be obtained for large commercial or multifamily developments that are under "one roof" and which cannot practically be phased or reduced in scope without affecting the project's viability, subject to review and approval of the city. Projects authorized prior to December 1, 1989, with service capacity allocations, based on payment of a development assistance fee, in excess of the above limitation shall continue to be honored, subject to compliance with other applicable provisions of this code. 
(b)  In reserving and allocating service capacity for applications submitted to the city, the allocation factors shown above shall be utilized. Any change in use which results in the need for additional service capacity shall require the applicant to apply for and pay for such additional service capacity. 
(Code 1982, § 23-48(g))  
Sec. 90-118. - Capacity reservation or allocation recapture procedures. 
(a)  Having obtained a service capacity reservation or allocation, the reservation or allocation shall be used and applied only with respect to the property for which the application for service capacity has been made and approved. The applicant is not otherwise permitted to sell, lease, sublet, assign, lend or transfer a service capacity reservation or allocation (or portion thereof) to any other property than that for which it was originally approved. 
(b)  To ensure maximum beneficial utilization of the available service capacity, the city reserves the right to recapture service capacity reservations or allocations, or parts thereof, for failure of the applicant to meet conditions of authorization or to responsibly and timely prosecute the development of the project for which service capacity was obtained. The city's sole responsibility in recapturing previously reserved or allocated service capacity, or parts thereof, shall be to refund 80 percent of the equivalent development assistance fee, with the remaining 20 percent retained by the city in addition to the application fee. 
(c)  The city may institute the recapture of reserved or allocated service capacity under the following circumstances: 
(1)  Failure to obtain a state department of environmental protection permit, if required, within 180 calendar days following service capacity reservation. 
(2)  Failure to obtain requisite building permits and pay the remainder of the wastewater development assistance fee within 12 months following service capacity reservation. 
(3)  Failure to obtain appropriate land use designation and platting (as appropriate) of the development within 12 months of service capacity reservation. Applications forfeited for this reason shall be given 100 percent reimbursement for development assistance fees. 
(4)  Failure to provide final building plans for commercial or other developments, for which service capacity reservation was based on preliminary estimates, with 12 months of service capacity reservation. 
(5)  Failure to obtain and comply with state department of environmental protection permit requirements within the life of the permit, including permit extensions. 
(6)  Violation of the prohibition against transfer of a service capacity reservation or allocation, or failure to provide requisite notification to the city of any change in ownership of the property for which a reservation or allocation has been obtained. 
(7)  Failure of those applicants who have previously obtained service capacity allocations in the existing system to pay outstanding development assistance fees and complete actions leading to utilization of such service capacity allocation within the time frames provided elsewhere in city codes. 
(8)  Failure to comply with requirements of the city public utilities service policy and codes, as may be amended from time to time. 
(d)  The city shall give the applicant, or successor in interest according to city records, 30 calendar days written notice of its intent to recapture reserved or allocated service capacity as provided above. The notice shall contain the basis for the intended recapture and state what corrective action is required to preserve the service capacity reservation or allocation. During the 30-day period, the applicant may take corrective action to comply with the requirements of the policy. If an applicant is unable to complete the corrective action within the 30-day period, a request for an extension to re-recapture date may be submitted to the city. The request for an extension shall be reviewed by the city and, if approved, one extension may be granted, subject to the applicant paying the development assistance fee differential (prevailing total fees due less amount already paid) at the time of and as a condition of obtaining a building permit. Any staff decision regarding the recapture of service capacity, as provided in the policy, may be appealed to the city commission. 
(Code 1982, § 23-48(h))  
Sec. 90-119. - Development assistance fees subject to change. 
Development assistance fees may be changed at any time, subject to approval by the city commission. Applicants who have secured and paid in full for service capacity shall not be subject to such fee revisions, provided that they are in compliance with the City Code. Applicants who have reserved service capacity prior to December 1, 1989, and who have outstanding development assistance fee obligations shall pay at current total fee rates. In special cases, the city commission may elect to finance infrastructure improvements through user fees to be calculated on a pro rata basis of daily flow. 
(Code 1982, § 23-48(i))  
Sec. 90-120. - City/developer cost sharing. 
(a)  It is the intent of the city to require all new development within the city service area to connect, at the owner or developer of said development's expense, to the city public utilities system where available. At times, this may require extensive construction, installation and extension of utility lines from their current terminus to the new development and along the development's frontage adjacent to or within public rights-of-way, at the expense of the owner or developer of said development. The development may, if determined by the city to be necessary, be required to grant the city utility easements of a reasonable width and length to accommodate the perpetual operation, maintenance, repair and replacement of said utility lines over, under and through a portion of the property being developed. Except for upsizing costs reimbursement described in subsection (b), the owner shall not be entitled to development assistance fees credits, connection fees credits, wholesale capacity charges credits, or any other compensation for the installation of utility lines required by this chapter. As used in this section, the term "utility lines" shall mean all potable water, reclaimed water and sanitary sewer main lines, meters, valves, lift stations, manholes, and other appurtenances thereto required to be installed in conformance with the city's public utilities master plan. 
(b)  The owner or developer shall cause the construction of the utility lines required to serve the development in accordance with the city public utilities master plan and the City of Longwood Manual of Standards for the Design, Construction and Maintenance of Water and Wastewater Systems as determined by the city. If any public utilities system facilities identified or required in the master plan exceed those required for the individual development, the city, at its option, shall determine and require upsizing of utility lines to meet those identified facilities in the master plan. The city shall pay the reasonable cost difference between the individual development utility lines requirements and the upsizing requirements of the city within 60 days after completion, inspection and acceptance for the installation of the upsizing as described in subsection (c) and the city's approval of the reasonable cost difference. All public utilities lines, utility system additions, improvements and upsizing shall become property of the city upon final inspection and approval by the city as evidenced by a certificate of completion and issuance of a final clearance by the state department of environmental protection, if required. The owner's or developer's licensed civil engineer shall calculate the cost difference of the facilities. This cost difference shall be subject to review, modification and approval by the city. Construction variations to the master plan shall require approval of the city and shall only be allowed when an extreme hardship can be demonstrated. 
(c)  Completion of utilities. Upon completion of the installation of the utility lines, the owner or developer of the development shall have the city inspect such improvements and obtain a certificate of completion from the city for the utility lines. As a condition precedent to receiving a certificate of completion for such utility lines, owner or developer shall cause the execution and delivery to the city of the following: 
(1)  A final clearance for the utility lines by the state department of environmental protection, if required; 
(2)  Invoices for construction costs of the utility lines; 
(3)  For utility lines construction costs exceeding $100,000.00, unless waived by written agreement with the city, a one-year maintenance bond or irrevocable letter of credit in an amount equal to 20 percent of the utility lines construction costs (construction cost amount to be approved by city engineer) guaranteeing the proper construction, functioning and maintenance of the utility lines for a one-year period following the city's issuance of a certificate of completion, such being in a form approved by the city attorney; 
(4)  A bill of sale conveying the utility lines to the city with an assignment of any associated warranties; 
(5)  A release or waiver of liens from all contractors, subcontractors, materialmen and laborers involved in the installation of the utility lines; and 
(6)  The design engineer of record certification to the city that the utility lines have been completed in accordance with approved design plans. 
No certificates of occupancy shall be issued for any part of the development until issuance of a certificate of completion by the city and completion of subsections (1)—(6) above. The utility lines shall be deemed completed upon owner or developer satisfying all of the conditions of this subsection (c). 
(Code 1982, § 23-48(j); Ord. No. 15-2073 , § 2, 10-19-2015)  
Sec. 90-121. - Agreements. 
(a)  The city shall have the authority to enter into agreements with owners and developers of property to address the timing of payments for development assistance fees, connection fees, and wholesale capacity charges, or any combination thereof, that may differ from the requirements of this chapter if determined to be in the best interest of city, which may include by way of example, for economic development purposes or to encourage desired development. 
(b)  The city shall have the authority to enter into and may require owners and developers to execute an agreement to address the requirements of this article concerning the construction, installation and extension of utility lines, oversizing requirements, and cost sharing for utility improvements. 
(Ord. No. 15-2073 , § 2, 10-19-2015)  
Sec. 90-122. - Collection of past due development assistance fees, connection fees, wholesale capacity charges. 
In the event that development assistance fees, connection fees, wholesale capacity charges, or any portion or combination thereof, are not paid when due for any reason, including by mistake or inadvertence, the city shall have the right to proceed to collect such fees and charges as follows: 
(1)  The city shall serve, by certified mail-return receipt requested and regular U.S. Mail, a notice of nonpayment upon the building permit applicant at the address set forth in the building permit application, and then current owner of the property based on the ownership information appearing on the Seminole County Property Appraiser website. Provided the city sends the notice of nonpayment, the applicant's and/or current owner's failure to receive delivery of such notice of nonpayment shall not invalidate or otherwise impact the city's ability to collect the outstanding amount owed and place and foreclose a notice of lien against the applicable property. 
(2)  The notice of nonpayment shall contain: 
a.  A description of the property; 
b.  Advise the applicant and the property owner of the amount due and the fee and/or charges that were not paid; and 
c.  Advise that in the event the fees and/or charges are not paid within 30 calendar days from the date of the notice of nonpayment, that a notice of lien against the applicable property for which the building permit was secured may be recorded in the official records of the county and such notice of lien may be foreclosed upon by the city to collect the outstanding sums owed plus accrued interest and attorneys' fees and other collection expenses. 
(3)  If the amount set forth in the notice of nonpayment is not paid within 30 days from the date of the notice of nonpayment, then: 
a.  The outstanding balance owed to the city shall accrue interest at the rate of 15 percent per annum until such amount is paid in full; 
b.  The city may proceed to record a notice of lien against the applicable property in the official records of the county. Once recorded, the notice of lien shall constitute a lien against the property described therein; and 
c.  A copy of the notice of lien shall be served by U.S. Mail to the applicant and the property owner at the same addresses as set forth in subsection (1) above. 
(4)  After the expiration of 60 days from the date of recording of the notice of lien, a suit may be filed to foreclose said lien. Such foreclosure proceedings shall be instituted and prosecuted in conformity with the procedures for the foreclosure of liens as set forth in the Florida Statutes. The city shall also have the right to bring an action for monetary judgment to collect past due amounts owed. 
(5)  The owner shall be responsible for and the city shall be entitled to reimbursement for the payment of all collection expenses and costs, including attorneys' fees and litigation costs and recording and filing fees, incurred by the city in the collection of fees and charges, filing of liens and in actions to foreclose such liens or actions for a monetary judgment. 
(6)  If development assistance fees, connection fees, wholesale capacity charges, or any portion or combination thereof, have not been paid when due, the city shall have the right to, without notice, immediately withhold the issuance of and not process for review any certificate of occupancy, development permit or development order applications associated with the development and property at issue and may issue and enforce a stop work order on construction associated with the development and property at issue until such fees and charges and the city's associated collection costs are paid in full. 
(7)  The collection and enforcement procedures set forth in this section shall be cumulative with, supplemental to and in addition to, any applicable procedures provided in any other ordinance or administrative regulations of the city, any applicable law or administrative regulation of the state, or any agreement. Failure of the city to follow the procedure set forth in this section shall not constitute a waiver of its rights to proceed under any other ordinances or administrative regulations of the city, any applicable law or administrative regulation of the state, or any agreement. 
(Ord. No. 15-2073 , § 2, 10-19-2015)  
Secs. 90-123—90-150. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - VIOLATIONS 
 
Sec. 90-151. - Penalties for violation. 
(a)  If any person violates any of the provisions of this chapter or any order or permit issued under this chapter, the city may commence an action for appropriate legal and/or equitable relief in the circuit court of the county. 
(1)  Injunctive relief. Whenever any person has violated or continues to violate the provisions of this chapter or any order or permit issued hereunder, the city may petition the circuit court for the issuance of a preliminary and/or permanent injunction which restrains or compels the activities on the part of the violator. 
(2)  Civil penalties. 
a.  Any person who has violated or continues to violate the provisions of this chapter or any order or permit issued hereunder, shall be liable to the city for a civil penalty of not more than $10,000.00 plus actual damages incurred by the city per violation, per day, for as long as the violation continues. In addition to the above-described penalty and damages, the city shall be entitled to recover reasonable attorney's fees, court costs, and other expenses associated with enforcement activities including sampling/monitoring expenses. 
b.  The city shall initiate legal proceedings in the circuit court to impose, assess and recover such sums. In determining the amount of liability, the court shall take into account all relevant circumstances, including, but not limited to, the extent of harm caused by the violation, the magnitude and duration of the violation, any economic benefit gained through the violation, corrective actions by the violator, the compliance history of the violator and other such factors as justice requires. 
(3)  Criminal prosecution. 
a.  Violations; generally. 
1.  Any person who willingly or knowingly violates any provision of this chapter or any order or permit issued under this chapter shall, upon conviction in a court of law, be guilty of a first degree misdemeanor, punishable as provided by state statute. 
2.  A second violation and conviction shall be a third degree felony, punishable as provided by state statute. 
b.  Falsifying information. 
1.  Any person who knowingly makes any false statement, representations or certifications in any application, record, report, plan or other document filed or required to be maintained pursuant to this chapter or any order or permit issued under this chapter, or who falsifies, tampers with, or knowingly renders inaccurate any monitoring device or method required under this or any order or permit issued under this chapter, shall, upon conviction in a court of law, be guilty of a first degree misdemeanor, punishable as provided by state statute. 
2.  A second violation and conviction shall be a third degree felony, punishable as provided by state statute. 
(b)  In addition to the penalties provided in subsection (a) of this section, any person who shall violate the provisions of this chapter shall be liable to the city for any damage caused to the property of the city or public utilities system and for reasonable costs and expenses, including but not limited to attorney's fees incurred in tracing, controlling and abating the violation, restoring the property or public utilities system to their former condition and in collecting sums due the city. 
(c)  The owner of a building, structure or premises where anything in violation of this chapter shall be placed or shall exist, and any person employed in connection with and who assisted or caused the commission of such violation, shall each be guilty of a separate offense and liable for the penalties provided herein. 
(d)  As an additional means of ensuring compliance with the provisions of this chapter the city code enforcement board shall have jurisdiction and authority to hear and decide alleged violations occurring within the corporate limits of the city. Proceedings before the code enforcement board shall be governed by its rules and procedures. 
(e)  Upon detection of prohibited acts as defined herein, the city shall be authorized to take immediate action to stop the violation and to remove and seize any equipment used in the commission of the violation. 
(Code 1982, § 23-49)  
Secs. 90-152—90-180. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - RATES, FEES AND CHARGES 
 
Sec. 90-181. - Rates, fees and charges. 
The rates, fees and charges for certain related services are set out in appendix B. 
(Code 1982, § 23-50) 
Cross reference— Connections, § 90-41.  
ARTICLE VII. - WATER CONSERVATION 
 
Sec. 90-182. - Short title. 
This article shall be known as the "water conservation ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 09-1886, § 1, 3-2-2009)  
Sec. 90-183. - Intent and purpose. 
It is the intent and purpose of this article to implement procedures that promote water conservation through more efficient landscape irrigation and prohibiting wasteful and unnecessary water use. 
(Ord. No. 09-1886, § 1, 3-2-2009)  
Sec. 90-184. - Definitions. 
For the purpose of this article, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivatives shall have the meaning given herein. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in the plural include the singular, and words in the singular include the plural. 
Address means the house number of a physical location of a specific property. This includes "rural route" numbers but excludes post office box numbers. If a lot number in a mobile home park or similar community is used by the U.S. Postal Service to determine a delivery location, the lot number shall be the property's address. An "even numbered address" means an address ending in the numbers 0, 2, 4, 6, 8 or the letters A—M. An "odd numbered address" means an address ending in the numbers 1, 3, 5, 7, 9 or the letters N—Z. 
District means the St. Johns River Water Management District.
